LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“She really ought to get away from him,” resumed Catherine to me. “They’re such beautiful shirts,” she went on, throwing her arms wide, “it makes me sad because I’ve never seen such — such beautiful shirts before.”

I glanced down at the shirts, at the pale, shifting, shimmering, under the moonlight, and then back at Catherine’s eager face. “You don’t understand,” she said. “He’s a very careful man.”

I nodded, not quite sure what she meant, but I was drawn into the conversation nonetheless.

“Tom’s got some woman in New York,” she continued, lowering her voice. “She might have been a great deal of trouble, but she’s not the kind of girl to let herself be taken advantage of. She’s got a lot of friends, and she’s very smart.”

I looked at her, surprised by the sudden shift in her tone. “You mean Myrtle Wilson?” I asked.

Catherine nodded. “Yes, Myrtle. She’s got a way of making people listen to her. She’s not like Daisy, you know. Daisy’s all about money and appearances, but Myrtle’s got a kind of fire.”

I thought about the contrast between the two women, the delicate, ethereal Daisy and the vibrant, earthy Myrtle. It was as if they belonged to different worlds, yet both were caught in the same web of Tom’s desires.

“Do you think Daisy knows about Myrtle?” I asked.

Catherine shrugged. “Who knows? Tom’s very careful. He’s got a way of keeping things separate. But you can tell by the way he looks at Myrtle that he’s not just fooling around.”

I felt a pang of sympathy for Daisy, imagining her in her elegant home, unaware or perhaps willfully ignorant of her husband’s infidelities.

“Sometimes I think Tom’s not a bad man,” Catherine said suddenly. “He’s just got a lot of trouble inside him. You can see it in his eyes.”

I looked at Tom, who was standing across the room, his face set in a hard, determined expression. There was something about him that was both commanding and cruel.

“Do you think he loves Daisy?” I asked.

Catherine laughed softly. “Love? I don’t know. Maybe he loves the idea of her. But he’s not the kind of man to be tied down.”

The room fell silent for a moment, the only sound the soft rustling of the curtains in the evening breeze.

“Sometimes I wonder what it would be like to live in their world,” I said. “All that wealth and glamour.”

Catherine smiled wistfully. “It’s not all it’s cracked up to be. There’s a lot of loneliness beneath the surface.”

I nodded, understanding more than I wanted to admit.

As the night wore on, the conversation drifted to other topics, but the image of Tom, Daisy, and Myrtle lingered in my mind. The tangled relationships, the secrets, and the lies painted a picture of a world that was both dazzling and tragic.

I realized that beneath the glittering facade of wealth and privilege, there were wounds that money could not heal, and hearts that were forever restless.

events.title: Violence Erupts and the Party Dissolves
detailed_summary: Myrtle defiantly shouts Daisy's name multiple times.
Tom reacts swiftly, striking Myrtle across the face with his open hand and breaking her nose.
The immediate aftermath involves bloody towels on the bathroom floor and the sounds of women scolding and Myrtle crying out in pain.
Mr. McKee awakens in a daze and starts to leave.
He pauses, observes the chaotic scene: his wife and Catherine tending to the bleeding Myrtle on the couch, who is trying to cover the Versailles tapestry with a gossip magazine.
Mr. McKee then continues out the door.
The narrator retrieves his hat and follows McKee.
In the elevator, McKee vaguely suggests getting lunch sometime.
The elevator operator reprimands McKee for touching the lever.
The narrator agrees to the lunch suggestion.
The narrative jumps, showing the narrator standing by McKee's bed as McKee, in his underwear, displays a portfolio of photographs with titles.
Finally, the narrator finds himself disoriented in the cold lower level of Pennsylvania Station early in the morning, reading a newspaper and waiting for the 4 a.m. train.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Daisy! Daisy! Daisy!” shouted Mrs. Wilson.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then I was lying half asleep in the cold lower level of the Pennsylvania Station, staring at the morning Tribune, and waiting for the four o’clock train.

events.text_segment:
“Daisy! Daisy! Daisy!” shouted Mrs. Wilson. “I’ll say it whenever I want to! Daisy! Dai—”
Making a short deft movement, Tom Buchanan broke her nose with his open hand.
Then there were bloody towels upon the bathroom floor, and women’s voices scolding, and high over the confusion a long broken wail of pain. Mr. McKee awoke from his doze and started in a daze toward the door. When he had gone halfway he turned around and stared at the scene—his wife and Catherine scolding and consoling as they stumbled here and there among the crowded furniture with articles of aid, and the despairing figure on the couch, bleeding fluently, and trying to spread a copy of Town Tattle over the tapestry scenes of Versailles. Then Mr. McKee turned and continued on out the door. Taking my hat from the chandelier, I followed.
“Come to lunch some day,” he suggested, as we groaned down in the elevator.
“Where?”
“Anywhere.”
“Keep your hands off the lever,” snapped the elevator boy.
“I beg your pardon,” said Mr. McKee with dignity, “I didn’t know I was touching it.”
“All right,” I agreed, “I’ll be glad to.”
… I was standing beside his bed and he was sitting up between the sheets, clad in his underwear, with a great portfolio in his hands.
“Beauty and the Beast… Loneliness… Old Grocery Horse… Brook’n Bridge…”
Then I was lying half asleep in the cold lower level of the Pennsylvania Station, staring at the morning Tribune, and waiting for the four o’clock train.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Daisy! Daisy! Daisy!" shouted Mrs. Wilson. "I'll say it whenever I want to! Daisy! Dai—"
Making a short deft movement, Tom Buchanan broke her nose with his open hand.
The bloody towels bunched and waved about on the floor.
Mrs. Wilson had changed her costume some time before, and was now attired in an elaborate afternoon dress of cream-colored chiffon, which gave out a continual rustle as she swept about the room.
She had a little dog, and her eyebrows had been plucked and then drawn on again at a more rakish angle but the efforts of nature toward the restoration of the old alignment gave a blurred air to her face.
Her laughter, her gestures, her assertions became more violently affected moment by moment, and as she expanded the room grew smaller around her.
The telephone rang inside, and the butler brought in a tray of cold fried chicken and a bottle of ale.
The two young women were now sitting on the couch, and Mrs. McKee was trying to cover the Versailles tapestry with a gossip magazine.
Mr. McKee, who had been dozing in a chair, got up and started to leave.
He paused, looked at the scene, and then went out the door.
I took my hat and followed him down the stairs.
In the elevator, he said, "You ought to come up sometime."
"I'd like to," I answered.
The elevator boy looked at us suspiciously and said, "Don't touch that lever."
"I won't," said Mr. McKee.
Later, I was standing by his bed, and he was showing me a portfolio of photographs, each with a title beneath it.
I was in the cold lower level of Pennsylvania Station early in the morning, reading a newspaper and waiting for the 4 a.m. train.

Making a short, deft movement, Tom Buchanan broke her nose with his open hand.

The bloody towels bunched and waved about on the floor.

"Oh, my God!" said Mrs. Wilson, and then she cried out in pain.

Mr. McKee, who had been dozing in a chair, woke up and started to get up.

events.title: Gatsby's Lavish Parties Described
detailed_summary: Music emanated from the neighbour's house during summer nights.
Guests, described metaphorically as moths, frequented his blue gardens amidst conversations, champagne, and stars.
During the day, guests enjoyed diving from a raft tower or sunbathing on his beach.
Gatsby's motorboats traversed the Sound, pulling aquaplanes.
On weekends, his Rolls-Royce transported groups to and from the city continuously, while his station wagon fetched guests from trains.
Every Monday, a large staff, including an extra gardener, worked to repair the weekend's festivities.
Large quantities of oranges and lemons were delivered weekly and juiced by a special machine.
Periodically, caterers set up extensive canvas tents and lighting.
Buffet tables featured elaborate food displays, including ornate salads and roasted meats.
A fully stocked bar with a brass rail offered a wide array of liquors, some unfamiliar to the younger guests.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was music from my neighbour’s house through the summer nights.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In the main hall a bar with a real brass rail was set up, and stocked with gins and liquors and with cordials so long forgotten that most of his female guests were too young to know one from another.

events.text_segment:
There was music from my neighbour’s house through the summer nights. In his blue gardens men and girls came and went like moths among the whisperings and the champagne and the stars. At high tide in the afternoon I watched his guests diving from the tower of his raft, or taking the sun on the hot sand of his beach while his two motorboats slit the waters of the Sound, drawing aquaplanes over cataracts of foam. On weekends his Rolls-Royce became an omnibus, bearing parties to and from the city between nine in the morning and long past midnight, while his station wagon scampered like a brisk yellow bug to meet all trains. And on Mondays eight servants, including an extra gardener, toiled all day with mops and scrubbing-brushes and hammers and garden-shears, repairing the ravages of the night before.
Every Friday five crates of oranges and lemons arrived from a fruiterer in New York—every Monday these same oranges and lemons left his back door in a pyramid of pulpless halves. There was a machine in the kitchen which could extract the juice of two hundred oranges in half an hour if a little button was pressed two hundred times by a butler’s thumb.
At least once a fortnight a corps of caterers came down with several hundred feet of canvas and enough coloured lights to make a Christmas tree of Gatsby’s enormous garden. On buffet tables, garnished with glistening hors-d’oeuvre, spiced baked hams crowded against salads of harlequin designs and pastry pigs and turkeys bewitched to a dark gold. In the main hall a bar with a real brass rail was set up, and stocked with gins and liquors and with cordials so long forgotten that most of his female guests were too young to know one from another.

events.title: The Party Atmosphere Intensifies
detailed_summary: A large orchestra, not a small ensemble, arrived by seven o'clock.
Swimmers returned from the beach to dress, and numerous cars from New York filled the driveway.
Halls and verandas became vibrant with brightly dressed guests, modern hairstyles, and luxurious shawls.
The bar operated at full capacity, with cocktails circulating throughout the garden.
The air filled with lively chatter, laughter, brief introductions, and superficial encounters between strangers.
As night fell, the lights brightened, the orchestra played upbeat music, and conversation grew louder.
Laughter became more frequent and unrestrained.
Social groups formed, dissolved, and reformed rapidly with new arrivals.
Confident young women moved through the crowd, briefly becoming centers of attention before moving on.
One woman impulsively grabbed a cocktail, drank it quickly, and began dancing alone on a platform.
After a brief silence, the orchestra adapted its rhythm for her.
A rumor spread incorrectly that she was a famous dancer's understudy, marking the true commencement of the party.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By seven o’clock the orchestra has arrived, no thin five-piece affair, but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos, and low and high drums.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The party has begun.

events.text_segment:
By seven o’clock the orchestra has arrived, no thin five-piece affair, but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos, and low and high drums. The last swimmers have come in from the beach now and are dressing upstairs; the cars from New York are parked five deep in the drive, and already the halls and salons and verandas are gaudy with primary colours, and hair bobbed in strange new ways, and shawls beyond the dreams of Castile. The bar is in full swing, and floating rounds of cocktails permeate the garden outside, until the air is alive with chatter and laughter, and casual innuendo and introductions forgotten on the spot, and enthusiastic meetings between women who never knew each other’s names.
The lights grow brighter as the earth lurches away from the sun, and now the orchestra is playing yellow cocktail music, and the opera of voices pitches a key higher. Laughter is easier minute by minute, spilled with prodigality, tipped out at a cheerful word. The groups change more swiftly, swell with new arrivals, dissolve and form in the same breath; already there are wanderers, confident girls who weave here and there among the stouter and more stable, become for a sharp, joyous moment the centre of a group, and then, excited with triumph, glide on through the sea-change of faces and voices and colour under the constantly changing light.
Suddenly one of these gypsies, in trembling opal, seizes a cocktail out of the air, dumps it down for courage and, moving her hands like Frisco, dances out alone on the canvas platform. A momentary hush; the orchestra leader varies his rhythm obligingly for her, and there is a burst of chatter as the erroneous news goes around that she is Gilda Gray’s understudy from the Follies. The party has begun.

Confident young women passed through the crowd, briefly the center of attention before moving on, their movements graceful and assured. Suddenly, one impulsive girl seized a cocktail, drank it down in a flash, and began to dance alone on a small platform. After a moment's silence, the orchestra shifted its rhythm to accompany her, the music adapting to her spontaneous performance. A rumor spread quickly, though incorrectly, that she was the understudy of a famous dancer named Anna Pavlova, and with that, the party truly began.

By seven o’clock the orchestra has arrived, no thin five-piece affair, but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos, and low and high drums. The lights grow brighter as the guests begin to pour in, their laughter and chatter filling the air with a vibrant energy. The garden is transformed into a shimmering wonderland, with lanterns hanging from the trees and the scent of blooming flowers mingling with the crisp night air. People in elegant gowns and sharp tuxedos move gracefully across the lawn, their faces glowing with excitement and anticipation.

Nick Carraway, standing near the edge of the crowd, observes the scene with a mixture of fascination and detachment. He notes the extravagance of Gatsby’s parties, the endless flow of champagne, and the seemingly endless stream of guests, many of whom he does not recognize. Yet, despite the opulence and gaiety, there is an undercurrent of restlessness, a sense that something is missing beneath the surface.

As the music swells, couples take to the dance floor, their movements synchronized with the lively rhythms. Gatsby himself appears, a figure of calm amidst the revelry, greeting guests with a warm smile and a gracious nod. His eyes, however, betray a deeper longing, a hope that tonight might bring him closer to the dream he has been chasing.

The night unfolds with a dazzling display of joy and excess, but as dawn approaches, the revelers begin to fade away, leaving behind only the echoes of laughter and the faint glow of the fading lights. In the quiet aftermath, the true nature of Gatsby’s world becomes clearer—a world built on illusion, desire, and the relentless pursuit of an unattainable ideal.

events.title: Nick Arrives at Gatsby's Party
detailed_summary: Nick reflects that he was likely one of the few attendees actually invited to Gatsby's parties.
He notes that most people simply showed up, arriving via car and finding their way to Gatsby's.
Upon arrival, guests were typically introduced by someone acquainted with Gatsby and then behaved freely, akin to being at an amusement park.
Many attendees never even met Gatsby, attending simply for the enjoyment of the party.
Nick confirms he received a formal invitation delivered by Gatsby's chauffeur earlier that Saturday.
The note expressed Gatsby's honor in inviting Nick to the 'little party' and mentioned prior intentions to meet, citing unspecified circumstances preventing it.
The invitation was signed by Jay Gatsby with a distinctive signature.
Dressed in white flannels, Nick went to Gatsby's around seven.
He felt uncomfortable amidst the unfamiliar crowd, though he recognized some faces from his commute.
Nick noticed many young Englishmen, well-dressed and seemingly eager, conversing intently with prosperous Americans.
He suspected they were involved in sales—bonds, insurance, or cars—keenly aware of the local wealth and hoping to capitalize on it.
Upon arriving, Nick tried to locate his host, Gatsby.
The few people he asked reacted with surprise and vehemently denied knowing Gatsby's location.
Feeling awkward, Nick retreated towards the cocktail table, seeing it as the only suitable place for a lone man to stand.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As soon as I arrived I made an attempt to find my host, but the two or three people of whom I asked his whereabouts stared at me in such an amazed way, and denied so vehemently any knowledge of his movements, that I slunk off in the direction of the cocktail table—the only place in the garden where a single man could linger without looking purposeless and alone.

events.text_segment:
I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. People were not invited—they went there. They got into automobiles which bore them out to Long Island, and somehow they ended up at Gatsby’s door. Once there they were introduced by somebody who knew Gatsby, and after that they conducted themselves according to the rules of behaviour associated with an amusement park. Sometimes they came and went without having met Gatsby at all, came for the party with a simplicity of heart that was its own ticket of admission.
I had been actually invited. A chauffeur in a uniform of robin’s-egg blue crossed my lawn early that Saturday morning with a surprisingly formal note from his employer: the honour would be entirely Gatsby’s, it said, if I would attend his “little party” that night. He had seen me several times, and had intended to call on me long before, but a peculiar combination of circumstances had prevented it—signed Jay Gatsby, in a majestic hand.
Dressed up in white flannels I went over to his lawn a little after seven, and wandered around rather ill at ease among swirls and eddies of people I didn’t know—though here and there was a face I had noticed on the commuting train. I was immediately struck by the number of young Englishmen dotted about; all well dressed, all looking a little hungry, and all talking in low, earnest voices to solid and prosperous Americans. I was sure that they were selling something: bonds or insurance or automobiles. They were at least agonizingly aware of the easy money in the vicinity and convinced that it was theirs for a few words in the right key.
As soon as I arrived I made an attempt to find my host, but the two or three people of whom I asked his whereabouts stared at me in such an amazed way, and denied so vehemently any knowledge of his movements, that I slunk off in the direction of the cocktail table—the only place in the garden where a single man could linger without looking purposeless and alone.

I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. People were not invited—they went there. They got into automobiles which bore them out to Long Island, and somehow they ended up at Gatsby’s door. Once there they conducted themselves according to the rules of behavior associated with amusement parks. Sometimes they came and went without having met Gatsby at all, came for the party with a simplicity of heart that was its own ticket of admission.

I was sure that Gatsby himself didn’t believe that his guests were coming to his house. He must have been glad to see me, because he was the first man I met. I had received a formal invitation from his chauffeur that afternoon, a note that said it was "a little party" and that he had intended to call on me but had been prevented by circumstances. The note was signed "Jay Gatsby" in a majestic hand.

I arrived at his house about seven o’clock, wearing white flannels, and I felt a little out of place among the swarms of people I did not know. I recognized a few faces from the train, but most were strangers. There were many young Englishmen, well-dressed and eager, who talked in low, earnest voices with prosperous Americans. I suspected they were selling bonds or insurance or automobiles, and were taking advantage of the local wealth.

I tried to find Gatsby, but when I asked a few people where he was, they looked at me in surprise and denied knowing him. Feeling awkward, I moved toward the cocktail table, which seemed the only place for a single man to stand.

I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. At least, that’s what I told myself as I navigated through the throng of people milling about the grand estate, the air thick with the hum of jazz and laughter. Gatsby’s parties were legendary, a kaleidoscope of opulence and extravagance, where the rich and the restless mingled beneath the shimmering lights. Yet, despite the spectacle, there was an air of mystery about the host himself. I had heard whispers and rumors, but none could quite capture the essence of Jay Gatsby.

As I stepped onto the manicured lawn, I caught sight of Gatsby standing apart from the crowd, his gaze distant yet inviting. He was a man of paradoxes—charming yet reserved, generous yet guarded. Our conversation that evening revealed a depth beneath the glittering surface, a yearning for something more profound than the fleeting pleasures of his lavish gatherings.

The guests came and went like waves, their faces a blur of excitement and indulgence. Yet, Gatsby remained a constant, a beacon amidst the chaos. His smile was genuine, his hospitality boundless, but there was a sadness in his eyes that spoke of dreams deferred and desires unfulfilled.

In the days that followed, I found myself drawn deeper into Gatsby’s world, uncovering layers of ambition, love, and loss. His story was intertwined with the shimmering promise of the American Dream, a testament to the relentless pursuit of happiness and the inevitable shadows that accompany it.

Reflecting on that first night, I realized that being invited to Gatsby’s house was more than a social courtesy—it was an entry into a narrative of hope and tragedy, a glimpse into the heart of a man who dared to dream beyond the confines of his reality.

events.title: Nick Reunites with Jordan and Hears Gossip About Gatsby
detailed_summary: Feeling intensely embarrassed and contemplating getting drunk, Nick spots Jordan Baker emerging from the house.
Jordan stood at the top of the steps, observing the garden with detached curiosity.
Nick felt compelled to join someone to avoid awkwardness.
He greeted her loudly across the garden.
Jordan acknowledged him casually, mentioning she thought he might be present since he lived nearby.
She briefly held his hand while listening to two girls in identical yellow dresses who approached.
The girls greeted Jordan, offering commiserations for her recent loss in a golf tournament final.
One girl mentioned they had met Jordan at a previous party about a month ago.
Jordan observed that the girl had changed her hair color since then.
As the girls departed, Jordan linked her arm with Nick's, and they walked down into the garden.
They accepted cocktails from a passing tray and sat at a table with the two girls in yellow and three unnamed men.
Jordan asked one of the girls if she attended Gatsby's parties frequently.
The girl confirmed she attended the last one where they met.
Her companion, Lucille, added that she enjoyed the parties because she could act freely and always had fun.
Lucille recounted tearing her dress at a previous party and receiving a replacement gown from Gatsby worth $265 after he asked for her details.
Jordan inquired if Lucille kept the expensive gown, which Lucille confirmed, noting it needed alterations.
The other girl remarked on the peculiarity of Gatsby's generosity, suggesting he avoids confrontation.
When Nick asked who they were discussing, the name 'Gatsby' was mentioned.
The two girls and Jordan leaned in together conspiratorially.
One girl whispered a rumor that Gatsby had killed someone.
This rumor created a palpable thrill among the group, including the three men.
Lucille countered sceptically, suggesting it was more likely he was a German spy during the war.
One of the men claimed confirmation from someone who supposedly grew up with Gatsby in Germany.
The first girl dismissed the spy theory, pointing out Gatsby served in the American army.
She intensified the murder rumor, suggesting observing Gatsby when he thinks he's unnoticed reveals his guilt.
Both Lucille and the first girl shivered, and the group instinctively looked around for Gatsby.
Nick mused on the romantic speculation surrounding Gatsby, noting even those usually indiscreet whispered about him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was testimony to the romantic speculation he inspired that there were whispers about him from those who had found little that it was necessary to whisper about in this world.

events.text_segment:
I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.
Welcome or not, I found it necessary to attach myself to someone before I should begin to address cordial remarks to the passersby.
“Hello!” I roared, advancing toward her. My voice seemed unnaturally loud across the garden.
“I thought you might be here,” she responded absently as I came up. “I remembered you lived next door to—”
She held my hand impersonally, as a promise that she’d take care of me in a minute, and gave ear to two girls in twin yellow dresses, who stopped at the foot of the steps.
“Hello!” they cried together. “Sorry you didn’t win.”
That was for the golf tournament. She had lost in the finals the week before.
“You don’t know who we are,” said one of the girls in yellow, “but we met you here about a month ago.”
“You’ve dyed your hair since then,” remarked Jordan, and I started, but the girls had moved casually on and her remark was addressed to the premature moon, produced like the supper, no doubt, out of a caterer’s basket. With Jordan’s slender golden arm resting in mine, we descended the steps and sauntered about the garden. A tray of cocktails floated at us through the twilight, and we sat down at a table with the two girls in yellow and three men, each one introduced to us as Mr. Mumble.
“Do you come to these parties often?” inquired Jordan of the girl beside her.
“The last one was the one I met you at,” answered the girl, in an alert confident voice. She turned to her companion: “Wasn’t it for you, Lucille?”
It was for Lucille, too.
“I like to come,” Lucille said. “I never care what I do, so I always have a good time. When I was here last I tore my gown on a chair, and he asked me my name and address—inside of a week I got a package from Croirier’s with a new evening gown in it.”
“Did you keep it?” asked Jordan.
“Sure I did. I was going to wear it tonight, but it was too big in the bust and had to be altered. It was gas blue with lavender beads. Two hundred and sixty-five dollars.”
“There’s something funny about a fellow that’ll do a thing like that,” said the other girl eagerly. “He doesn’t want any trouble with anybody.”
“Who doesn’t?” I inquired.
“Gatsby. Somebody told me—”
The two girls and Jordan leaned together confidentially.
“Somebody told me they thought he killed a man once.”
A thrill passed over all of us. The three Mr. Mumbles bent forward and listened eagerly.
“I don’t think it’s so much that,” argued Lucille sceptically; “It’s more that he was a German spy during the war.”
One of the men nodded in confirmation.
“I heard that from a man who knew all about him, grew up with him in Germany,” he assured us positively.
“Oh, no,” said the first girl, “it couldn’t be that, because he was in the American army during the war.” As our credulity switched back to her she leaned forward with enthusiasm. “You look at him sometimes when he thinks nobody’s looking at him. I’ll bet he killed a man.”
She narrowed her eyes and shivered. Lucille shivered. We all turned and looked around for Gatsby. It was testimony to the romantic speculation he inspired that there were whispers about him from those who had found little that it was necessary to whisper about in this world.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden. I followed her down a flight of stairs and across a deep green lawn to the hedge that was the boundary of the property. I felt that I wanted the world to be in uniform and at a sort of moral attention forever; I wanted no more riotous excursions with privileged glimpses into the human heart. Only Gatsby, the man who gives his name to this book, was exempt from my reaction—Gatsby, who represented everything for which I have an unaffected scorn.

"Hello," I shouted across the garden.

Jordan looked at me with a wan, charming smile. "I thought you were going to be at the office all day," she said.

"I live next door," I explained.

She held out her hand and I took it, feeling the coolness of her fingers. Two girls in yellow dresses came up behind her, and Jordan turned to them with a slight smile.

"Hello, Jordan," one of the girls said. "We heard about your loss in the golf tournament."

"Yes," the other added, "we were so sorry to hear."

"Thank you," Jordan said, her voice indifferent. "I suppose I was just unlucky."

"We met you at one of Gatsby's parties last month," the first girl said.

"You had your hair a different color then," Jordan observed.

The girls laughed and moved away, and Jordan linked her arm through mine as we walked down into the garden. A tray of cocktails was being passed around, and we accepted two and sat down at a table with the two girls in yellow and three men.

"Do you come to Gatsby's parties often?" Jordan asked one of the girls.

"I was at the last one," she replied.

"I like them," said Lucille, the other girl. "You can do whatever you want. I had a dress torn off me there once, and Gatsby sent me a new one worth $265. He asked me my address and sent it to me the next day."

"Do you still have it?" Jordan asked.

"Yes," Lucille said, "but it needs alterations."

"That's very generous of him," I said.

"Yes," the girl said, "but he doesn't like to be contradicted."

"Who are you talking about?" I asked.

"Gatsby," they said together, leaning in conspiratorially.

"I heard he killed a man," one whispered.

The three men looked at each other and smiled.

"I heard he was a German spy during the war," Lucille said skeptically.

"I know a man who grew up with him in Germany," one of the men said.

"But he was in the American army," the girl said.

"I think he killed a man," she repeated, "and when he thinks nobody's looking, he looks at you like he wants to kill you too."

Lucille and the girl shivered, and the group looked around as if expecting to see Gatsby himself.

I thought about the romantic speculation that surrounded Gatsby, and how even those who were usually indiscreet whispered about him.

I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden. She was dressed in white, and had a little white roadster, which she drove with a cool, indifferent air that made her seem somehow untouchable. Her eyes, bright and keen, scanned the crowd with a detached amusement, as if she were watching a play unfold before her.

"You look like a great advertisement for the Evening News," she said, smiling slightly as she noticed my discomfort. "Come on, let's get out of here."

We walked down the steps together, the gravel crunching beneath our feet, and I felt a sudden relief at her company. The party was a blur of laughter and music, but beneath it all was a tension I couldn't quite place. Gatsby was nowhere to be seen, and the guests seemed to be waiting for something, or someone.

Jordan led me to the edge of the garden, where the lights from the house cast long shadows across the lawn. "He's not here yet," she said, glancing back toward the house. "But he'll come. He always does."

I nodded, trying to steady my nerves. The evening had taken a strange turn, and I wasn't sure what to expect next. As we stood there, a figure appeared at the end of the driveway, silhouetted against the night sky. It was Gatsby, his tall frame unmistakable even in the dim light.

He approached us with a smile that seemed both genuine and rehearsed. "I'm sorry to keep you waiting," he said, his voice smooth and confident. "I had some business to attend to."

Jordan introduced me, and Gatsby shook my hand warmly. There was something magnetic about him, an aura of mystery that drew people in despite the rumors that swirled around his name. I found myself wanting to know more, to understand the man behind the legend.

As the night wore on, Gatsby and I talked about his past, his dreams, and the future he envisioned. He spoke with a passion that was both inspiring and unsettling, revealing a vulnerability beneath his polished exterior. It was clear that he was chasing something elusive, a dream that seemed just out of reach.

The party continued around us, but I was lost in Gatsby's world, captivated by his story and the intensity of his gaze. For a moment, I forgot my own troubles and the complicated web of relationships that bound us all together.

But as the first light of dawn began to creep over the horizon, reality intruded once more. Gatsby's smile faded, and a shadow crossed his face. "I have to go," he said quietly. "There are things I need to take care of."

Jordan and I watched as he disappeared into the early morning mist, leaving behind a sense of longing and unanswered questions. The garden was silent now, the echoes of the night's revelry fading into memory.

I realized then that Gatsby was a man defined by his dreams, a dreamer who refused to let go, no matter the cost. And in that moment, I understood that his story was far from over.

events.title: Encounter with the Owl-Eyed Man in the Library
detailed_summary: As the first supper service began, Jordan invited Nick to join her group at another table.
This group consisted of three married couples and Jordan's persistent, suggestive undergraduate escort, representing East Egg's reserved nobility contrasting with West Egg's flamboyance.
After about thirty minutes, Jordan expressed boredom with the polite company and suggested they leave to find Gatsby, noting Nick's unease about not having met him.
They searched the crowded bar, the top of the steps, and the veranda without finding Gatsby.
They decided to try an imposing door and entered a grand, oak-panelled library, likely imported.
Inside, a stout, middle-aged man with large spectacles sat drunk on a table, staring intently at the bookshelves.
He turned excitedly upon their entrance and scrutinized Jordan.
He demanded their opinion about the books.
Waving towards the shelves, he declared he had already ascertained their authenticity – they were real books with pages.
He expressed surprise, having expected them to be convincing fakes, like cardboard props.
To prove his point, he fetched a volume of the 'Stoddard Lectures'.
He triumphantly presented it as genuine printed matter, comparing Gatsby to the theatrical producer Belasco for his thorough realism.
He noted the pages weren't cut, implying they hadn't been read, but still praised the effort.
He quickly returned the book, warning that removing one might cause the whole library facade to collapse.
He inquired if Nick and Jordan were brought by someone, stating most guests were, including himself.
He mentioned being brought by a Mrs. Claud Roosevelt whom he met the previous night.
He admitted he'd been drunk for a week and hoped sitting in the library would sober him up.
When asked if it worked, he was unsure, having only been there an hour, and started to talk about the real books again.
Nick and Jordan confirmed he'd already told them, shook his hand formally, and left the library.

events.text_segment:
The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. There were three married couples and Jordan’s escort, a persistent undergraduate given to violent innuendo, and obviously under the impression that sooner or later Jordan was going to yield him up her person to a greater or lesser degree. Instead of rambling, this party had preserved a dignified homogeneity, and assumed to itself the function of representing the staid nobility of the countryside—East Egg condescending to West Egg and carefully on guard against its spectroscopic gaiety.
“Let’s get out,” whispered Jordan, after a somehow wasteful and inappropriate half-hour; “this is much too polite for me.”
We got up, and she explained that we were going to find the host: I had never met him, she said, and it was making me uneasy. The undergraduate nodded in a cynical, melancholy way.
The bar, where we glanced first, was crowded, but Gatsby was not there. She couldn’t find him from the top of the steps, and he wasn’t on the veranda. On a chance we tried an important-looking door, and walked into a high Gothic library, panelled with carved English oak, and probably transported complete from some ruin overseas.
A stout, middle-aged man, with enormous owl-eyed spectacles, was sitting somewhat drunk on the edge of a great table, staring with unsteady concentration at the shelves of books. As we entered he wheeled excitedly around and examined Jordan from head to foot.
“What do you think?” he demanded impetuously.
“About what?”
He waved his hand toward the bookshelves.
“About that. As a matter of fact you needn’t bother to ascertain. I ascertained. They’re real.”
“The books?”
He nodded.
“Absolutely real—have pages and everything. I thought they’d be a nice durable cardboard. Matter of fact, they’re absolutely real. Pages and—Here! Lemme show you.”
Taking our scepticism for granted, he rushed to the bookcases and returned with Volume One of the Stoddard Lectures.
“See!” he cried triumphantly. “It’s a bona-fide piece of printed matter. It fooled me. This fella’s a regular Belasco. It’s a triumph. What thoroughness! What realism! Knew when to stop, too—didn’t cut the pages. But what do you want? What do you expect?”
He snatched the book from me and replaced it hastily on its shelf, muttering that if one brick was removed the whole library was liable to collapse.
“Who brought you?” he demanded. “Or did you just come? I was brought. Most people were brought.”
Jordan looked at him alertly, cheerfully, without answering.
“I was brought by a woman named Roosevelt,” he continued. “Mrs. Claud Roosevelt. Do you know her? I met her somewhere last night. I’ve been drunk for about a week now, and I thought it might sober me up to sit in a library.”
“Has it?”
“A little bit, I think. I can’t tell yet. I’ve only been here an hour. Did I tell you about the books? They’re real. They’re—”
“You told us.”
We shook hands with him gravely and went back outdoors.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. This was a curious party. The three married couples were all talking in low, earnest voices, and Jordan's escort, a persistent undergraduate, was leaning forward with a suggestive expression, as if he expected something from her. They represented, I gathered, the well-to-do East Egg set, and their dignified homogeneity was a sharp contrast to the flamboyant West Egg crowd. After about half an hour, Jordan, who had grown bored with the polite company, said, "I'm bored now. I thought what I said was very clever."

"You said a great many things," I assured her.

"I know. I know. But I don't want to talk now. I want to find Gatsby."

"You never saw him."

"I know. I want to see him."

We went down the steps together and searched the crowded bar, the top of the steps, and the veranda, but Gatsby was nowhere to be found. Finally, we tried an imposing door and entered a library, a high-ceilinged room paneled in carved English oak, probably transported complete from some ruin overseas.

Inside, a stout, middle-aged man with enormous owl-eyed spectacles sat drunk on a folding table, staring with unsteady concentration at the shelves of books. He turned excitedly at our entrance and scrutinized Jordan with a faintly hostile curiosity.

"What do you think?"

"About what?"

"About the books."

He waved his hand at the shelves. "They're real. Pages and—here's one," he cried triumphantly, snatching a volume and opening it. "This here's a nice one. See? It's a bona-fide printed book."

"It's a nice library," I said.

"It's a library," he corrected. "It's a real library."

"Absolutely real—have pages and everything."

"Pages? Who's pages?"

"Pages."

"I thought they'd be a nice durable cardboard. Matter of fact, they're absolutely real. Pages."

He opened another volume. "See! It's a bona-fide piece of printed matter. It fooled me. This fella's a regular Belasco. It's a triumph. What thoroughness! What realism! Knew when to stop, too—didn't cut the pages. But what do you want?"

He replaced the book on the shelf and added, "You can't have a decent library without books, you know."

"I thought they'd be real," I admitted.

"The library's a nice touch, isn't it?"

"It's a library," I said.

"Yes, but what do you want?"

He looked at us gravely. "You were brought here by somebody, weren't you?"

"Yes," I said.

"Most of these people were brought here."

"I was brought here by a man named Gatsby."

"I was brought here by a lady named Mrs. Claud Roosevelt. I met her last night."

"Have you been drunk all day?"

"I've been drunk for about a week now, I guess."

"And you hope to sober up by sitting here?"

"I hope so."

"Has it worked?"

"I don't know. I've only been here an hour."

He began to talk about the books again, but Jordan and I assured him he had already told us all about them. We shook hands with him gravely and left the library.

1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion omits the direct dialogue exchanges between the characters, especially the back-and-forth about the books and the authenticity of the library. Instead, it summarizes these interactions, which reduces the immediacy and character dynamics present in the original.
- The completion invents a minor internal reaction from the narrator regarding the undergraduate's behavior, which is not present in the original passage.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion does not include the specific description of the party's function as representing a particular social group and their attitude toward the other guests, which is a key element in the original's depiction of social dynamics.
- The sense of the party's "dignified homogeneity" and their self-assigned role is not fully conveyed.
- The completion lacks the detail about the undergraduate's demeanor and the narrator's observation of his expectations regarding Jordan.
- The original's description of the library's architectural style and the suggestion that it was transported from overseas is only partially captured.
- The completion omits the muttered comment about the library collapsing if a book is removed, which adds to the characterization of the man in the library.
- The original's subtle humor and the awkwardness of the encounter, especially in the dialogue, are not fully present.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion inaccurately attributes a sense of boredom to the narrator regarding the undergraduate, which is not explicitly stated in the original.
- The sequence of searching for Gatsby is generally correct, but the completion does not clearly indicate the narrator's unease as being the reason for seeking Gatsby, as stated by Jordan in the original.
- The completion paraphrases the man's comments about the books and the library, but does not maintain the original's structure of repeated assertions and the demonstration with the book, which are important for the pacing and tone.
- The completion summarizes the handshake and departure rather than presenting it as a formal, grave gesture, which alters the tone of the ending.

The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. The air was thick with the scent of lilacs and the soft murmur of laughter and conversation. The garden was illuminated by strings of fairy lights that twinkled like stars, casting a warm glow over the guests. As I approached, I noticed the table was laden with an array of delicacies—platters of cold meats, bowls of fresh fruit, and glasses filled with sparkling champagne.

Jordan greeted me with a smile, her eyes sparkling with the same mischievous light that had first drawn me to her. "Come, sit with us," she said, patting the seat beside her. I took my place among the group, a mix of familiar faces and strangers, all caught up in the revelry of the evening.

The conversation flowed easily, punctuated by bursts of laughter and the clinking of glasses. Stories were exchanged, some true, others exaggerated for effect, but all contributing to the vibrant tapestry of the night. I found myself drawn into the warmth of the gathering, momentarily forgetting the complexities and uncertainties that had brought me here.

As the supper progressed, the music from the band grew louder, and some guests began to dance on the lawn, their movements graceful and carefree. The moon hung low in the sky, casting a silver light over the scene, adding to the dreamlike quality of the evening. I watched as Jordan moved among the guests, her presence commanding yet effortless, a queen in her domain.

At one point, Gatsby himself appeared, stepping out from the shadows with a smile that seemed both genuine and enigmatic. He approached our table, his eyes searching mine briefly before settling on Jordan. They exchanged a few words, their conversation hushed but charged with an unspoken understanding. Gatsby then turned to me, extending his hand in greeting. His grip was firm, his demeanor composed, yet there was an intensity beneath the surface that hinted at deeper emotions.

The night wore on, and the guests continued to revel, their spirits buoyed by the music, the wine, and the promise of endless possibilities. Yet beneath the surface, I sensed a tension, a fragile balance that could be disrupted at any moment. The grandeur of the party, the opulence of the setting, and the charm of the host all seemed to mask a deeper yearning, a longing for something just out of reach.

As the clock neared midnight, the first supper concluded, and the guests began to drift away from the tables, some heading towards the dance floor, others seeking quieter corners for more intimate conversations. Jordan leaned towards me, her voice low and conspiratorial. "There's always another supper," she whispered, "and with it, another chance to uncover the secrets that lie beneath the surface."

I nodded, feeling the weight of her words and the promise they held. The night was far from over, and the story of Gatsby's world was still unfolding, layer by intricate layer. In that moment, I realized that I was not merely a spectator but a participant in a drama that was as captivating as it was elusive, a tale of dreams and desires, of hope and heartbreak, set against the glittering backdrop of a world that was both dazzling and dangerous.

events.title: Nick Unknowingly Meets Gatsby
detailed_summary: Back outside, dancing had commenced on the garden's canvas platform.
Various couples danced, some awkwardly, some fashionably, while single girls danced alone or briefly joined the orchestra.
By midnight, the party's energy escalated; performers sang, guests performed 'stunts,' and laughter filled the air.
The girls in yellow performed a costumed act, and champagne was served in large glasses.
The moon cast a silvery light on the Sound.
Nick, still with Jordan, sat at a table with a man his age and a boisterous young woman.
Nick began enjoying himself after drinking champagne, finding the scene transformed.
During a pause, the man at the table smiled at Nick.
The man commented on Nick's familiar face and asked if he served in the First Division during the war.
Nick confirmed his service in the Twenty-eighth Infantry.
The man shared his own service in the Sixteenth Infantry.
They briefly reminisced about villages in France.
The man mentioned living nearby, having just bought a hydroplane he planned to test.
He invited Nick to join him for a flight along the shore the next morning.
Nick agreed and asked for a time, receiving a flexible response.
Just as Nick was about to ask the man's name, Jordan interjected, asking if he was having a better time.
Nick confirmed he was enjoying himself more and turned back to the man.
He explained the party was unusual for him as he hadn't met the host, gesturing towards his own house nearby and mentioning Gatsby sent the invitation.
The man looked momentarily confused.
He then identified himself suddenly as Gatsby.
Nick expressed surprise and apologized.
Gatsby, calling Nick 'old sport,' apologized for being a poor host, assuming Nick already knew who he was.
Gatsby offered a remarkable, reassuring smile that seemed to embrace the world before focusing entirely on Nick with immense favor.
The smile conveyed deep understanding and belief, projecting the exact positive impression Nick hoped to make.
The smile vanished abruptly, revealing an elegant man around thirty, whose formal speech bordered on absurd, suggesting carefully chosen words.
Nick realized Gatsby had been selecting his words deliberately even before the introduction.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was dancing now on the canvas in the garden; old men pushing young girls backward in eternal graceless circles, superior couples holding each other tortuously, fashionably, and keeping in the corners—and a great number of single girls dancing individually or relieving the orchestra for a moment of the burden of the banjo or the traps.

events.text_segment:
There was dancing now on the canvas in the garden; old men pushing young girls backward in eternal graceless circles, superior couples holding each other tortuously, fashionably, and keeping in the corners—and a great number of single girls dancing individually or relieving the orchestra for a moment of the burden of the banjo or the traps. By midnight the hilarity had increased. A celebrated tenor had sung in Italian, and a notorious contralto had sung in jazz, and between the numbers people were doing “stunts” all over the garden, while happy, vacuous bursts of laughter rose toward the summer sky. A pair of stage twins, who turned out to be the girls in yellow, did a baby act in costume, and champagne was served in glasses bigger than finger-bowls. The moon had risen higher, and floating in the Sound was a triangle of silver scales, trembling a little to the stiff, tinny drip of the banjoes on the lawn.
I was still with Jordan Baker. We were sitting at a table with a man of about my age and a rowdy little girl, who gave way upon the slightest provocation to uncontrollable laughter. I was enjoying myself now. I had taken two finger-bowls of champagne, and the scene had changed before my eyes into something significant, elemental, and profound.
At a lull in the entertainment the man looked at me and smiled.
“Your face is familiar,” he said politely. “Weren’t you in the First Division during the war?”
“Why yes. I was in the Twenty-eighth Infantry.”
“I was in the Sixteenth until June nineteen-eighteen. I knew I’d seen you somewhere before.”
We talked for a moment about some wet, grey little villages in France. Evidently he lived in this vicinity, for he told me that he had just bought a hydroplane, and was going to try it out in the morning.
“Want to go with me, old sport? Just near the shore along the Sound.”
“What time?”
“Any time that suits you best.”
It was on the tip of my tongue to ask his name when Jordan looked around and smiled.
“Having a gay time now?” she inquired.
“Much better.” I turned again to my new acquaintance. “This is an unusual party for me. I haven’t even seen the host. I live over there—” I waved my hand at the invisible hedge in the distance, “and this man Gatsby sent over his chauffeur with an invitation.”
For a moment he looked at me as if he failed to understand.
“I’m Gatsby,” he said suddenly.
“What!” I exclaimed. “Oh, I beg your pardon.”
“I thought you knew, old sport. I’m afraid I’m not a very good host.”
He smiled understandingly—much more than understandingly. It was one of those rare smiles with a quality of eternal reassurance in it, that you may come across four or five times in life. It faced—or seemed to face—the whole eternal world for an instant, and then concentrated on you with an irresistible prejudice in your favour. It understood you just so far as you wanted to be understood, believed in you as you would like to believe in yourself, and assured you that it had precisely the impression of you that, at your best, you hoped to convey. Precisely at that point it vanished—and I was looking at an elegant young roughneck, a year or two over thirty, whose elaborate formality of speech just missed being absurd. Some time before he introduced himself I’d got a strong impression that he was picking his words with care.

At least one of the stage twins, girls in yellow, had been doing a costume act, and there was a burst of laughter as a rowdy little girl in a pink dress ran out onto the canvas and began to dance. Champagne was served in glasses that were almost too large for the hands that held them, and the performers sang and performed stunts, their voices and laughter mingling with the music.

Nick, still with Jordan, sat at a table with a man about his own age and a boisterous young woman. After a few glasses of champagne, Nick found himself enjoying the scene more than he had expected. The man at the table smiled at him during a lull in the music.

"You look familiar," the man said. "Did you go to the war? First Division?"

"Twenty-eighth Infantry," Nick replied.

"Sixteenth," the man said. "I was in the Sixteenth."

They talked briefly about villages in France, and the man mentioned that he lived nearby and had just bought a hydroplane he intended to try out the next morning. He invited Nick to join him for a flight along the shore.

"What time?" Nick asked.

"Whenever you like," the man answered.

Just as Nick was about to ask the man's name, Jordan interjected, "Are you having a better time now?"

"Yes," Nick said, "much better."

He turned back to the man. "This is a very unusual party for me. I haven’t even met the host."

The man looked momentarily confused, then suddenly said, "I’m Gatsby."

Nick was surprised and apologized.

"I’m sorry," Gatsby said, calling Nick "old sport." "I’m afraid I’m not a very good host. I thought you knew who I was."

Gatsby smiled—a smile that seemed to embrace the whole world and then concentrated with an irresistible favor upon Nick. It was a smile that understood, believed in, and assured, projecting the exact impression of a man who had come to be trusted and admired.

Then the smile faded, and Gatsby appeared as an elegant man of about thirty, whose formal speech bordered on the absurd, as if he had chosen his words with care even before the introduction.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The lights grow brighter as the night deepens, casting a golden glow over the revelers. Laughter and music mingle in the warm air, creating a symphony of joy and abandon. The air is thick with the scent of jasmine and the faint hint of champagne, mingling with the soft rustle of silk and the crisp snap of tuxedos. In the midst of the swirling crowd, Gatsby stands apart, his eyes scanning the throng with a mixture of hope and melancholy. His smile is practiced, yet there is a distant look in his gaze, as if he is searching for something just beyond reach.

Nick Carraway, the narrator, observes the scene with a mixture of fascination and skepticism. He notes the extravagance and the carelessness of the guests, many of whom have come without invitation, drawn by the allure of Gatsby's wealth and the promise of a night to remember. Yet beneath the surface, there is an undercurrent of loneliness and longing, a sense that the glittering facade masks deeper truths.

As the music swells, a figure emerges from the crowd—Daisy Buchanan, radiant and ethereal, her laughter like the tinkling of crystal. She moves with a grace that captivates all who see her, yet there is a fragility in her smile, a hint of sadness that only Gatsby seems to perceive. Their eyes meet across the room, and for a moment, the world narrows to just the two of them, suspended in a fragile bubble of possibility.

The party continues into the early hours, the revelers lost in a haze of music, dance, and fleeting connections. Conversations drift from trivial gossip to whispered confessions, and the boundaries between reality and illusion blur. Gatsby's dream, embodied in the figure of Daisy, seems both within reach and impossibly distant, a shimmering mirage on the horizon of his desires.

As dawn approaches, the guests begin to depart, their laughter fading into the quiet of the morning. The garden, once alive with movement and sound, falls silent, bathed in the soft light of the rising sun. Gatsby remains, standing alone amidst the remnants of the night's festivities, his gaze fixed on the horizon where the green light flickers faintly across the water—a symbol of hope, yearning, and the elusive nature of the American Dream.

In this moment, the grandeur of the party gives way to a profound sense of solitude and reflection. The characters, each caught in their own web of dreams and disappointments, are left to confront the realities that lie beneath the surface of their glittering lives. The dance, the music, and the laughter are but fleeting distractions from the deeper truths that define their existence.

Through Nick's eyes, the reader is invited to contemplate the complexities of human desire, the illusions we create, and the inevitable passage of time that renders all things transient. The Great Gatsby, with its vivid portrayal of a world both dazzling and tragic, offers a timeless meditation on the pursuit of happiness and the cost of chasing dreams that may never be fulfilled.

events.title: Gatsby's Enigma and Detachment
detailed_summary: Immediately after Gatsby identified himself, a butler arrived with news of a phone call from Chicago.
Gatsby excused himself courteously to the group, urging Nick to ask for anything he needed and promising to return later.
Once Gatsby left, Nick turned to Jordan, expressing his surprise, admitting he had pictured Gatsby as older and heavier.
Nick asked Jordan about Gatsby's identity and origins.
Jordan replied simply that he's 'just a man named Gatsby.'
When pressed about Gatsby's background and profession, Jordan mentioned Gatsby once claimed to be an Oxford graduate.
This briefly created a potential background for Gatsby, but Jordan immediately expressed her disbelief.
Her sceptical tone reminded Nick of the earlier rumor about Gatsby killing someone, fueling his curiosity.
Nick reflected that humble origins would be understandable, but a young man mysteriously appearing and buying a palace seemed implausible.
Jordan steered the conversation away from specifics, stating she likes Gatsby's large, intimate parties where privacy is possible.
The orchestra leader announced the next piece, requested by Gatsby: Vladimir Tostoff's 'Jazz History of the World,' described as a recent sensation.
As the music started, Nick observed Gatsby standing alone on the steps, watching the party with an approving gaze.
Nick noted Gatsby's healthy appearance and neat grooming, seeing nothing sinister.
He speculated Gatsby's sobriety might set him apart, as Gatsby seemed to grow more formal while the guests became more uninhibited.
After the music ended, guests engaged in playful, intimate behavior, but no one approached Gatsby in such a manner; he remained separate.

events.text_segment:
Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire. He excused himself with a small bow that included each of us in turn.
“If you want anything just ask for it, old sport,” he urged me. “Excuse me. I will rejoin you later.”
When he was gone I turned immediately to Jordan—constrained to assure her of my surprise. I had expected that Mr. Gatsby would be a florid and corpulent person in his middle years.
“Who is he?” I demanded. “Do you know?”
“He’s just a man named Gatsby.”
“Where is he from, I mean? And what does he do?”
“Now you’re started on the subject,” she answered with a wan smile. “Well, he told me once he was an Oxford man.”
A dim background started to take shape behind him, but at her next remark it faded away.
“However, I don’t believe it.”
“Why not?”
“I don’t know,” she insisted, “I just don’t think he went there.”
Something in her tone reminded me of the other girl’s “I think he killed a man,” and had the effect of stimulating my curiosity. I would have accepted without question the information that Gatsby sprang from the swamps of Louisiana or from the lower East Side of New York. That was comprehensible. But young men didn’t—at least in my provincial inexperience I believed they didn’t—drift coolly out of nowhere and buy a palace on Long Island Sound.
“Anyhow, he gives large parties,” said Jordan, changing the subject with an urban distaste for the concrete. “And I like large parties. They’re so intimate. At small parties there isn’t any privacy.”
There was the boom of a bass drum, and the voice of the orchestra leader rang out suddenly above the echolalia of the garden.
“Ladies and gentlemen,” he cried. “At the request of Mr. Gatsby we are going to play for you Mr. Vladmir Tostoff’s latest work, which attracted so much attention at Carnegie Hall last May. If you read the papers you know there was a big sensation.” He smiled with jovial condescension, and added: “Some sensation!” Whereupon everybody laughed.
“The piece is known,” he concluded lustily, “as ‘Vladmir Tostoff’s Jazz History of the World!’ ”
The nature of Mr. Tostoff’s composition eluded me, because just as it began my eyes fell on Gatsby, standing alone on the marble steps and looking from one group to another with approving eyes. His tanned skin was drawn attractively tight on his face and his short hair looked as though it were trimmed every day. I could see nothing sinister about him. I wondered if the fact that he was not drinking helped to set him off from his guests, for it seemed to me that he grew more correct as the fraternal hilarity increased. When the “Jazz History of the World” was over, girls were putting their heads on men’s shoulders in a puppyish, convivial way, girls were swooning backward playfully into men’s arms, even into groups, knowing that someone would arrest their falls—but no one swooned backward on Gatsby, and no French bob touched Gatsby’s shoulder, and no singing quartets were formed with Gatsby’s head for one link.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire. Gatsby excused himself with a courteous nod to us all and went out into the hall. "If you want anything, Nick," he said, "just ask for it. I’ll be back in a minute." When he had gone, Jordan and I exchanged a surprised glance. "He’s a very careful man," she said. "I’d like to know who he is and what he does." "I thought he was a gentleman," I said. "He’s the kind of man you’d like to take home and introduce to your mother and sister." "He’s just a man named Gatsby," she answered. "That’s all." "Where is he from?" I asked. "Somewhere around the Middle West," she said. "He told me once he was an Oxford man." "An Oxford man!" I repeated. "Like hell he is! He wears a pink suit." "Well, he’s an Oxford man," she insisted. "He’s a man who’d like to be a gentleman." I remembered the story about the man who killed a man and then fled to the West. "Do you think he killed a man?" I asked. "I don’t know," she said. "I don’t want to talk about it." I thought about the mystery of Gatsby’s origins. It was hard to believe that a man who had appeared so suddenly and bought a mansion could have humble beginnings. "I like large parties," she said. "They’re so intimate. At small parties there isn’t any privacy." The orchestra leader announced the next number, a jazz composition called "Jazz History of the World," by Vladimir Tostoff, a recent sensation. As the music began, I noticed Gatsby standing alone on the marble steps, watching the party with an approving gaze. He looked healthy and well-groomed, with nothing sinister about him. Unlike the guests, who grew more uninhibited as the evening progressed, Gatsby seemed to become more formal. After the music ended, the guests engaged in playful, intimate behavior, but no one approached Gatsby in such a manner; he remained apart, observing quietly.

events.text_segment:
“I beg your pardon.”
Gatsby’s butler was suddenly standing beside us.
“Miss Baker?” he inquired. “I beg your pardon, but Mr. Gatsby would like to speak to you alone.”
“With me?” she exclaimed in surprise.
“Yes, madame.”
She got up slowly, raising her eyebrows at me in astonishment, and followed the butler toward the house. I noticed that she wore her evening-dress, all her dresses, like sports clothes—there was a jauntiness about her movements as if she had first learned to walk upon golf courses on clean, crisp mornings.
I was alone and it was almost two. For some time confused and intriguing sounds had issued from a long, many-windowed room which overhung the terrace. Eluding Jordan’s undergraduate, who was now engaged in an obstetrical conversation with two chorus girls, and who implored me to join him, I went inside.
The large room was full of people. One of the girls in yellow was playing the piano, and beside her stood a tall, red-haired young lady from a famous chorus, engaged in song. She had drunk a quantity of champagne, and during the course of her song she had decided, ineptly, that everything was very, very sad—she was not only singing, she was weeping too. Whenever there was a pause in the song she filled it with gasping, broken sobs, and then took up the lyric again in a quavering soprano. The tears coursed down her cheeks—not freely, however, for when they came into contact with her heavily beaded eyelashes they assumed an inky colour, and pursued the rest of their way in slow black rivulets. A humorous suggestion was made that she sing the notes on her face, whereupon she threw up her hands, sank into a chair, and went off into a deep vinous sleep.
“She had a fight with a man who says he’s her husband,” explained a girl at my elbow.
I looked around. Most of the remaining women were now having fights with men said to be their husbands. Even Jordan’s party, the quartet from East Egg, were rent asunder by dissension. One of the men was talking with curious intensity to a young actress, and his wife, after attempting to laugh at the situation in a dignified and indifferent way, broke down entirely and resorted to flank attacks—at intervals she appeared suddenly at his side like an angry diamond, and hissed: “You promised!” into his ear.
The reluctance to go home was not confined to wayward men. The hall was at present occupied by two deplorably sober men and their highly indignant wives. The wives were sympathizing with each other in slightly raised voices.
“Whenever he sees I’m having a good time he wants to go home.”
“Never heard anything so selfish in my life.”
“We’re always the first ones to leave.”
“So are we.”
“Well, we’re almost the last tonight,” said one of the men sheepishly. “The orchestra left half an hour ago.”
In spite of the wives’ agreement that such malevolence was beyond credibility, the dispute ended in a short struggle, and both wives were lifted, kicking, into the night.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“I beg your pardon.” I turned around and saw a man approaching, his face familiar yet shadowed by the dim light of the evening. It was Gatsby himself, his smile as enigmatic as ever, his eyes gleaming with a mixture of hope and melancholy. The garden around us was alive with the soft murmur of distant conversations and the gentle rustling of leaves stirred by a cool breeze.

“I didn’t mean to startle you,” he said, his voice smooth and reassuring. “I just wanted to make sure you were enjoying the party.”

I nodded, still a bit taken aback by his sudden appearance. “Yes, it’s quite something. The way you’ve transformed this place—it’s like stepping into another world.”

Gatsby’s smile widened, but there was a hint of sadness beneath it. “That’s the idea. To create a world where anything is possible, where the past can be rewritten.”

I looked at him closely, trying to decipher the layers beneath his charm. There was a restlessness in his gaze, a yearning that seemed to transcend the glittering facade of his lavish lifestyle.

“Do you ever get tired of it all?” I asked. “The parties, the guests who barely know you, the endless pursuit of something just out of reach?”

He sighed, a sound almost lost amidst the distant music. “Sometimes. But then I remember why I do it. For her.”

I understood immediately. Daisy. The name hung in the air between us, unspoken but palpable. Gatsby’s entire existence seemed to revolve around the hope of rekindling a love that time had tried to erode.

“Do you think she’ll come tonight?” I ventured.

He looked toward the house, where the lights shone brightly against the night sky. “I hope so. I’ve been waiting for this moment for years.”

As we stood there, the party continued unabated, a symphony of laughter, music, and clinking glasses. Yet, amidst the revelry, there was an undercurrent of tension, a fragile hope that something extraordinary might happen.

Suddenly, a figure appeared at the edge of the garden, her silhouette illuminated by the moonlight. Daisy. She moved gracefully toward us, her eyes sparkling with a mixture of surprise and affection.

“Gatsby,” she whispered, her voice trembling slightly.

He took her hand gently, his expression softening. “Daisy, I’ve waited so long.”

She smiled, a radiant smile that seemed to light up the night. “I know.”

In that moment, the world around us seemed to pause, the past and present converging in a delicate dance of hope and longing. The dream that Gatsby had nurtured for so long was finally within reach, yet the shadows of reality loomed just beyond the horizon.

As the night deepened, I realized that beneath the glittering surface of wealth and glamour lay a profound truth about the human heart—the relentless pursuit of love, the desire to reclaim lost time, and the fragile nature of dreams.

And so, the story of Gatsby and Daisy unfolded, a tale of passion and tragedy, set against the backdrop of a world forever changed by ambition and desire.

events.title: Jordan Hints at Secrets; Nick Departs
detailed_summary: While Nick waited for his hat, Jordan and Gatsby emerged from the library.
Gatsby was speaking earnestly to Jordan but quickly became formal as other guests approached to leave.
Jordan's group called for her from the porch, but she paused to shake Nick's hand.
She whispered that she had just heard something astonishing, asking how long they were in the library (about an hour).
Jordan repeated it was 'simply amazing' but stated she was sworn to secrecy, playfully tantalizing Nick.
Yawning, she invited Nick to visit, providing her aunt's name (Mrs. Sigourney Howard) for the phone book.
She hurried away, waving goodbye as she joined her party.
Feeling slightly embarrassed for staying so late on his first visit, Nick joined the remaining guests around Gatsby.
He wanted to explain his earlier search for Gatsby and apologize for not recognizing him.
Gatsby dismissed it warmly, telling Nick not to worry.
He reminded Nick about their hydroplane plans for nine the next morning, his familiar phrase ('old sport') now feeling less personal.
The butler interrupted, informing Gatsby that Philadelphia was on the phone.
Gatsby instructed the butler to tell them he'd be there shortly and bid Nick good night.
As Nick left, Gatsby's smile made him feel a pleasant significance in being among the last guests.
Gatsby repeated 'Good night, old sport... Good night.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Good night, old sport… Good night.”

events.text_segment:
As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together. He was saying some last word to her, but the eagerness in his manner tightened abruptly into formality as several people approached him to say goodbye.
Jordan’s party were calling impatiently to her from the porch, but she lingered for a moment to shake hands.
“I’ve just heard the most amazing thing,” she whispered. “How long were we in there?”
“Why, about an hour.”
“It was… simply amazing,” she repeated abstractedly. “But I swore I wouldn’t tell it and here I am tantalizing you.” She yawned gracefully in my face. “Please come and see me… Phone book… Under the name of Mrs. Sigourney Howard… My aunt…” She was hurrying off as she talked—her brown hand waved a jaunty salute as she melted into her party at the door.
Rather ashamed that on my first appearance I had stayed so late, I joined the last of Gatsby’s guests, who were clustered around him. I wanted to explain that I’d hunted for him early in the evening and to apologize for not having known him in the garden.
“Don’t mention it,” he enjoined me eagerly. “Don’t give it another thought, old sport.” The familiar expression held no more familiarity than the hand which reassuringly brushed my shoulder. “And don’t forget we’re going up in the hydroplane tomorrow morning, at nine o’clock.”
Then the butler, behind his shoulder:
“Philadelphia wants you on the phone, sir.”
“All right, in a minute. Tell them I’ll be right there… Good night.”
“Good night.”
“Good night.” He smiled—and suddenly there seemed to be a pleasant significance in having been among the last to go, as if he had desired it all the time. “Good night, old sport… Good night.”

"Don't worry about it, old sport," he said, though the phrase sounded less intimate than before. "We'll have the hydroplane out tomorrow at nine." Just then the butler came in and told Gatsby that Philadelphia was on the phone. "Tell them I'll be there in a minute," Gatsby said. Then he turned to me and said, "Good night, old sport." I left, feeling that there was some pleasant significance in being among the last to go. "Good night, old sport... Good night."
