To young Gatz, resting on his oars and looking up at the railed deck, that yacht represented all the beauty and glamour in the world. It was a rich cream color, bright with nickel, swollen here and there in its monstrous length with triumphant hatboxes and supper-boxes and tool-boxes, and terraced with a labyrinth of windshields that mirrored a dozen suns. The yacht represented the culmination of everything he had dreamed of. 

He had never seen a yacht before, and to him it was a thing of wonder and splendor. When Dan Cody came aboard, Gatsby, then James Gatz, was quick to smile and eager to please. The old man asked him questions, and Gatsby told him his name was Jay Gatsby, and that he had big plans for the future. 

Cody took a liking to the young man and hired him almost immediately. They went to Duluth, where Cody bought Gatsby a set of nautical clothes, and Gatsby joined him aboard the Tuolomee. For five years, Gatsby served as Cody's steward, mate, skipper, secretary, and even caretaker during Cody's bouts of heavy drinking. 

Cody trusted Gatsby to manage his affairs, especially when he was incapacitated by drink. They traveled together to the West Indies and the Barbary Coast, voyaging around the continent. 

Their association came to an abrupt end when Ella Kaye boarded the yacht in Boston. A week later, Dan Cody died, and Gatsby was left without the fortune he had hoped to inherit.

events.title: Dan Cody's Influence, Lost Inheritance, and Narrative Context
detailed_summary: The narrator recalls seeing a portrait of Dan Cody in Gatsby's bedroom, describing him as a 'pioneer debauchee'.
Cody represented the untamed, rough nature of the frontier brought to the East Coast.
Witnessing Cody's heavy drinking is cited as the indirect reason for Gatsby's own temperance.
Gatsby inherited $25,000 from Cody, but never received the money.
Legal maneuvering, likely by Ella Kaye, ensured the fortune went to her instead.
Despite losing the money, Gatsby gained what the narrator considers a uniquely fitting education from his time with Cody.
This experience transformed the 'vague contour' of Jay Gatsby into a fully formed man.
Nick explains he's recounting this history (told to him later by Gatsby) to correct the wild rumors about Gatsby's past.
He inserts this information during a pause in the main narrative to clarify Gatsby's background during a period of Nick's own confusion.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I take advantage of this short halt, while Gatsby, so to speak, caught his breath, to clear this set of misconceptions away.

events.text_segment:
I remember the portrait of him up in Gatsby’s bedroom, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon. It was indirectly due to Cody that Gatsby drank so little. Sometimes in the course of gay parties women used to rub champagne into his hair; for himself he formed the habit of letting liquor alone.
And it was from Cody that he inherited money—a legacy of twenty-five thousand dollars. He didn’t get it. He never understood the legal device that was used against him, but what remained of the millions went intact to Ella Kaye. He was left with his singularly appropriate education; the vague contour of Jay Gatsby had filled out to the substantiality of a man.
He told me all this very much later, but I’ve put it down here with the idea of exploding those first wild rumours about his antecedents, which weren’t even faintly true. Moreover he told it to me at a time of confusion, when I had reached the point of believing everything and nothing about him. So I take advantage of this short halt, while Gatsby, so to speak, caught his breath, to clear this set of misconceptions away.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I remember the portrait of him up in Gatsby’s bedroom, a grey, florid man with a hard, empty face—the pioneer debauchee, who during one phase of American life brought back to the Eastern seaboard the savage violence of the frontier brothel and saloon. That’s the man who taught Gatsby everything he knew, the man who took him out on his yacht and showed him the world. Dan Cody was a copper magnate, a man who had made his fortune in the rough and tumble of the West, and he represented to Gatsby the kind of grand, untamed life that Gatsby dreamed of. I remember Gatsby telling me how he had worked for Cody as his personal assistant, how he had been his protege, and how he had inherited twenty-five thousand dollars from him. But Gatsby never got the money. Ella Kaye, the woman who was with Cody at the end, had maneuvered to get the fortune for herself. Yet, despite losing the money, Gatsby gained something far more valuable: an education in the ways of the world, a sense of style and ambition, and the transformation from a vague, uncertain youth into the man he became. I tell you this now because I want to clear up the wild rumors about Gatsby’s past. There was a time when I was confused about who he really was, but after hearing this story, I understood the man behind the myth.

events.title: Tom Buchanan's Unpleasant Visit and Rude Departure
detailed_summary: The narrator notes a pause in his involvement with Gatsby's life, during which he spent time in New York with Jordan Baker.
He visits Gatsby's house one Sunday afternoon.
Tom Buchanan arrives unexpectedly on horseback, accompanied by a man named Sloane and a woman.
Gatsby greets them effusively but appears unsettled by Tom's presence, rushing to offer drinks.
Mr. Sloane rudely declines all refreshments.
An awkward conversation follows about the ride and local roads.
Gatsby initiates a tense exchange by reminding Tom they had met previously.
Tom responds with gruff politeness but clearly doesn't recall the earlier meeting well.
Gatsby pointedly mentions knowing Tom's wife.
Sloane remains aloof, while the woman becomes friendly after drinking and suggests they all attend Gatsby's next party.
Gatsby invites them to stay for supper, but the woman counters with an invitation for Gatsby and Nick to join *her* supper party.
Sloane subtly tries to dissuade the woman and makes it clear Gatsby is not included in his address to her.
Gatsby, eager to go and see more of Tom, misses the social cue and agrees, offering to follow in his car as he lacks a horse.
While Gatsby goes inside to prepare, the others wait on the porch.
Sloane and the woman have a heated, private discussion.
Tom expresses incredulity and disdain that Gatsby thinks he's actually invited, questioning where he met Daisy and criticizing modern women.
Sloane and the woman abruptly mount their horses and prepare to leave.
Sloane curtly tells Tom they are late and asks Nick to inform Gatsby they couldn't wait.
After cool farewells, the trio rides away quickly.
Gatsby emerges from the house, ready to leave, just as they vanish down the drive.

events.text_segment:
It was a halt, too, in my association with his affairs. For several weeks I didn’t see him or hear his voice on the phone—mostly I was in New York, trotting around with Jordan and trying to ingratiate myself with her senile aunt—but finally I went over to his house one Sunday afternoon. I hadn’t been there two minutes when somebody brought Tom Buchanan in for a drink. I was startled, naturally, but the really surprising thing was that it hadn’t happened before.
They were a party of three on horseback—Tom and a man named Sloane and a pretty woman in a brown riding-habit, who had been there previously.
“I’m delighted to see you,” said Gatsby, standing on his porch. “I’m delighted that you dropped in.”
As though they cared!
“Sit right down. Have a cigarette or a cigar.” He walked around the room quickly, ringing bells. “I’ll have something to drink for you in just a minute.”
He was profoundly affected by the fact that Tom was there. But he would be uneasy anyhow until he had given them something, realizing in a vague way that that was all they came for. Mr. Sloane wanted nothing. A lemonade? No, thanks. A little champagne? Nothing at all, thanks… I’m sorry—
“Did you have a nice ride?”
“Very good roads around here.”
“I suppose the automobiles—”
“Yeah.”
Moved by an irresistible impulse, Gatsby turned to Tom, who had accepted the introduction as a stranger.
“I believe we’ve met somewhere before, Mr. Buchanan.”
“Oh, yes,” said Tom, gruffly polite, but obviously not remembering. “So we did. I remember very well.”
“About two weeks ago.”
“That’s right. You were with Nick here.”
“I know your wife,” continued Gatsby, almost aggressively.
“That so?”
Tom turned to me.
“You live near here, Nick?”
“Next door.”
“That so?”
Mr. Sloane didn’t enter into the conversation, but lounged back haughtily in his chair; the woman said nothing either—until unexpectedly, after two highballs, she became cordial.
“We’ll all come over to your next party, Mr. Gatsby,” she suggested. “What do you say?”
“Certainly; I’d be delighted to have you.”
“Be ver’ nice,” said Mr. Sloane, without gratitude. “Well—think ought to be starting home.”
“Please don’t hurry,” Gatsby urged them. He had control of himself now, and he wanted to see more of Tom. “Why don’t you—why don’t you stay for supper? I wouldn’t be surprised if some other people dropped in from New York.”
“You come to supper with me,” said the lady enthusiastically. “Both of you.”
This included me. Mr. Sloane got to his feet.
“Come along,” he said—but to her only.
“I mean it,” she insisted. “I’d love to have you. Lots of room.”
Gatsby looked at me questioningly. He wanted to go and he didn’t see that Mr. Sloane had determined he shouldn’t.
“I’m afraid I won’t be able to,” I said.
“Well, you come,” she urged, concentrating on Gatsby.
Mr. Sloane murmured something close to her ear.
“We won’t be late if we start now,” she insisted aloud.
“I haven’t got a horse,” said Gatsby. “I used to ride in the army, but I’ve never bought a horse. I’ll have to follow you in my car. Excuse me for just a minute.”
The rest of us walked out on the porch, where Sloane and the lady began an impassioned conversation aside.
“My God, I believe the man’s coming,” said Tom. “Doesn’t he know she doesn’t want him?”
“She says she does want him.”
“She has a big dinner party and he won’t know a soul there.” He frowned. “I wonder where in the devil he met Daisy. By God, I may be old-fashioned in my ideas, but women run around too much these days to suit me. They meet all kinds of crazy fish.”
Suddenly Mr. Sloane and the lady walked down the steps and mounted their horses.
“Come on,” said Mr. Sloane to Tom, “we’re late. We’ve got to go.” And then to me: “Tell him we couldn’t wait, will you?”
Tom and I shook hands, the rest of us exchanged a cool nod, and they trotted quickly down the drive, disappearing under the August foliage just as Gatsby, with hat and light overcoat in hand, came out the front door.

It was a halt, too, in my association with his affairs. For a while, I found myself adrift, caught between the glittering world Gatsby inhabited and the more grounded reality I had always known. The parties, the lavish displays, the endless stream of guests—all seemed to fade into a distant hum, replaced by a quiet contemplation of what it all meant.

Gatsby himself remained an enigma, a figure both larger than life and deeply vulnerable. His relentless pursuit of a dream, embodied in the green light across the bay, was both inspiring and tragic. I often wondered if he truly believed in the possibility of recapturing the past, or if he was merely chasing a phantom that would forever elude him.

In the days that followed, I found myself reflecting on the nature of the American Dream, the illusions we chase, and the realities we must face. Gatsby's story was a cautionary tale, a reminder that wealth and status could not buy happiness or fulfillment. Yet, there was something undeniably noble in his unwavering hope, his refusal to accept the limitations imposed by society or circumstance.

As the summer waned, the parties ceased, and the mansion grew quiet. The guests disappeared as swiftly as they had arrived, leaving behind only memories and the faint scent of extravagance. Gatsby's world, once so vibrant and alive, seemed to dissolve into the twilight, a fleeting moment of brilliance in the vast expanse of time.

In the end, it was not the glittering facade that defined Gatsby, but the man beneath—the dreamer who dared to believe in the impossible. And though his story ended in tragedy, it left an indelible mark on those who knew him, a testament to the enduring power of hope and the complexities of the human heart.

events.text_segment:
Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party. Perhaps his presence gave the evening its peculiar quality of oppressiveness—it stands out in my memory from Gatsby’s other parties that summer. There were the same people, or at least the same sort of people, the same profusion of champagne, the same many-coloured, many-keyed commotion, but I felt an unpleasantness in the air, a pervading harshness that hadn’t been there before. Or perhaps I had merely grown used to it, grown to accept West Egg as a world complete in itself, with its own standards and its own great figures, second to nothing because it had no consciousness of being so, and now I was looking at it again, through Daisy’s eyes. It is invariably saddening to look through new eyes at things upon which you have expended your own powers of adjustment.
They arrived at twilight, and, as we strolled out among the sparkling hundreds, Daisy’s voice was playing murmurous tricks in her throat.
“These things excite me so,” she whispered. “If you want to kiss me any time during the evening, Nick, just let me know and I’ll be glad to arrange it for you. Just mention my name. Or present a green card. I’m giving out green—”
“Look around,” suggested Gatsby.
“I’m looking around. I’m having a marvellous—”
“You must see the faces of many people you’ve heard about.”
Tom’s arrogant eyes roamed the crowd.
“We don’t go around very much,” he said; “in fact, I was just thinking I don’t know a soul here.”
“Perhaps you know that lady.” Gatsby indicated a gorgeous, scarcely human orchid of a woman who sat in state under a white-plum tree. Tom and Daisy stared, with that peculiarly unreal feeling that accompanies the recognition of a hitherto ghostly celebrity of the movies.
“She’s lovely,” said Daisy.
“The man bending over her is her director.”
He took them ceremoniously from group to group:
“Mrs. Buchanan… and Mr. Buchanan—” After an instant’s hesitation he added: “the polo player.”
“Oh no,” objected Tom quickly, “not me.”
But evidently the sound of it pleased Gatsby for Tom remained “the polo player” for the rest of the evening.
“I’ve never met so many celebrities,” Daisy exclaimed. “I liked that man—what was his name?—with the sort of blue nose.”
Gatsby identified him, adding that he was a small producer.
“Well, I liked him anyhow.”
“I’d a little rather not be the polo player,” said Tom pleasantly, “I’d rather look at all these famous people in—in oblivion.”
Daisy and Gatsby danced. I remember being surprised by his graceful, conservative foxtrot—I had never seen him dance before. Then they sauntered over to my house and sat on the steps for half an hour, while at her request I remained watchfully in the garden. “In case there’s a fire or a flood,” she explained, “or any act of God.”
Tom appeared from his oblivion as we were sitting down to supper together. “Do you mind if I eat with some people over here?” he said. “A fellow’s getting off some funny stuff.”
“Go ahead,” answered Daisy genially, “and if you want to take down any addresses here’s my little gold pencil.”… She looked around after a moment and told me the girl was “common but pretty,” and I knew that except for the half-hour she’d been alone with Gatsby she wasn’t having a good time.

It was as if the presence of Tom Buchanan cast a shadow over the festivities, or perhaps it was the way Daisy looked at the familiar scene with a new, critical eye. Nick thought about how sad it was to see things through someone else's perspective, especially when it altered the charm of the familiar.

She observed the girl Tom joined, remarking to Nick that she was "common but pretty."

Nick concluded that Daisy was generally unhappy at the party, finding enjoyment only during her private time with Gatsby.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party. This time he was not a little hostile. He had changed since his New Haven years. Now he was a sturdy, straw-haired man of thirty with a rather hard mouth and a supercilious manner. Two shining arrogant eyes had established dominance over his face and gave him the appearance of always leaning aggressively forward. Not even the effeminate swank of his riding clothes could hide the enormous power of that body—he seemed to fill those glistening boots until he strained the top lacing, and you could see a great pack of muscle shifting when his shoulder moved under his thin coat. It was a body capable of enormous leverage—a cruel body.

The party had begun to fall off a little in the past week or so. The lights in the house failed to go on one Saturday night, and, when I came over to the window to see what was happening, I saw that the whole front of the house was blazing with light, and the garden was crowded with a whole pitiful swarm of faces. But the lights were on now, and the music was playing, and the whole scene had a certain harshness that I had not noticed before. I wondered if it was because of Tom’s presence or because I was seeing the familiar West Egg scene through Daisy’s eyes. It was sad to realize how much the world had changed, and how the things you had always known could look so different when seen through new eyes.

Daisy arrived, radiant and excited, and whispered to me, “You must come and see the house sometime.” She leaned close and said, “I’m glad it’s a girl. And I hope she’ll be a fool—that’s the best thing a girl can be in this world, a beautiful little fool.” She smiled mischievously and added, “You must know Gatsby.”

Gatsby came over and began to show off, pointing out the famous people who had come to the party. “That’s a movie star,” he said, indicating a woman in a shimmering dress. “And that’s her director.”

Tom looked around with a bored expression. “I don’t know anybody here,” he said.

Gatsby smiled and said, “That’s Mr. Sloane, the polo player.”

Tom frowned. “I’m the polo player,” he said.

“No,” Gatsby insisted, “you’re the polo player.”

Daisy laughed and said, “I like to see you at a party, Tom. You’re so quiet. I like to see you dance.”

Tom said, “I don’t care for all these people. I like to see the famous people. I like to see them when they don’t know they’re being looked at.”

I was surprised to see Gatsby dance so gracefully when he took Daisy in his arms. I had never seen him dance before.

Later, Daisy and Gatsby sat on the steps of my porch, talking quietly for half an hour. Daisy asked me to stand guard while they talked, and I stayed in the garden, watching the party go on without them.

Tom came to the porch and said, “I’m going to eat with the other crowd. They’re telling some pretty good stories.”

Daisy gave him her gold pencil and said, “You can take down their addresses.”

She looked at the girl Tom had joined and said to me, “She’s common but pretty.”

I thought that Daisy was generally unhappy at the party, and that she found her only real enjoyment in the private moments she shared with Gatsby.

Tom was evidently perturbed at Daisy’s running around alone, for on the following Saturday night he came with her to Gatsby’s party. The evening was charged with a peculiar tension, a silent battle waged beneath the glittering surface of laughter and music. Gatsby, ever the gracious host, welcomed them with a smile that seemed to hold a secret, a hope that perhaps this night would bring him closer to the dream he had so carefully constructed.

The mansion was alive with the hum of conversation and the clinking of glasses, the air thick with the scent of expensive perfume and the faint trace of cigar smoke. Guests moved like shadows through the rooms, their faces illuminated by the soft glow of chandeliers, their voices rising and falling in a symphony of idle chatter and whispered gossip.

Daisy, radiant in a gown that shimmered like moonlight, seemed both enchanted and uneasy. Her eyes flickered with a mixture of curiosity and apprehension as she took in the opulence around her. Tom, his jaw set and his gaze sharp, watched her closely, his discomfort growing with each passing moment.

Gatsby approached them with a confidence that belied the nervous flutter in his chest. He introduced them to a few of his acquaintances, his voice steady but his hands betraying a slight tremor. As the evening wore on, Gatsby found moments to speak with Daisy alone, their conversations laced with nostalgia and unspoken longing.

Tom, sensing the undercurrent between them, grew increasingly agitated. His laughter became forced, his remarks edged with sarcasm. At one point, he pulled Daisy aside, his voice low and urgent, warning her of the dangers of indulging in Gatsby’s world.

But Daisy, caught between the past and the present, between the security of her marriage and the allure of a rekindled romance, seemed torn. Her heart fluttered with memories of a time when life was simpler, when love was untainted by the complexities of wealth and status.

As the night deepened, the party reached its crescendo. The music swelled, the dancers twirled beneath the stars, and the champagne flowed freely. Yet, amidst the revelry, an undercurrent of unease persisted, a silent acknowledgment that the night’s enchantment was fragile, that the illusions it fostered could shatter with the dawn.

In a quiet moment, Gatsby and Daisy stood together on the terrace, the city lights sparkling below like a sea of fireflies. Gatsby’s voice was soft, filled with hope and desperation as he spoke of the future he dreamed of, a future where they could be together, unburdened by the past.

Daisy’s eyes glistened with tears, her voice barely a whisper as she confessed her own desires and fears. The world around them seemed to fade, leaving only the two of them suspended in a fragile bubble of possibility.

But reality intruded with the arrival of Tom, his presence a stark reminder of the barriers that separated them. The moment dissolved, replaced by a tense silence that spoke volumes.

As the guests began to depart, the night’s magic waned. Tom and Daisy left together, their faces masks of composure, concealing the turmoil beneath. Gatsby watched them go, his heart heavy with the weight of unfulfilled dreams.

The party, once a beacon of hope and celebration, now seemed a hollow echo of what might have been. Gatsby retreated into the shadows of his mansion, the silence a stark contrast to the night’s earlier exuberance.

In the days that followed, the fragile equilibrium between the characters shifted, setting in motion a chain of events that would unravel the carefully woven tapestry of their lives. The Saturday night at Gatsby’s party became a turning point, a moment where illusions collided with reality, and the true nature of love, ambition, and betrayal was laid bare.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We were at a particularly tipsy table.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Perhaps some unbelievable guest would arrive, a person infinitely rare and to be marvelled at, some authentically radiant young girl who with one fresh glance at Gatsby, one moment of magical encounter, would blot out those five years of unwavering devotion.

events.text_segment:
We were at a particularly tipsy table. That was my fault—Gatsby had been called to the phone, and I’d enjoyed these same people only two weeks before. But what had amused me then turned septic on the air now.
“How do you feel, Miss Baedeker?”
The girl addressed was trying, unsuccessfully, to slump against my shoulder. At this inquiry she sat up and opened her eyes.
“Wha’?”
A massive and lethargic woman, who had been urging Daisy to play golf with her at the local club tomorrow, spoke in Miss Baedeker’s defence:
“Oh, she’s all right now. When she’s had five or six cocktails she always starts screaming like that. I tell her she ought to leave it alone.”
“I do leave it alone,” affirmed the accused hollowly.
“We heard you yelling, so I said to Doc Civet here: ‘There’s somebody that needs your help, Doc.’ ”
“She’s much obliged, I’m sure,” said another friend, without gratitude, “but you got her dress all wet when you stuck her head in the pool.”
“Anything I hate is to get my head stuck in a pool,” mumbled Miss Baedeker. “They almost drowned me once over in New Jersey.”
“Then you ought to leave it alone,” countered Doctor Civet.
“Speak for yourself!” cried Miss Baedeker violently. “Your hand shakes. I wouldn’t let you operate on me!”
It was like that. Almost the last thing I remember was standing with Daisy and watching the moving-picture director and his Star. They were still under the white-plum tree and their faces were touching except for a pale, thin ray of moonlight between. It occurred to me that he had been very slowly bending toward her all evening to attain this proximity, and even while I watched I saw him stoop one ultimate degree and kiss at her cheek.
“I like her,” said Daisy, “I think she’s lovely.”
But the rest offended her—and inarguably because it wasn’t a gesture but an emotion. She was appalled by West Egg, this unprecedented “place” that Broadway had begotten upon a Long Island fishing village—appalled by its raw vigour that chafed under the old euphemisms and by the too obtrusive fate that herded its inhabitants along a shortcut from nothing to nothing. She saw something awful in the very simplicity she failed to understand.
I sat on the front steps with them while they waited for their car. It was dark here in front; only the bright door sent ten square feet of light volleying out into the soft black morning. Sometimes a shadow moved against a dressing-room blind above, gave way to another shadow, an indefinite procession of shadows, who rouged and powdered in an invisible glass.
“Who is this Gatsby anyhow?” demanded Tom suddenly. “Some big bootlegger?”
“Where’d you hear that?” I inquired.
“I didn’t hear it. I imagined it. A lot of these newly rich people are just big bootleggers, you know.”
“Not Gatsby,” I said shortly.
He was silent for a moment. The pebbles of the drive crunched under his feet.
“Well, he certainly must have strained himself to get this menagerie together.”
A breeze stirred the grey haze of Daisy’s fur collar.
“At least they are more interesting than the people we know,” she said with an effort.
“You didn’t look so interested.”
“Well, I was.”
Tom laughed and turned to me.
“Did you notice Daisy’s face when that girl asked her to put her under a cold shower?”
Daisy began to sing with the music in a husky, rhythmic whisper, bringing out a meaning in each word that it had never had before and would never have again. When the melody rose her voice broke up sweetly, following it, in a way contralto voices have, and each change tipped out a little of her warm human magic upon the air.
“Lots of people come who haven’t been invited,” she said suddenly. “That girl hadn’t been invited. They simply force their way in and he’s too polite to object.”
“I’d like to know who he is and what he does,” insisted Tom. “And I think I’ll make a point of finding out.”
“I can tell you right now,” she answered. “He owned some drugstores, a lot of drugstores. He built them up himself.”
The dilatory limousine came rolling up the drive.
“Good night, Nick,” said Daisy.
Her glance left me and sought the lighted top of the steps, where “Three O’Clock in the Morning,” a neat, sad little waltz of that year, was drifting out the open door. After all, in the very casualness of Gatsby’s party there were romantic possibilities totally absent from her world. What was it up there in the song that seemed to be calling her back inside? What would happen now in the dim, incalculable hours? Perhaps some unbelievable guest would arrive, a person infinitely rare and to be marvelled at, some authentically radiant young girl who with one fresh glance at Gatsby, one moment of magical encounter, would blot out those five years of unwavering devotion.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
We were at a particularly tipsy table. Miss Baedeker, who had been drinking steadily, was now quite drunk and loud, recounting how she had been dunked in the pool earlier in the evening. She traded barbed remarks with Doctor Civet, who was equally inebriated and irritable. The atmosphere was thick with the smell of cheap perfume and stale liquor, and the conversation was a jumble of insults and laughter.

Later, Daisy and I stepped away from the table and wandered toward the edge of the garden. Under a large tree, we saw the movie director passionately kissing his star companion. Daisy watched them with a soft smile and said, "She's lovely."

But as we looked around at the crowd, the raw vigor and lack of refinement in West Egg struck Daisy deeply. She was appalled by the crudeness and the reckless abandon of the guests, the way they seemed to live without any social graces or restraint. "It's so different from what I know," she murmured. "The simplicity of it all is awful."

As we waited for our car, Tom suddenly turned to me and said, "I bet Gatsby's a bootlegger."

I laughed it off, but Tom was serious. He criticized Gatsby's choice of guests, calling them vulgar and unworthy. Daisy, however, defended them, saying they were more interesting than our own circle, though Tom doubted her sincerity.

Daisy began humming along with the music drifting from Gatsby's house, her voice soft and wistful. She complained about the uninvited guests who forced their way into Gatsby's parties, spoiling the atmosphere.

Tom insisted he would find out more about Gatsby's background and business dealings. Daisy offered an explanation, claiming that Gatsby owned a chain of drugstores he had built himself.

As our limousine arrived, Daisy said goodnight, her eyes lingering on Gatsby's house and the music that floated through the night air. I thought about the romantic possibilities that Gatsby's world held, so different from Daisy's own. I wondered what might be happening inside, and if perhaps a new, captivating guest might arrive who could one day replace Daisy in Gatsby's long-held devotion.

As we waited for our car, Tom suddenly said, "I bet Gatsby's a bootlegger."

I laughed, but Tom was serious. He criticized Gatsby's guests, calling them vulgar and unworthy. Daisy defended them, saying they were more interesting than our own crowd, though Tom doubted her sincerity.

Daisy began humming and singing softly along with the music drifting from Gatsby's house. She complained about the uninvited guests who forced their way into Gatsby's parties.

Tom insisted he would find out about Gatsby's background and business. Daisy offered an explanation, saying Gatsby owned a chain of drugstores he had built himself.

When the limousine arrived, Daisy said goodnight, her eyes lingering on Gatsby's house and the music that floated through the night. I thought about the romantic possibilities in Gatsby's world, so different from Daisy's own. I wondered what might be happening inside, and if perhaps a new guest might arrive who could one day replace Daisy in Gatsby's long-held devotion.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
We were at a particularly tipsy table, the kind where laughter bubbled up like champagne and the clinking of glasses was a constant melody. The night was young, and the air was thick with the scent of jasmine and the promise of something extraordinary. Gatsby's mansion was alive with the hum of jazz, the flicker of candlelight, and the shimmer of silk and sequins. 

Nick Carraway, our narrator, found himself both an observer and a participant in this dazzling world. He had come to West Egg seeking a fresh start, but what he found was a labyrinth of dreams and illusions, where the past was never truly gone and the future was always just out of reach. 

At the table, the conversation flowed as freely as the liquor. Tom Buchanan, with his imposing presence and booming voice, dominated the discussion, his opinions as forceful as his physique. Daisy, radiant and ethereal, laughed with a voice that seemed to float above the rest, her charm both captivating and elusive. 

Jordan Baker, the professional golfer with a cool demeanor and a hint of cynicism, exchanged knowing glances with Nick, their shared understanding of the world's superficiality creating a subtle bond. 

Gatsby himself was a figure of mystery and magnetism. His smile was one of those rare smiles that could make you feel like you were the only person in the world. Yet, beneath the surface, there was an air of longing, a yearning for something just beyond his grasp. 

As the night deepened, the party swirled around us like a living, breathing entity. The music soared, the dancers twirled, and the stars above seemed to pulse in time with the rhythm of the revelry. But amidst the gaiety, there was an undercurrent of tension, a sense that the glittering facade was fragile and could shatter at any moment. 

Nick reflected on the nature of the American Dream, the idea that anyone could rise from humble beginnings to achieve greatness. Gatsby embodied this dream, his wealth and status a testament to his determination and ambition. Yet, Nick also saw the hollowness beneath the surface, the moral decay and emptiness that often accompanied such pursuits. 

The night wore on, and the guests began to drift away, their laughter fading into the early morning light. Gatsby stood apart, gazing out across the bay toward the green light at the end of Daisy's dock, a symbol of hope and desire. 

In that moment, Nick understood the tragedy of Gatsby's dream—a dream that was beautiful and inspiring, yet ultimately unattainable. The past could not be recaptured, and the future was uncertain. But still, Gatsby reached for it, driven by a love that transcended time and reason. 

As dawn broke, the party ended, and the mansion grew silent. Nick left the tipsy table behind, carrying with him the memories of a night that encapsulated the glittering allure and profound sadness of the Jazz Age. The Great Gatsby was a story of dreams and disillusionment, of love and loss, and of the enduring human spirit that strives for something greater, even in the face of inevitable disappointment.

events.title: Gatsby's Post-Party Despair and Obsession with Repeating the Past
detailed_summary: Nick waits for Gatsby after the party guests have left.
Gatsby finally appears, looking strained and tired.
He immediately tells Nick that Daisy disliked the party and didn't have a good time.
Nick senses Gatsby's profound depression and feelings of distance from Daisy.
Gatsby reveals his ultimate desire: for Daisy to tell Tom she never loved him.
He believes this declaration would erase the past four years, allowing them to return to Louisville and marry as if it were five years ago.
He expresses frustration that Daisy doesn't seem to understand or accept this plan.
Nick advises Gatsby not to demand too much from Daisy, stating, 'You can't repeat the past'.
Gatsby reacts with incredulous disagreement, passionately insisting that the past *can* be repeated.
He vows to 'fix everything just the way it was before'.
Gatsby talks extensively about the past, conveying his longing to recover something essential—perhaps an idealized version of himself—that became intertwined with loving Daisy.
He feels his life has been disordered since losing her and believes returning to a specific 'starting place' could clarify what was lost.
He recounts a specific memory: walking with Daisy on a moonlit autumn night five years earlier.
He describes the magical atmosphere and his perception of the sidewalk as a symbolic ladder to a higher realm attainable only alone.
He recalls the moment before kissing Daisy, realizing that doing so would forever bind his 'unutterable visions' to her 'perishable breath,' ending his purely imaginative, god-like state.
He paused, then kissed her, feeling her 'blossom' and completing the 'incarnation' of his dream.
Listening to Gatsby's intensely sentimental story, Nick feels a fleeting sense of recognition, as if recalling a lost fragment of wisdom or language.
However, the feeling remains elusive and ultimately 'uncommunicable'.

events.text_segment:
I stayed late that night. Gatsby asked me to wait until he was free, and I lingered in the garden until the inevitable swimming party had run up, chilled and exalted, from the black beach, until the lights were extinguished in the guestrooms overhead. When he came down the steps at last the tanned skin was drawn unusually tight on his face, and his eyes were bright and tired.
“She didn’t like it,” he said immediately.
“Of course she did.”
“She didn’t like it,” he insisted. “She didn’t have a good time.”
He was silent, and I guessed at his unutterable depression.
“I feel far away from her,” he said. “It’s hard to make her understand.”
“You mean about the dance?”
“The dance?” He dismissed all the dances he had given with a snap of his fingers. “Old sport, the dance is unimportant.”
He wanted nothing less of Daisy than that she should go to Tom and say: “I never loved you.” After she had obliterated four years with that sentence they could decide upon the more practical measures to be taken. One of them was that, after she was free, they were to go back to Louisville and be married from her house—just as if it were five years ago.
“And she doesn’t understand,” he said. “She used to be able to understand. We’d sit for hours—”
He broke off and began to walk up and down a desolate path of fruit rinds and discarded favours and crushed flowers.
“I wouldn’t ask too much of her,” I ventured. “You can’t repeat the past.”
“Can’t repeat the past?” he cried incredulously. “Why of course you can!”
He looked around him wildly, as if the past were lurking here in the shadow of his house, just out of reach of his hand.
“I’m going to fix everything just the way it was before,” he said, nodding determinedly. “She’ll see.”
He talked a lot about the past, and I gathered that he wanted to recover something, some idea of himself perhaps, that had gone into loving Daisy. His life had been confused and disordered since then, but if he could once return to a certain starting place and go over it all slowly, he could find out what that thing was…
… One autumn night, five years before, they had been walking down the street when the leaves were falling, and they came to a place where there were no trees and the sidewalk was white with moonlight. They stopped here and turned toward each other. Now it was a cool night with that mysterious excitement in it which comes at the two changes of the year. The quiet lights in the houses were humming out into the darkness and there was a stir and bustle among the stars. Out of the corner of his eye Gatsby saw that the blocks of the sidewalks really formed a ladder and mounted to a secret place above the trees—he could climb to it, if he climbed alone, and once there he could suck on the pap of life, gulp down the incomparable milk of wonder.
His heart beat faster as Daisy’s white face came up to his own. He knew that when he kissed this girl, and forever wed his unutterable visions to her perishable breath, his mind would never romp again like the mind of God. So he waited, listening for a moment longer to the tuning-fork that had been struck upon a star. Then he kissed her. At his lips’ touch she blossomed for him like a flower and the incarnation was complete.
Through all he said, even through his appalling sentimentality, I was reminded of something—an elusive rhythm, a fragment of lost words, that I had heard somewhere a long time ago. For a moment a phrase tried to take shape in my mouth and my lips parted like a dumb man’s, as though there was more struggling upon them than a wisp of startled air. But they made no sound, and what I had almost remembered was uncommunicable forever.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I stayed late that night, standing on the marble steps and looking at the dark water before me. The party had thinned out, and the guests had gone home, leaving Gatsby alone in the vast emptiness of his mansion. When he finally appeared, he looked strained and tired, as if the evening had taken a toll on him.

"She didn't like it," he said abruptly, his voice low and tense. "She didn't have a good time."

I could see the profound depression in his eyes, the distance that had grown between him and Daisy. He seemed to carry the weight of a dream slipping away.

"I want her to tell Tom she never loved him," Gatsby confessed, his voice trembling with longing. "That would erase the past four years. We could go back to Louisville, marry as if it were five years ago."

He was frustrated that Daisy didn't seem to understand or accept this plan. I tried to caution him gently, "You can't repeat the past."

He looked at me incredulously, disbelief flashing across his face. "Can't repeat the past? Why of course you can!"

His passion was palpable as he vowed to "fix everything just the way it was before."

Gatsby spoke at length about the past, revealing his yearning to recover something essential—perhaps an idealized version of himself—that had become intertwined with loving Daisy. He felt his life had been disordered since losing her and believed that returning to a specific 'starting place' could clarify what was lost.

He recounted a memory: walking with Daisy on a moonlit autumn night five years earlier. The atmosphere was magical, and he perceived the sidewalk as a symbolic ladder to a higher realm attainable only alone.

He recalled the moment before kissing Daisy, realizing that doing so would forever bind his 'unutterable visions' to her 'perishable breath,' ending his purely imaginative, god-like state. He paused, then kissed her, feeling her 'blossom' and completing the 'incarnation' of his dream.

Listening to Gatsby's intensely sentimental story, I felt a fleeting sense of recognition, as if recalling a lost fragment of wisdom or language. Yet, the feeling remained elusive and ultimately uncommunicable.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I stayed late that night. The house was quiet, the kind of quiet that presses against your ears and makes every creak and whisper feel amplified. The moonlight filtered through the tall windows, casting long shadows across the polished floors and the faded, ornate wallpaper. I found myself wandering from room to room, each one holding its own memories and secrets.

In the library, the shelves were lined with leather-bound volumes, their spines cracked and worn from years of handling. I ran my fingers along the titles, feeling the weight of history and knowledge. It was in this room that Gatsby had often retreated, seeking solace among the pages of his favorite books. The scent of old paper and dust mingled with the faint aroma of his cologne, a reminder of his presence even in absence.

I moved to the drawing room, where the grand piano stood silent, its keys gleaming under the moonlight. I remembered the nights when music had filled this space, the melodies weaving through the air like threads of gold. Gatsby's parties had been legendary, a kaleidoscope of laughter, jazz, and champagne. Yet, beneath the glamour, there was always a sense of longing, a yearning that no amount of revelry could satisfy.

As I gazed out the window, the green light across the bay shimmered faintly, a beacon of hope and desire. It was a symbol of Gatsby's dreams, his relentless pursuit of a future that seemed just within reach yet forever elusive. The light flickered, mirroring the fragile nature of his aspirations.

I found myself drawn to the garden, where the roses bloomed under the starlit sky. The fragrance was intoxicating, a blend of sweetness and melancholy. Here, Gatsby had often stood, lost in thought, contemplating the path that had led him to this moment. The garden was a sanctuary, a place where reality and dreams intertwined.

The night deepened, and the world outside the estate seemed to fade away. In the stillness, I felt the weight of the past pressing upon me, the echoes of laughter and sorrow mingling in the air. Gatsby's story was one of hope and tragedy, a testament to the human spirit's capacity for both resilience and despair.

As dawn approached, the first light of morning painted the sky in hues of pink and gold. The house, once vibrant with life, now stood silent and somber. I knew that the days ahead would bring change, that the illusions of the past would give way to the realities of the present.

Yet, in that quiet moment, I held onto the memory of Gatsby—the man who dared to dream, who reached for the stars despite the odds. His story was a reminder that even in the face of loss, the human heart continues to hope, to strive, and to believe in the possibility of a better tomorrow.

events.title: Gatsby's Parties Cease and Staff Replaced
detailed_summary: Nick notices Gatsby's house is dark on a Saturday night, signaling the end of his extravagant parties.
Cars arriving at Gatsby's driveway turn away disappointed.
Concerned, Nick goes to Gatsby's house and encounters a rude, unfamiliar butler who confirms Gatsby isn't sick but offers no further information.
Nick learns from his housekeeper that Gatsby fired his entire staff a week prior and hired new ones, rumored not to be actual servants, who maintain secrecy and order supplies minimally.
Gatsby phones Nick the next day.
Gatsby confirms he fired his staff because he wanted people who wouldn't spread rumors, as Daisy frequently visits him in the afternoons.
Nick realizes Gatsby dismantled his entire social spectacle because Daisy disapproved.
Gatsby mentions the new staff are associates of Wolfshiem, possibly siblings who previously ran a hotel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I see.”

events.text_segment:
It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over. Only gradually did I become aware that the automobiles which turned expectantly into his drive stayed for just a minute and then drove sulkily away. Wondering if he were sick I went over to find out—an unfamiliar butler with a villainous face squinted at me suspiciously from the door.
“Is Mr. Gatsby sick?”
“Nope.” After a pause he added “sir” in a dilatory, grudging way.
“I hadn’t seen him around, and I was rather worried. Tell him Mr. Carraway came over.”
“Who?” he demanded rudely.
“Carraway.”
“Carraway. All right, I’ll tell him.”
Abruptly he slammed the door.
My Finn informed me that Gatsby had dismissed every servant in his house a week ago and replaced them with half a dozen others, who never went into West Egg village to be bribed by the tradesmen, but ordered moderate supplies over the telephone. The grocery boy reported that the kitchen looked like a pigsty, and the general opinion in the village was that the new people weren’t servants at all.
Next day Gatsby called me on the phone.
“Going away?” I inquired.
“No, old sport.”
“I hear you fired all your servants.”
“I wanted somebody who wouldn’t gossip. Daisy comes over quite often—in the afternoons.”
So the whole caravansary had fallen in like a card house at the disapproval in her eyes.
“They’re some people Wolfshiem wanted to do something for. They’re all brothers and sisters. They used to run a small hotel.”
“I see.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over.

The groups of white-washed men and girls went hurrying by, and the cars which had been turning up the drive with a flourish all afternoon now turned away, and the lights in the house failed to go on. I went over to Gatsby’s and found his new butler, a solemn-faced fellow with a mustache, who told me that Mr. Gatsby was not ill but was not receiving visitors.

I was puzzled and a little concerned. The next day, my Finnish housekeeper told me that Gatsby had fired all his servants a week ago and had hired new ones, who were not really servants but people who kept the house and took orders from him. They were very discreet and did not gossip. She said that the new staff were probably connected with Meyer Wolfsheim and that they had once run a hotel together.

The following afternoon, Gatsby called me on the telephone. He explained that he had dismissed his old servants because they were prone to gossip, and he wanted to keep his affairs private. He told me that Daisy came over in the afternoons and that he wanted everything to be quiet and orderly. I realized then that Gatsby had dismantled his entire social spectacle because Daisy disapproved of it.

It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over.

When I came back from the East last autumn I found that my house was on the sound and that Gatsby’s house was still empty. I went over to see him one Saturday afternoon, and the lights were out. A few cars turned into the drive, slowed, and then turned away disappointed.

I walked up to the door and rang the bell. A new butler, a solemn, obsequious man I had never seen before, opened it. I asked about Gatsby. He said he was not at home and that he was not ill. I asked if he was expecting to go away. The butler said he did not know and shut the door in my face.

The next day, the grocery boy told me that Gatsby had fired all his servants a week ago and had hired new ones, who did not go into the village and ordered supplies by telephone. The village people said they were not really servants but a set of brothers who had once run a hotel and were connected with Meyer Wolfsheim.

That afternoon Gatsby called me on the telephone. I asked if he was going away. He said no, but that he had fired his old servants because they were gossiping. He said Daisy came over in the afternoons and that he wanted people who would not gossip. I realized then that Gatsby had dismantled his whole social life because Daisy disapproved.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over. The front door was locked and the lawns were dark. A few cars, driven by his neighbors, crawled slowly past his place, and the occasional taxi stopped at the curb, but the lights in Gatsby’s mansion were out. The silence was unbroken except for the faint sound of a piano playing somewhere in the distance, a melancholy tune that seemed to echo the emptiness of the night.

Gatsby himself was nowhere to be seen. Rumors swirled among the townspeople—some said he had fled, others whispered of a sudden tragedy. But Nick Carraway, who had come to know Gatsby better than most, understood that the man’s dream had quietly slipped away, leaving behind only the shell of a once-glittering life.

In the days that followed, the house remained dark and deserted. The parties ceased, the guests vanished, and the neighborhood returned to its usual calm. Gatsby’s name, once spoken with awe and envy, faded into obscurity. Yet, for Nick, the memory of Gatsby’s unwavering hope and the tragic beauty of his dream lingered on, a poignant reminder of the elusive nature of the American Dream and the cost of chasing illusions.

events.title: Invitation to Lunch Amidst Oppressive Heat
detailed_summary: Gatsby calls Nick at Daisy's request, inviting him to lunch at the Buchanans' house the following day, mentioning Miss Baker will also attend.
Daisy calls Nick shortly after, expressing relief that he accepted, making Nick sense that something significant is planned, possibly the confrontation Gatsby had previously mentioned.
The next day is described as unbearably hot, the peak of summer.
Nick travels by train through the intense heat, observing the discomfort of fellow passengers, including a woman who drops her purse.
Nick retrieves the purse for the woman but feels unjustly suspected by her and others nearby.
The train conductor complains about the heat, leaving a sweaty stain on Nick's ticket.
Nick reflects on the overpowering heat, questioning the significance of romance or emotion in such extreme weather.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That anyone should care in this heat whose flushed lips he kissed, whose head made damp the pyjama pocket over his heart!

events.text_segment:
He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow? Miss Baker would be there. Half an hour later Daisy herself telephoned and seemed relieved to find that I was coming. Something was up. And yet I couldn’t believe that they would choose this occasion for a scene—especially for the rather harrowing scene that Gatsby had outlined in the garden.
The next day was broiling, almost the last, certainly the warmest, of the summer. As my train emerged from the tunnel into sunlight, only the hot whistles of the National Biscuit Company broke the simmering hush at noon. The straw seats of the car hovered on the edge of combustion; the woman next to me perspired delicately for a while into her white shirtwaist, and then, as her newspaper dampened under her fingers, lapsed despairingly into deep heat with a desolate cry. Her pocketbook slapped to the floor.
“Oh, my!” she gasped.
I picked it up with a weary bend and handed it back to her, holding it at arm’s length and by the extreme tip of the corners to indicate that I had no designs upon it—but everyone near by, including the woman, suspected me just the same.
“Hot!” said the conductor to familiar faces. “Some weather!… Hot!… Hot!… Hot!… Is it hot enough for you? Is it hot? Is it… ?”
My commutation ticket came back to me with a dark stain from his hand. That anyone should care in this heat whose flushed lips he kissed, whose head made damp the pyjama pocket over his heart!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow? Miss Baker would be there, too. I was to come alone. I was glad to do it, for I felt that I had something to tell him, something to warn him about, and yet I was not quite sure what it was. 

Shortly after Gatsby’s call, Daisy rang me up. She sounded as if she had been crying. “I’m glad it’s you,” she said. “I was afraid you wouldn’t come.” 

I felt that there was something to be said, something to be done, and that the time had come. The next day was unbearably hot, the kind of day when the sun seems to scorch the earth and the air hangs heavy and still. 

I took the train into town, sitting in a crowded car where the heat was almost unbearable. A woman near me dropped her purse, and I picked it up for her. She looked at me suspiciously, as if I had done something wrong, and I felt the eyes of others upon me, judging me unfairly. 

The train conductor, wiping his forehead with a handkerchief, left a damp, sweaty stain on my ticket. The heat was oppressive, and I wondered what meaning romance or emotion could have in such a stifling atmosphere.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow? Miss Baker would be there, too. I was to come alone. I was glad to do it, for I felt that I had something to tell him, something to warn him about, and yet I was not quite sure what it was.

Shortly after Gatsby’s call, Daisy rang me up. She sounded as if she had been crying. “I’m glad it’s you,” she said. “I was afraid you wouldn’t come.”

The next day was broiling, almost the last, certainly the warmest, of the summer. The sun had burned away the last pale autumn leaves on the trees and the air was heavy and still. I took the train into town, sitting in a crowded car with straw seats that stuck to my skin. The heat was oppressive, and the passengers were restless and uncomfortable.

A woman near me dropped her pocketbook. I picked it up and handed it back to her. She looked at me suspiciously, as if I had done something wrong, and I felt the eyes of others upon me, judging me unfairly. Her face was flushed with heat and embarrassment, and her newspaper was damp and crumpled.

The train conductor, wiping his forehead with a handkerchief, complained about the heat and left a damp, sweaty stain on my ticket. The whistles of the National Biscuit Company blew in the distance, and the heat seemed to press down on everything.

I thought about how, in such a stifling atmosphere, romance or emotion seemed to lose their meaning, as if the heat could burn away all feeling and leave only discomfort and suspicion.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow? Miss Baker would be there, too. I was to come alone.

Almost immediately after Gatsby’s call, Daisy rang me up. She sounded as if she had been crying. “I’m glad it’s you,” she said. “I was afraid I wouldn’t come.”

The next day was broiling, almost the last, certainly the warmest, of the summer. The sun had burned away the last pale autumn leaves on the trees and the air was heavy and still.

I took the train into town. The car was crowded and stifling, the straw seats sticking to my skin. We emerged from the tunnel into the sunlight, and the heat struck us full in the face. The whistles of the National Biscuit Company broke the hush at noon.

A woman near me dropped her pocketbook. I picked it up and held it carefully, but the eyes of the other passengers were upon me suspiciously. The woman was flushed with heat, and her newspaper was damp and crumpled. She gave a little cry and fanned herself with the paper.

The conductor came through, wiping his forehead with a handkerchief. “Hot enough for you?” he said. “Hot enough for me,” he repeated, leaving a damp, sweaty stain on my ticket.

The heat was oppressive, and the passengers shifted uneasily. I thought how, in such a stifling atmosphere, romance and emotion seemed to lose their meaning.

The invitation was unexpected, yet it stirred a familiar warmth within me. Daisy’s voice, soft and inviting, lingered in my mind as I accepted. The next day, I found myself standing before the grand façade of her mansion, the sun casting a golden glow over the manicured lawns. I watched as they exchanged glances, their past entwined with the present in a delicate dance of hope and regret.

The day left me contemplative, pondering the complexities of love, ambition, and the elusive nature of the American Dream. In that moment, the world of East Egg shimmered with both promise and peril, a testament to the enduring allure of Gatsby’s dream.

events.title: Tense Arrival and Pammy's Introduction at the Buchanans'
detailed_summary: Nick and Gatsby arrive at the Buchanans' house, hearing the phone ringing inside.
The butler answers the phone with a dismissive remark about the heat before greeting them.
The butler leads them into a cool, darkened room where Daisy and Jordan are reclining languidly on a couch, complaining about the heat.
Jordan greets Nick.
Tom's voice is heard on the phone in the hall; Jordan whispers to Nick that Tom's mistress is likely the caller.
Tom's voice rises in anger as he argues about selling his car.
Tom enters the room abruptly, greeting Gatsby with veiled hostility.
Daisy asks Tom to make cold drinks.
While Tom is out of the room, Daisy impulsively kisses Gatsby, murmuring that she loves him.
Jordan reminds them of her presence, and Daisy playfully suggests Jordan kiss Nick.
Daisy's daughter, Pammy, is brought in by her nurse.
Daisy fawns over the child, showing her off to Gatsby and Nick.
Gatsby appears surprised by the child's existence, looking at her intently.
Daisy comments on Pammy resembling her rather than Tom.
Pammy is quickly led away by the nurse as Tom returns with gin rickeys.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With a reluctant backward glance the well-disciplined child held to her nurse’s hand and was pulled out the door, just as Tom came back, preceding four gin rickeys that clicked full of ice.

events.text_segment:
… Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door.
“The master’s body?” roared the butler into the mouthpiece. “I’m sorry, madame, but we can’t furnish it—it’s far too hot to touch this noon!”
What he really said was: “Yes… Yes… I’ll see.”
He set down the receiver and came toward us, glistening slightly, to take our stiff straw hats.
“Madame expects you in the salon!” he cried, needlessly indicating the direction. In this heat every extra gesture was an affront to the common store of life.
The room, shadowed well with awnings, was dark and cool. Daisy and Jordan lay upon an enormous couch, like silver idols weighing down their own white dresses against the singing breeze of the fans.
“We can’t move,” they said together.
Jordan’s fingers, powdered white over their tan, rested for a moment in mine.
“And Mr. Thomas Buchanan, the athlete?” I inquired.
Simultaneously I heard his voice, gruff, muffled, husky, at the hall telephone.
Gatsby stood in the centre of the crimson carpet and gazed around with fascinated eyes. Daisy watched him and laughed, her sweet, exciting laugh; a tiny gust of powder rose from her bosom into the air.
“The rumour is,” whispered Jordan, “that that’s Tom’s girl on the telephone.”
We were silent. The voice in the hall rose high with annoyance: “Very well, then, I won’t sell you the car at all… I’m under no obligations to you at all… and as for your bothering me about it at lunch time, I won’t stand that at all!”
“Holding down the receiver,” said Daisy cynically.
“No, he’s not,” I assured her. “It’s a bona-fide deal. I happen to know about it.”
Tom flung open the door, blocked out its space for a moment with his thick body, and hurried into the room.
“Mr. Gatsby!” He put out his broad, flat hand with well-concealed dislike. “I’m glad to see you, sir… Nick…”
“Make us a cold drink,” cried Daisy.
As he left the room again she got up and went over to Gatsby and pulled his face down, kissing him on the mouth.
“You know I love you,” she murmured.
“You forget there’s a lady present,” said Jordan.
Daisy looked around doubtfully.
“You kiss Nick too.”
“What a low, vulgar girl!”
“I don’t care!” cried Daisy, and began to clog on the brick fireplace. Then she remembered the heat and sat down guiltily on the couch just as a freshly laundered nurse leading a little girl came into the room.
“Bles-sed pre-cious,” she crooned, holding out her arms. “Come to your own mother that loves you.”
The child, relinquished by the nurse, rushed across the room and rooted shyly into her mother’s dress.
“The bles-sed pre-cious! Did mother get powder on your old yellowy hair? Stand up now, and say—How-de-do.”
Gatsby and I in turn leaned down and took the small reluctant hand. Afterward he kept looking at the child with surprise. I don’t think he had ever really believed in its existence before.
“I got dressed before luncheon,” said the child, turning eagerly to Daisy.
“That’s because your mother wanted to show you off.” Her face bent into the single wrinkle of the small white neck. “You dream, you. You absolute little dream.”
“Yes,” admitted the child calmly. “Aunt Jordan’s got on a white dress too.”
“How do you like mother’s friends?” Daisy turned her around so that she faced Gatsby. “Do you think they’re pretty?”
“Where’s Daddy?”
“She doesn’t look like her father,” explained Daisy. “She looks like me. She’s got my hair and shape of the face.”
Daisy sat back upon the couch. The nurse took a step forward and held out her hand.
“Come, Pammy.”
“Goodbye, sweetheart!”
With a reluctant backward glance the well-disciplined child held to her nurse’s hand and was pulled out the door, just as Tom came back, preceding four gin rickeys that clicked full of ice.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door. The butler opened it with a wan smile and a nod, his face flushed from the heat. “It’s pretty hot,” he said, as if that explained everything, and led us into a cool, darkened room where Daisy and Jordan were reclining on a couch, their faces pale and their voices low with languor. Jordan glanced up and gave me a brief, polite smile. The telephone rang again in the hall, and Jordan leaned toward me and whispered, “That’s probably Tom’s girl.” From the hall came Tom’s voice, sharp and angry, arguing about selling his car. Suddenly he appeared in the doorway, his eyes fixed on Gatsby with a veiled hostility. Daisy called out to him to bring some cold drinks, and as he left the room, she turned to Gatsby and impulsively kissed him, murmuring, “I love you now — isn’t that enough?” Jordan cleared her throat, reminding us of her presence, and Daisy laughed, suggesting that Jordan should kiss me. Then the nurse entered, carrying Pammy, Daisy’s little daughter. Daisy’s face lit up as she took the child, showing her off to Gatsby and me. Jordan leaned toward me and whispered, “That’s probably his girl on the phone.” We all fell silent, listening. Daisy said cynically, “He’s got a woman in New York.” I tried to reassure her, but the tension lingered. Suddenly Tom appeared in the doorway, his eyes fixed on Gatsby with a veiled hostility. Daisy called out to him to bring some cold drinks. LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door. The afternoon sun filtered through the tall windows, casting long shadows across the polished floor. Gatsby stood with an air of restless anticipation, his eyes fixed on the distant horizon beyond the manicured lawns. I could sense the tension in the room, a palpable energy that seemed to vibrate in the very air we breathed.

The telephone rang again, sharp and insistent, breaking the fragile silence. Tom Buchanan answered it with a curt nod, his voice low and clipped as he spoke. The conversation was brief, but the expression on his face darkened with each passing moment. He hung up and turned to us, his gaze piercing and unyielding.

"We need to talk," he said, his tone brooking no argument. "There are things you don’t understand, Gatsby. Things about Daisy and me, about the past and what it means for the future."

Gatsby’s jaw tightened, but he said nothing. I could see the conflict raging behind his eyes, the struggle between hope and reality. Daisy, standing nearby, looked pale and fragile, as if the weight of the moment threatened to crush her.

We moved into the drawing room, the heavy curtains drawn to keep out the afternoon glare. The room was filled with the scent of fresh flowers and the faint trace of expensive cologne. Tom paced back and forth, his hands clenched into fists.

"You think you can just walk back into her life," he said, his voice rising. "But you don’t know what you’re dealing with. Daisy is my wife, and I won’t let you take her away from me."

Gatsby stepped forward, his eyes blazing with determination. "I love her," he said simply. "I’ve loved her for years. I want to make her happy."

Daisy looked between them, her eyes wide with fear and confusion. "Please," she whispered. "Stop this. I don’t want to hurt anyone."

The room fell into a heavy silence, broken only by the ticking of the grandfather clock in the corner. I felt as though we were all caught in a web of secrets and lies, each of us struggling to find a way out.

Suddenly, the front door burst open, and Jordan Baker entered, her face flushed and breathless. "There’s been an accident," she said urgently. "You need to come quickly."

We followed her outside, the cool evening air a sharp contrast to the stifling atmosphere inside. The street was crowded with people, their faces etched with worry and fear. A car was parked at the curb, its headlights casting long beams of light into the darkness.

Tom pushed his way through the crowd, his expression grim. "It’s Myrtle," he said. "She’s been hit by a car."

Gatsby’s face went pale, and Daisy clutched my arm tightly. The world seemed to tilt on its axis, the fragile balance of our lives shattered in an instant.

As the night wore on, the truth began to unravel, revealing the tangled web of love, betrayal, and tragedy that bound us all together. In the end, it was not the grand parties or the glittering wealth that defined us, but the choices we made and the consequences we could not escape.

Tom makes small talk about the weather and shows Gatsby the estate.
Gatsby points out his own house across the bay.
They have lunch in a darkened dining room, the mood strained despite attempts at gaiety.
Daisy despairs about the heat and the future, impulsively suggesting they all go to town.
While Tom talks to Gatsby about converting a garage, Daisy pointedly tells Gatsby he looks cool.

Tom, visibly shocked and angered by the intimacy he witnessed, abruptly agrees to go to town.

events.text_segment:
Gatsby took up his drink.
“They certainly look cool,” he said, with visible tension.
We drank in long, greedy swallows.
“I read somewhere that the sun’s getting hotter every year,” said Tom genially. “It seems that pretty soon the earth’s going to fall into the sun—or wait a minute—it’s just the opposite—the sun’s getting colder every year.
“Come outside,” he suggested to Gatsby, “I’d like you to have a look at the place.”
I went with them out to the veranda. On the green Sound, stagnant in the heat, one small sail crawled slowly toward the fresher sea. Gatsby’s eyes followed it momentarily; he raised his hand and pointed across the bay.
“I’m right across from you.”
“So you are.”
Our eyes lifted over the rose-beds and the hot lawn and the weedy refuse of the dog-days alongshore. Slowly the white wings of the boat moved against the blue cool limit of the sky. Ahead lay the scalloped ocean and the abounding blessed isles.
“There’s sport for you,” said Tom, nodding. “I’d like to be out there with him for about an hour.”
We had luncheon in the dining-room, darkened too against the heat, and drank down nervous gaiety with the cold ale.
“What’ll we do with ourselves this afternoon?” cried Daisy, “and the day after that, and the next thirty years?”
“Don’t be morbid,” Jordan said. “Life starts all over again when it gets crisp in the fall.”
“But it’s so hot,” insisted Daisy, on the verge of tears, “and everything’s so confused. Let’s all go to town!”
Her voice struggled on through the heat, beating against it, moulding its senselessness into forms.
“I’ve heard of making a garage out of a stable,” Tom was saying to Gatsby, “but I’m the first man who ever made a stable out of a garage.”
“Who wants to go to town?” demanded Daisy insistently. Gatsby’s eyes floated toward her. “Ah,” she cried, “you look so cool.”
Their eyes met, and they stared together at each other, alone in space. With an effort she glanced down at the table.
“You always look so cool,” she repeated.
She had told him that she loved him, and Tom Buchanan saw. He was astounded. His mouth opened a little, and he looked at Gatsby, and then back at Daisy as if he had just recognized her as someone he knew a long time ago.
“You resemble the advertisement of the man,” she went on innocently. “You know the advertisement of the man—”
“All right,” broke in Tom quickly, “I’m perfectly willing to go to town. Come on—we’re all going to town.”
He got up, his eyes still flashing between Gatsby and his wife. No one moved.
“Come on!” His temper cracked a little. “What’s the matter, anyhow? If we’re going to town, let’s start.”
His hand, trembling with his effort at self-control, bore to his lips the last of his glass of ale. Daisy’s voice got us to our feet and out on to the blazing gravel drive.
“Are we just going to go?” she objected. “Like this? Aren’t we going to let anyone smoke a cigarette first?”
“Everybody smoked all through lunch.”
“Oh, let’s have fun,” she begged him. “It’s too hot to fuss.”
He didn’t answer.
“Have it your own way,” she said. “Come on, Jordan.”
They went upstairs to get ready while we three men stood there shuffling the hot pebbles with our feet. A silver curve of the moon hovered already in the western sky. Gatsby started to speak, changed his mind, but not before Tom wheeled and faced him expectantly.
“Have you got your stables here?” asked Gatsby with an effort.
“About a quarter of a mile down the road.”
“Oh.”
A pause.
“I don’t see the idea of going to town,” broke out Tom savagely. “Women get these notions in their heads—”
“Shall we take anything to drink?” called Daisy from an upper window.
“I’ll get some whisky,” answered Tom. He went inside.
Gatsby turned to me rigidly:
“I can’t say anything in his house, old sport.”
“She’s got an indiscreet voice,” I remarked. “It’s full of—” I hesitated.
“Her voice is full of money,” he said suddenly.
That was it. I’d never understood before. It was full of money—that was the inexhaustible charm that rose and fell in it, the jingle of it, the cymbals’ song of it… High in a white palace the king’s daughter, the golden girl…
Tom came out of the house wrapping a quart bottle in a towel, followed by Daisy and Jordan wearing small tight hats of metallic cloth and carrying light capes over their arms.
“Shall we all go in my car?” suggested Gatsby. He felt the hot, green leather of the seat. “I ought to have left it in the shade.”
“Is it standard shift?” demanded Tom.
“Yes.”
“Well, you take my coupé and let me drive your car to town.”

Gatsby took up his drink. He sipped it rather nervously, and then set it down. "It's really his house," he said, nodding across the bay. "I suppose the latest thing is to sit back and let Mr. Nobody from Nowhere make love to your wife. Well, if that's the idea you can count me out... Nowadays people begin by sneering at family life and family institutions, and next they'll throw everything overboard and have intermarriage between black and white. The idea is if we don't look out the white race will be—will be utterly submerged. It's all scientific stuff; it's been proved." 

Tom Buchanan eyed Gatsby suspiciously. "I suppose the latest thing is to sit back and let Mr. Nobody from Nowhere make love to your wife. Well, if that's the idea you can count me out..."

They went inside to the darkened dining room. The windows were open and the curtains fluttered in the warm breeze. The mood was strained, despite the attempts at gaiety. Daisy looked at the ceiling, then at the windows, then at the floor. "It's so hot," she said. "I just don't know what to do."

"Let's go to town," she said impulsively. "Let's all go to town."

Tom turned to Gatsby. "I was just talking to Mr. Gatsby about the garage."

Daisy, with a sudden smile, said to Gatsby, "You look cool."

Their eyes met, and for a moment there was an intense, exclusive gaze between Daisy and Gatsby. Tom noticed it, his face tightening.

"Well," Tom said abruptly, "let's go to town."

His agitation grew as he tried to hurry everyone along. Daisy resisted, asking for time to have a cigarette, but Tom insisted.

Gatsby took up his drink. He had been standing there for a moment, his eyes fixed on the green light across the bay, the symbol of his unattainable dreams and the past he longed to reclaim. The room around him buzzed with the laughter and chatter of the party guests, but he seemed detached, lost in his own thoughts. Nick Carraway, observing from a distance, noticed the subtle tension in Gatsby's posture, the way his smile didn't quite reach his eyes.

The evening had unfolded with the usual extravagance—music, dancing, and the clinking of glasses—but beneath the surface, a quiet desperation lingered. Gatsby's wealth and charm had drawn a crowd, yet he remained an enigma, a man chasing a dream that seemed just out of reach. As the night deepened, the guests began to drift away, leaving Gatsby and Nick alone on the veranda, the cool night air carrying the scent of jasmine and the distant hum of the city.

"You always look so cool," Nick remarked, trying to break the silence.

Gatsby smiled faintly. "I have to. It's the only way to keep going."

They spoke of the past, of memories that shimmered like fragile glass, beautiful yet easily shattered. Gatsby's voice held a mixture of hope and melancholy as he recounted his early days, the moment he first saw Daisy, and the life he envisioned with her. Nick listened, understanding that beneath the glittering facade was a man vulnerable and profoundly human.

As dawn approached, Gatsby's gaze returned to the green light, a beacon of his dreams and the promise of a future that might never be. The party was over, the guests gone, but Gatsby remained, a solitary figure standing at the edge of the world he had built, yearning for a love that time had changed but never diminished.
