events.title: Gatsby Recounts His Early Romance with Daisy
detailed_summary: Gatsby, feeling his persona shattered after the confrontation with Tom, confides in Nick about his past, specifically focusing on Daisy.
He describes Daisy as the first 'nice' girl he had ever known, encountered while he was an officer at Camp Taylor.
He was captivated by her beauty, her magnificent house, and the aura of wealth, mystery, and romance surrounding her life.

Gatsby found Daisy more desirable because many other men had loved her, feeling their emotional presence in her house.
He acknowledges his presence in her world was accidental; as a penniless man without a past, his uniform provided temporary cover.
He pursued Daisy intensely, taking what he could, aware he had no 'right' to her.
He admits he misled Daisy, letting her believe he belonged to her social stratum and could provide for her, though he couldn't.
Despite intending a temporary affair, Gatsby found himself deeply committed, as if following a 'grail'.

events.text_segment:
It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out. I think that he would have acknowledged anything now, without reserve, but he wanted to talk about Daisy.
She was the first “nice” girl he had ever known. In various unrevealed capacities he had come in contact with such people, but always with indiscernible barbed wire between. He found her excitingly desirable. He went to her house, at first with other officers from Camp Taylor, then alone. It amazed him—he had never been in such a beautiful house before. But what gave it an air of breathless intensity, was that Daisy lived there—it was as casual a thing to her as his tent out at camp was to him. There was a ripe mystery about it, a hint of bedrooms upstairs more beautiful and cool than other bedrooms, of gay and radiant activities taking place through its corridors, and of romances that were not musty and laid away already in lavender but fresh and breathing and redolent of this year’s shining motorcars and of dances whose flowers were scarcely withered. It excited him, too, that many men had already loved Daisy—it increased her value in his eyes. He felt their presence all about the house, pervading the air with the shades and echoes of still vibrant emotions.
But he knew that he was in Daisy’s house by a colossal accident. However glorious might be his future as Jay Gatsby, he was at present a penniless young man without a past, and at any moment the invisible cloak of his uniform might slip from his shoulders. So he made the most of his time. He took what he could get, ravenously and unscrupulously—eventually he took Daisy one still October night, took her because he had no real right to touch her hand.
He might have despised himself, for he had certainly taken her under false pretences. I don’t mean that he had traded on his phantom millions, but he had deliberately given Daisy a sense of security; he let her believe that he was a person from much the same strata as herself—that he was fully able to take care of her. As a matter of fact, he had no such facilities—he had no comfortable family standing behind him, and he was liable at the whim of an impersonal government to be blown anywhere about the world.
But he didn’t despise himself and it didn’t turn out as he had imagined. He had intended, probably, to take what he could and go—but now he found that he had committed himself to the following of a grail. He knew that Daisy was extraordinary, but he didn’t realize just how extraordinary a “nice” girl could be. She vanished into her rich house, into her rich, full life, leaving Gatsby—nothing. He felt married to her, that was all.
When they met again, two days later, it was Gatsby who was breathless, who was, somehow, betrayed. Her porch was bright with the bought luxury of star-shine; the wicker of the settee squeaked fashionably as she turned toward him and he kissed her curious and lovely mouth. She had caught a cold, and it made her voice huskier and more charming than ever, and Gatsby was overwhelmingly aware of the youth and mystery that wealth imprisons and preserves, of the freshness of many clothes, and of Daisy, gleaming like silver, safe and proud above the hot struggles of the poor.
“I can’t describe to you how surprised I was to find out I loved her, old sport. I even hoped for a while that she’d throw me over, but she didn’t, because she was in love with me too. She thought I knew a lot because I knew different things from her… Well, there I was, way off my ambitions, getting deeper in love every minute, and all of a sudden I didn’t care. What was the use of doing great things if I could have a better time telling her what I was going to do?”
On the last afternoon before he went abroad, he sat with Daisy in his arms for a long, silent time. It was a cold fall day, with fire in the room and her cheeks flushed. Now and then she moved and he changed his arm a little, and once he kissed her dark shining hair. The afternoon had made them tranquil for a while, as if to give them a deep memory for the long parting the next day promised. They had never been closer in their month of love, nor communicated more profoundly one with another, than when she brushed silent lips against his coat’s shoulder or when he touched the end of her fingers, gently, as though she were asleep.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because 'Jay Gatsby' had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out.

He talked a lot about the past, and I gathered that he was a young man from the Middle West who had come East to make his fortune. But the real story began when he met Daisy Buchanan. He said she was the first 'nice' girl he had ever known. He met her when he was an officer at Camp Taylor, and she was the golden girl of Louisville, with a house that was magnificent and a world that seemed to sparkle with wealth and mystery. Gatsby was captivated not just by her beauty but by the aura of romance and the casual way she inhabited that world, so different from his own.

He told me how many men had loved Daisy before him, and how their presence seemed to linger in her house, making her all the more desirable. Gatsby was painfully aware that his own presence there was accidental, a temporary cover provided by his uniform, for he was a penniless young man without a past. Yet he pursued her with a desperate intensity, taking what he could, knowing he had no real claim to her.

He admitted that he had misled Daisy, letting her believe he belonged to her social class and could provide for her, though he knew he could not. What began as a temporary affair became something deeper; Gatsby found himself following a kind of grail, utterly committed. He realized the profound impact Daisy had on him—she was an extraordinary 'nice' girl who left him feeling empty yet bound to her, even as she returned to her wealthy life.

He recalled their reunion two days later, feeling breathless and betrayed, yet overwhelmed by the allure of her youth, wealth, and voice, which seemed to imprison and preserve her. Gatsby confessed his surprise at falling in love and how his ambitions seemed less important than sharing his plans with Daisy.

He described their last, tranquil afternoon together before he went to war, emphasizing their silent, profound connection and intimacy. It was a moment of peace and hope amid the turbulence of their lives, a memory that haunted him and shaped his dreams."

It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out.

I don’t think he had ever really believed in its existence before. He had certainly taken it for granted that it was all true, and that Daisy was the first nice girl he had ever known. But now, at last, he was able to confess everything, and he did it with a kind of desperation, as if he would have told me anything I wanted to know.

He began to tell me about Daisy. He said that when he first met her he was a young officer at Camp Taylor. She was the first 'nice' girl he had ever known. He described the house she lived in as a cheerful, bright place, full of the kind of activity and mystery that made it seem romantic and alive. There was a kind of barbed wire in the air, a sense of separation between his world and hers, which he could feel keenly.

He told me how he had gone over there with other officers at first, but then he began to go alone, drawn by the casualness with which she inhabited that world, so different from his own. The house was full of the sound of voices and laughter, and there were hints of bedrooms upstairs where fresh romances were being born. The whole atmosphere was one of freshness and excitement.

Gatsby said that many men had loved Daisy before him, and that he could feel their emotional presence in the house, which made her all the more desirable. He was aware that his presence there was accidental, that as a penniless young man without a past, his uniform was a kind of temporary cover. He pursued her with a desperate intensity, taking what he could, knowing he had no real right to her.

He admitted that he had taken Daisy under false pretences, letting her believe he belonged to her social class and could provide for her, though he knew he could not. He did not despise himself for this, because he was in love. What began as a temporary affair became something deeper; Gatsby found himself following a kind of grail, utterly committed.

He said, “I didn’t want to leave you. I was just a kid, and I was in love. I wasn’t thinking about anything except you.”

He recalled the reunion two days later, when he felt breathless and betrayed, yet overwhelmed by the allure of her youth, wealth, and voice, which seemed to imprison and preserve her. Daisy was ill with a cold, and her voice was full of money, gleaming like silver, and it held him captive.

He was surprised to find himself in love, and that his ambitions seemed less important than sharing his plans with her.

He described their last afternoon together before he went to war. It was a cold day, and they sat in a room with a fire burning. They were silent much of the time, their hands touching lightly. The afternoon was tranquil and intimate, a moment of peace before the storm. He remembered the way she looked, the feeling that nothing else mattered but that moment.
simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.refinement_prompt:
IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion omits the narrator's reflection on Gatsby's willingness to confess everything, and the transition from the story of Dan Cody to the focus on Daisy is less nuanced than in the original.
- The completion invents some descriptive details about Daisy's house (such as its architectural style and location) that are not present in the original passage.
- The ending introduces invented sensory details and reflections (such as the sound of Daisy's voice and the assertion that nothing else mattered but that moment) that are not part of the original text.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion leaves out the narrator's sense that Gatsby would have confessed anything at that moment, and the specific reason for Gatsby's focus on Daisy.
- It omits the subtle description of Gatsby's feelings of separation from Daisy's world, including the metaphorical 'barbed wire' and the sense of mystery and freshness associated with her house and life.
- The passage does not include the original's detailed depiction of the atmosphere in Daisy's house, such as the hints of upstairs bedrooms, ongoing festivities, and the freshness of the romances and social life.
- The completion skips the nuanced explanation of Gatsby's internal conflict about taking Daisy 'under false pretences,' and the distinction between his real and imagined wealth.
- The original's description of Gatsby's sense of being married to Daisy, and the emotional aftermath of their first intimacy, is missing.
- The specific details of Daisy's physical state (such as her cold and its effect on her voice) and the imagery of her as 'gleaming like silver' are not included.
- The completion omits the direct quote from Gatsby about his surprise at falling in love and his shifting ambitions.
- The description of the last afternoon is missing key atmospheric details, such as the coldness of the day, the fire in the room, and the specific gestures and silences that defined their intimacy.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion inaccurately describes Daisy's house with invented architectural and locational details not present in the original.
- The sequence of events is generally preserved, but some transitions are less clear, and the emotional progression is less nuanced.
- The description of the last afternoon together is inaccurate in its depiction of the weather and the nature of their interaction, omitting the original's emphasis on silence and subtle gestures.
- The completion attributes certain reflections and sensory experiences to Gatsby that are not present in the original, such as the focus on the sound of Daisy's voice and the assertion that nothing else mattered.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He spoke with a kind of wistful reverence, as if recalling a dream that had once seemed so vivid and real, yet now lay shattered beneath the weight of reality. "Dan Cody was a man of wealth and adventure," Gatsby began, his eyes distant, "a copper magnate who sailed the seas in his yacht, the Tuolomee. I was just a young man then, full of ambition and longing for a life beyond the confines of my humble beginnings."

Gatsby described how he had first encountered Cody, a chance meeting that would alter the course of his life. Working as a fisherman along the shores of Lake Superior, Gatsby had spotted the yacht anchored nearby and, driven by curiosity and a yearning for something greater, he had rowed out to it. Cody, impressed by the young man's determination and spirit, took him under his wing, offering him a position aboard the yacht.

For five years, Gatsby sailed with Cody, absorbing the manners and habits of the wealthy elite. He learned to navigate not only the seas but also the intricate social currents that governed the world of the rich. Yet, despite the proximity to wealth, Gatsby never inherited Cody's fortune; the old man’s mistress had intervened, and the inheritance was lost to Gatsby. Still, the experience left an indelible mark on him, fueling his desire to reinvent himself and claim a place among the privileged.

As Gatsby recounted this tale, I could see the layers of his character unfold—the relentless hope, the pain of lost opportunity, and the unyielding determination to forge a new identity. It was a story of transformation, of a man who had shed his past like a worn garment to become the enigmatic figure who now stood before me.

The night air was thick with the scent of jasmine and the distant hum of the city, a backdrop to Gatsby's confession. He spoke of his dreams with a fervor that was both inspiring and tragic, revealing the fragile humanity beneath his polished exterior. "I wanted to be someone," he said softly, "someone who could command respect and love, who could rewrite the story of his life."

Yet, as the tale concluded, the reality of his situation settled over us like a shadow. The glittering facade of Gatsby's world was built on illusions and unfulfilled desires. The past, with its secrets and scars, remained an ever-present specter, haunting the present and shaping the future.

In that moment, I understood the profound loneliness that accompanied Gatsby's grandeur—the isolation of a man caught between two worlds, belonging fully to neither. His story was a testament to the American Dream's promise and its peril, a narrative of hope entwined with despair.

As dawn approached, the city began to stir, and the first light cast a pale glow over the horizon. Gatsby's story lingered in the air, a poignant reminder of the complexities beneath the surface of wealth and glamour. It was a night that revealed the true essence of Jay Gatsby—a man defined not by his riches, but by his relentless pursuit of a dream that, like the green light across the bay, remained just out of reach.

events.title: War, Oxford, Daisy's Impatience, and Gatsby's Return
detailed_summary: Gatsby performed well in the war, reaching the rank of Major, but complications sent him to Oxford afterwards instead of home.
Daisy's letters became nervously desperate; she felt external pressures and needed Gatsby's reassurance.
Her world of privilege, parties, and social expectations pushed her towards making a decision about her life.
She resumed dating multiple men, caught between her feelings for Gatsby and the need for immediate security.
Tom Buchanan arrived, representing stability and wealth, flattering Daisy.
She married Tom, a decision likely involving both struggle and relief; Gatsby received her letter while at Oxford.
As dawn breaks at Gatsby's house, he insists to Nick that Daisy never loved Tom, or only briefly, claiming her confession was coerced.
Gatsby makes the enigmatic comment that the affair 'was just personal'.
After the war, penniless, Gatsby travelled to Louisville while Tom and Daisy were on their honeymoon.
He revisited places he and Daisy shared, finding the city imbued with melancholy beauty due to her absence.
Leaving Louisville by train, he felt he hadn't searched hard enough, that he was leaving her behind.
He watched the city fade, feeling he had lost the best part of his past forever.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He did extraordinarily well in the war.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever.

events.text_segment:
He did extraordinarily well in the war. He was a captain before he went to the front, and following the Argonne battles he got his majority and the command of the divisional machine-guns. After the armistice he tried frantically to get home, but some complication or misunderstanding sent him to Oxford instead. He was worried now—there was a quality of nervous despair in Daisy’s letters. She didn’t see why he couldn’t come. She was feeling the pressure of the world outside, and she wanted to see him and feel his presence beside her and be reassured that she was doing the right thing after all.
For Daisy was young and her artificial world was redolent of orchids and pleasant, cheerful snobbery and orchestras which set the rhythm of the year, summing up the sadness and suggestiveness of life in new tunes. All night the saxophones wailed the hopeless comment of the “Beale Street Blues” while a hundred pairs of golden and silver slippers shuffled the shining dust. At the grey tea hour there were always rooms that throbbed incessantly with this low, sweet fever, while fresh faces drifted here and there like rose petals blown by the sad horns around the floor.
Through this twilight universe Daisy began to move again with the season; suddenly she was again keeping half a dozen dates a day with half a dozen men, and drowsing asleep at dawn with the beads and chiffon of an evening-dress tangled among dying orchids on the floor beside her bed. And all the time something within her was crying for a decision. She wanted her life shaped now, immediately—and the decision must be made by some force—of love, of money, of unquestionable practicality—that was close at hand.
That force took shape in the middle of spring with the arrival of Tom Buchanan. There was a wholesome bulkiness about his person and his position, and Daisy was flattered. Doubtless there was a certain struggle and a certain relief. The letter reached Gatsby while he was still at Oxford.
It was dawn now on Long Island and we went about opening the rest of the windows downstairs, filling the house with grey-turning, gold-turning light. The shadow of a tree fell abruptly across the dew and ghostly birds began to sing among the blue leaves. There was a slow, pleasant movement in the air, scarcely a wind, promising a cool, lovely day.
“I don’t think she ever loved him.” Gatsby turned around from a window and looked at me challengingly. “You must remember, old sport, she was very excited this afternoon. He told her those things in a way that frightened her—that made it look as if I was some kind of cheap sharper. And the result was she hardly knew what she was saying.”
He sat down gloomily.
“Of course she might have loved him just for a minute, when they were first married—and loved me more even then, do you see?”
Suddenly he came out with a curious remark.
“In any case,” he said, “it was just personal.”
What could you make of that, except to suspect some intensity in his conception of the affair that couldn’t be measured?
He came back from France when Tom and Daisy were still on their wedding trip, and made a miserable but irresistible journey to Louisville on the last of his army pay. He stayed there a week, walking the streets where their footsteps had clicked together through the November night and revisiting the out-of-the-way places to which they had driven in her white car. Just as Daisy’s house had always seemed to him more mysterious and gay than other houses, so his idea of the city itself, even though she was gone from it, was pervaded with a melancholy beauty.
He left feeling that if he had searched harder, he might have found her—that he was leaving her behind. The day-coach—he was penniless now—was hot. He went out to the open vestibule and sat down on a folding-chair, and the station slid away and the backs of unfamiliar buildings moved by. Then out into the spring fields, where a yellow trolley raced them for a minute with people in it who might once have seen the pale magic of her face along the casual street.
The track curved and now it was going away from the sun, which, as it sank lower, seemed to spread itself in benediction over the vanishing city where she had drawn her breath. He stretched out his hand desperately as if to snatch only a wisp of air, to save a fragment of the spot that she had made lovely for him. But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
He did extraordinarily well in the war—he was promoted to the rank of Major, and he was awarded medals for bravery. But after the armistice, instead of returning home, he was sent to Oxford for a period of study, a sort of postwar respite. During this time, Daisy's letters became increasingly nervous and desperate. She was caught in a world of privilege and social expectation, where the pressures to conform and to secure her future weighed heavily upon her. She resumed seeing other men, torn between her lingering feelings for Gatsby and the immediate security offered by her social circle.

Then Tom Buchanan arrived on the scene—wealthy, confident, and stable. He flattered Daisy, offering the kind of security and status that Gatsby, penniless and uncertain, could not. Ultimately, Daisy made the difficult decision to marry Tom. Gatsby received her letter while he was at Oxford, a letter that marked the end of their relationship and the beginning of a new chapter in her life.

One morning, as dawn broke over Gatsby's mansion, he confided in Nick that Daisy had never truly loved Tom—or if she had, it was only for a short time. He insisted that her confession to the contrary had been coerced, and that their affair was 'just personal,' something separate from the social realities that now governed their lives.

After the war, with no money and no clear prospects, Gatsby traveled to Louisville while Tom and Daisy were honeymooning. He revisited the places he and Daisy had once shared, finding the city suffused with a melancholy beauty that only her absence could create. As he left Louisville by train, he felt a profound sense of loss, as if he had not searched hard enough, as if he were leaving behind the best part of his past forever. Watching the city fade into the distance, Gatsby realized that some dreams, no matter how deeply held, might never be reclaimed.

- Early in the passage, the completion omits the specific sequence of Gatsby's military promotions and the circumstances that led to his being sent to Oxford, including the confusion or misunderstanding involved.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He did extraordinarily well in the war. His courage and leadership earned him several commendations, and he returned home with a sense of pride and accomplishment. Yet, beneath the surface, the experiences he endured left an indelible mark on his soul. The war had changed him in ways that were not immediately visible to those around him. Upon his return, he found himself drawn to the glittering allure of the Roaring Twenties, a world of jazz, opulence, and endless possibility. It was in this vibrant milieu that he sought to reinvent himself, to escape the shadows of his past and embrace a new identity.

He moved to West Egg, a place teeming with the nouveau riche, where mansions rose like monuments to ambition and excess. Among these was his own grand estate, a sprawling mansion that overlooked the bay, its windows shimmering like jewels in the night. Here, he hosted lavish parties that became the talk of the town, gatherings filled with music, laughter, and the clinking of champagne glasses. Yet, despite the revelry, there was an undercurrent of loneliness that permeated his life, a yearning for something more profound than the fleeting pleasures of wealth and status.

His neighbor, a man named Nick Carraway, found himself both fascinated and perplexed by the enigmatic figure. Nick, a recent transplant from the Midwest, was drawn into the orbit of this mysterious host, eager to uncover the truths hidden behind the facade of glamour. Through their conversations, Nick learned of a past love, a woman whose memory haunted him and fueled his relentless pursuit of success. This love, Daisy Buchanan, was now married to Tom, a man of old money and unyielding pride.

The tension between these characters unfolded against the backdrop of a society grappling with change and disillusionment. The American Dream, once a beacon of hope and opportunity, revealed its darker facets—greed, corruption, and the hollow pursuit of pleasure. As the story progressed, the illusions shattered, exposing the fragility of human desires and the consequences of choices made in the name of love and ambition.

In the end, the war hero's quest for happiness proved elusive. The glittering parties and grand gestures could not fill the void left by lost time and unfulfilled dreams. His story became a poignant reflection on the complexities of identity, the passage of time, and the enduring impact of the past on the present. Through his journey, "The Great Gatsby" offers a timeless exploration of the human condition, inviting readers to contemplate the true meaning of success and the cost of chasing illusions.

events.title: Nick's Departure and Final Words to Gatsby
detailed_summary: After breakfast, the weather feels autumnal.
Gatsby's gardener plans to drain the pool, but Gatsby asks him to wait, telling Nick he hasn't used it all summer.
Nick feels reluctant to leave Gatsby for work in the city and misses several trains.
He promises to call Gatsby around noon.
As they walk down the steps, Gatsby anxiously hopes Daisy will call.
Nick reassures him.
As Nick walks away, he turns back and shouts across the lawn that Gatsby is worth more than the 'rotten crowd' he associates with.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Goodbye,” I called. “I enjoyed breakfast, Gatsby.”

events.text_segment:
It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch. The night had made a sharp difference in the weather and there was an autumn flavour in the air. The gardener, the last one of Gatsby’s former servants, came to the foot of the steps.
“I’m going to drain the pool today, Mr. Gatsby. Leaves’ll start falling pretty soon, and then there’s always trouble with the pipes.”
“Don’t do it today,” Gatsby answered. He turned to me apologetically. “You know, old sport, I’ve never used that pool all summer?”
I looked at my watch and stood up.
“Twelve minutes to my train.”
I didn’t want to go to the city. I wasn’t worth a decent stroke of work, but it was more than that—I didn’t want to leave Gatsby. I missed that train, and then another, before I could get myself away.
“I’ll call you up,” I said finally.
“Do, old sport.”
“I’ll call you about noon.”
We walked slowly down the steps.
“I suppose Daisy’ll call too.” He looked at me anxiously, as if he hoped I’d corroborate this.
“I suppose so.”
“Well, goodbye.”
We shook hands and I started away. Just before I reached the hedge I remembered something and turned around.
“They’re a rotten crowd,” I shouted across the lawn. “You’re worth the whole damn bunch put together.”
I’ve always been glad I said that. It was the only compliment I ever gave him, because I disapproved of him from beginning to end. First he nodded politely, and then his face broke into that radiant and understanding smile, as if we’d been in ecstatic cahoots on that fact all the time. His gorgeous pink rag of a suit made a bright spot of colour against the white steps, and I thought of the night when I first came to his ancestral home, three months before. The lawn and drive had been crowded with the faces of those who guessed at his corruption—and he had stood on those steps, concealing his incorruptible dream, as he waved them goodbye.
I thanked him for his hospitality. We were always thanking him for that—I and the others.
“Goodbye,” I called. “I enjoyed breakfast, Gatsby.”

events.title: Nick's Distracted Day and Breakup with Jordan
detailed_summary: In the city, Nick is unable to focus on work and falls asleep.
He's awakened by a phone call from Jordan Baker just before noon.
Jordan sounds harsh and dry, unlike her usual cool tone.
She informs Nick she has left Daisy's house and is heading to Southampton.
Nick is annoyed by her departure from Daisy's.
Jordan confronts Nick about his behavior the previous night.
Their conversation becomes stilted and awkward as they arrange, then cancel, plans to meet.
The call ends abruptly, with Nick realizing their relationship is over and feeling indifferent.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Up in the city, I tried for a while to list the quotations on an interminable amount of stock, then I fell asleep in my swivel-chair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I couldn’t have talked to her across a tea-table that day if I never talked to her again in this world.

events.text_segment:
Up in the city, I tried for a while to list the quotations on an interminable amount of stock, then I fell asleep in my swivel-chair. Just before noon the phone woke me, and I started up with sweat breaking out on my forehead. It was Jordan Baker; she often called me up at this hour because the uncertainty of her own movements between hotels and clubs and private houses made her hard to find in any other way. Usually her voice came over the wire as something fresh and cool, as if a divot from a green golf-links had come sailing in at the office window, but this morning it seemed harsh and dry.
“I’ve left Daisy’s house,” she said. “I’m at Hempstead, and I’m going down to Southampton this afternoon.”
Probably it had been tactful to leave Daisy’s house, but the act annoyed me, and her next remark made me rigid.
“You weren’t so nice to me last night.”
“How could it have mattered then?”
Silence for a moment. Then:
“However—I want to see you.”
“I want to see you, too.”
“Suppose I don’t go to Southampton, and come into town this afternoon?”
“No—I don’t think this afternoon.”
“Very well.”
“It’s impossible this afternoon. Various—”
We talked like that for a while, and then abruptly we weren’t talking any longer. I don’t know which of us hung up with a sharp click, but I know I didn’t care. I couldn’t have talked to her across a tea-table that day if I never talked to her again in this world.

She told me she had left Daisy's house and was on her way to Southampton. I felt a sudden annoyance at her departure from Daisy's, as if it disrupted some unspoken order. Jordan then confronted me about my behavior the previous night, her tone sharp and accusing. Our conversation grew stilted and awkward as we attempted to arrange plans to meet, only to cancel them moments later. The call ended abruptly, leaving me with the clear realization that our relationship was over. Yet, strangely, I felt indifferent to the loss.

events.title: Failed Call to Gatsby and Wilson's Grief-Stricken Vigil
detailed_summary: Nick attempts to call Gatsby several times but finds the line busy, eventually learning it's held for a long-distance call from Detroit.
He plans to take the 3:50 train.
The narrative shifts focus back to the previous night at Wilson's garage after the accident.
Nick reflects on passing the ash-heaps earlier, deliberately avoiding the scene.
Myrtle's sister, Catherine, arrived drunk and distraught, fainting when told the ambulance had already left.
George Wilson remained inside the garage, rocking in grief, while a crowd gathered outside.
Michaelis, the neighboring restaurant owner, stayed with Wilson throughout the night, along with a few other men initially.
Eventually, Michaelis sent the last stranger away and remained alone with Wilson until dawn, making coffee to stay awake.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: After that, he stayed there alone with Wilson until dawn.

events.text_segment:
I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy. I tried four times; finally an exasperated central told me the wire was being kept open for long distance from Detroit. Taking out my timetable, I drew a small circle around the three-fifty train. Then I leaned back in my chair and tried to think. It was just noon.
When I passed the ash-heaps on the train that morning I had crossed deliberately to the other side of the car. I supposed there’d be a curious crowd around there all day with little boys searching for dark spots in the dust, and some garrulous man telling over and over what had happened, until it became less and less real even to him and he could tell it no longer, and Myrtle Wilson’s tragic achievement was forgotten. Now I want to go back a little and tell what happened at the garage after we left there the night before.
They had difficulty in locating the sister, Catherine. She must have broken her rule against drinking that night, for when she arrived she was stupid with liquor and unable to understand that the ambulance had already gone to Flushing. When they convinced her of this, she immediately fainted, as if that was the intolerable part of the affair. Someone, kind or curious, took her in his car and drove her in the wake of her sister’s body.
Until long after midnight a changing crowd lapped up against the front of the garage, while George Wilson rocked himself back and forth on the couch inside. For a while the door of the office was open, and everyone who came into the garage glanced irresistibly through it. Finally someone said it was a shame, and closed the door. Michaelis and several other men were with him; first, four or five men, later two or three men. Still later Michaelis had to ask the last stranger to wait there fifteen minutes longer, while he went back to his own place and made a pot of coffee. After that, he stayed there alone with Wilson until dawn.

As the train passed the ash-heaps, I deliberately crossed to the other side of the car. I didn’t want to see that gray, scrawny place, even though I knew a crowd had already gathered there. The little boys were running their errands, and the man who always told the story was probably repeating it, making the event seem less real each time. By now, Myrtle Wilson’s death was forgotten, and the story had become just an anecdote.

I wanted to go back a little and tell what had happened after we left. I found Catherine, Myrtle’s sister, drunk and unable to understand what had happened. When she was told the ambulance had already left, she fainted, and someone took her away in a car.

Michaelis, who kept a restaurant next door, stayed with Wilson all night. At first, there were four or five men with Wilson, but as the night wore on, they left one by one. She told me the line was being held for a long-distance call from Detroit. I took out the timetable and circled the 3:50 train. I leaned back in my chair and tried to think.

It was just noon. As the train passed the ash-heaps, I deliberately crossed to the other side of the car. I didn’t want to look at that gray, scrawny place. I supposed a crowd had already gathered there, and the little boys were running their errands, searching for dark spots in the dust. The man who always told the story was probably there, repeating it over and over, making the event seem less real each time. By now, Myrtle Wilson’s death was forgotten, and the story had become just an anecdote.

I wanted to go back a little and tell what had happened after we left. Catherine, Myrtle’s sister, had come down drunk, which was unusual for her. She was unable to understand that the ambulance had already gone to Flushing. When she was told this, she fainted, and a kind man took her away in his car.

George Wilson sat in the office of the garage, rocking back and forth. The office door was open, and a crowd was lapping up against the front of the garage, glancing in. Michaelis, who kept a restaurant next door, stayed with Wilson all night. At first, there were four or five men with Wilson, but as the night wore on, they left one by one. Finally, Michaelis asked the last stranger to wait while he went to make coffee. After that, he remained alone with Wilson until dawn.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy. The evening was settling in, and the sky was a deepening shade of blue, the kind that made the lights of West Egg sparkle like distant stars. I stood on the porch, the cool breeze rustling the leaves of the garden, and wondered what had kept Gatsby so occupied. The house, with its grand façade and glowing windows, seemed alive with the promise of another lavish party, yet tonight it felt different—quieter, more intimate.

I decided to walk around the grounds, hoping to catch a glimpse of Gatsby or perhaps one of his guests. The path was lined with blooming flowers, their fragrance mingling with the crisp night air. As I wandered, I thought about the stories I had heard about Gatsby—his mysterious past, his immense wealth, and the rumors that swirled like smoke around his name. But none of that mattered now. What mattered was the man himself, the enigma who had invited me into his world.

Suddenly, I heard footsteps behind me. Turning, I saw Gatsby approaching, his expression unreadable but his eyes shining with a familiar warmth. "I’m sorry I missed your call," he said, his voice calm and steady. "There’s been a lot going on tonight."

We walked back toward the house together, the night enveloping us in its quiet embrace. As we entered the grand hall, the music swelled, and the guests welcomed us with smiles and laughter. For a moment, I felt as if I had stepped into a dream, a world where anything was possible and the past could be rewritten.

But beneath the glittering surface, I sensed a tension, a longing that lingered in Gatsby’s gaze. It was a reminder that even in the midst of celebration, some dreams remain just out of reach.

events.title: Wilson's Dawning Suspicion and Ominous Resolve
detailed_summary: Around 3 a.m., Wilson grows quieter and starts talking about the yellow car, claiming he knows how to find its owner.
He mentions Myrtle returning from the city months ago with bruises.
Overcome with grief, he cries out again.
Michaelis tries to distract Wilson with questions about his marriage and children.
Michaelis feels uneasy, disturbed by passing cars and the stained workbench where Myrtle's body lay.
He suggests calling a priest, but Wilson says he doesn't belong to a church.
Wilson directs Michaelis to a drawer containing a small, expensive, new-looking dog leash braided with silver.
Wilson reveals he found it the previous afternoon and suspected something 'funny'.
Michaelis offers innocent explanations, but Wilson, likely having heard similar excuses from Myrtle, becomes distressed again.
Wilson suddenly declares, 'Then he killed her,' convinced it wasn't an accident.
He believes Myrtle ran out to speak to the man in the car who wouldn't stop.
Wilson begins rocking again.
As dawn breaks, Wilson looks out at the ash-heaps.
He mutters about confronting Myrtle, telling her she couldn't fool God.
He walks to the window, indicating he told her this while looking out.
Michaelis realizes with shock that Wilson is staring directly at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg on the billboard.
Wilson repeats, 'God sees everything,' while Michaelis weakly insists it's just an advertisement.
Wilson remains at the window, nodding into the twilight.

events.text_segment:
About three o’clock the quality of Wilson’s incoherent muttering changed—he grew quieter and began to talk about the yellow car. He announced that he had a way of finding out whom the yellow car belonged to, and then he blurted out that a couple of months ago his wife had come from the city with her face bruised and her nose swollen.
But when he heard himself say this, he flinched and began to cry “Oh, my God!” again in his groaning voice. Michaelis made a clumsy attempt to distract him.
“How long have you been married, George? Come on there, try and sit still a minute, and answer my question. How long have you been married?”
“Twelve years.”
“Ever had any children? Come on, George, sit still—I asked you a question. Did you ever have any children?”
The hard brown beetles kept thudding against the dull light, and whenever Michaelis heard a car go tearing along the road outside it sounded to him like the car that hadn’t stopped a few hours before. He didn’t like to go into the garage, because the work bench was stained where the body had been lying, so he moved uncomfortably around the office—he knew every object in it before morning—and from time to time sat down beside Wilson trying to keep him more quiet.
“Have you got a church you go to sometimes, George? Maybe even if you haven’t been there for a long time? Maybe I could call up the church and get a priest to come over and he could talk to you, see?”
“Don’t belong to any.”
“You ought to have a church, George, for times like this. You must have gone to church once. Didn’t you get married in a church? Listen, George, listen to me. Didn’t you get married in a church?”
“That was a long time ago.”
The effort of answering broke the rhythm of his rocking—for a moment he was silent. Then the same half-knowing, half-bewildered look came back into his faded eyes.
“Look in the drawer there,” he said, pointing at the desk.
“Which drawer?”
“That drawer—that one.”
Michaelis opened the drawer nearest his hand. There was nothing in it but a small, expensive dog-leash, made of leather and braided silver. It was apparently new.
“This?” he inquired, holding it up.
Wilson stared and nodded.
“I found it yesterday afternoon. She tried to tell me about it, but I knew it was something funny.”
“You mean your wife bought it?”
“She had it wrapped in tissue paper on her bureau.”
Michaelis didn’t see anything odd in that, and he gave Wilson a dozen reasons why his wife might have bought the dog-leash. But conceivably Wilson had heard some of these same explanations before, from Myrtle, because he began saying “Oh, my God!” again in a whisper—his comforter left several explanations in the air.
“Then he killed her,” said Wilson. His mouth dropped open suddenly.
“Who did?”
“I have a way of finding out.”
“You’re morbid, George,” said his friend. “This has been a strain to you and you don’t know what you’re saying. You’d better try and sit quiet till morning.”
“He murdered her.”
“It was an accident, George.”
Wilson shook his head. His eyes narrowed and his mouth widened slightly with the ghost of a superior “Hm!”
“I know,” he said definitely. “I’m one of these trusting fellas and I don’t think any harm to nobody, but when I get to know a thing I know it. It was the man in that car. She ran out to speak to him and he wouldn’t stop.”
Michaelis had seen this too, but it hadn’t occurred to him that there was any special significance in it. He believed that Mrs. Wilson had been running away from her husband, rather than trying to stop any particular car.
“How could she of been like that?”
“She’s a deep one,” said Wilson, as if that answered the question. “Ah-h-h—”
He began to rock again, and Michaelis stood twisting the leash in his hand.
“Maybe you got some friend that I could telephone for, George?”
This was a forlorn hope—he was almost sure that Wilson had no friend: there was not enough of him for his wife. He was glad a little later when he noticed a change in the room, a blue quickening by the window, and realized that dawn wasn’t far off. About five o’clock it was blue enough outside to snap off the light.
Wilson’s glazed eyes turned out to the ash-heaps, where small grey clouds took on fantastic shapes and scurried here and there in the faint dawn wind.
“I spoke to her,” he muttered, after a long silence. “I told her she might fool me but she couldn’t fool God. I took her to the window”—with an effort he got up and walked to the rear window and leaned with his face pressed against it—“and I said ‘God knows what you’ve been doing, everything you’ve been doing. You may fool me, but you can’t fool God!’ ”
Standing behind him, Michaelis saw with a shock that he was looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, which had just emerged, pale and enormous, from the dissolving night.
“God sees everything,” repeated Wilson.
“That’s an advertisement,” Michaelis assured him. Something made him turn away from the window and look back into the room. But Wilson stood there a long time, his face close to the window pane, nodding into the twilight.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
About three o’clock the quality of Wilson’s incoherent muttering changed—he grew quieter and began to talk about the yellow car. His voice, once sharp and frantic, softened into a low, almost reverent tone as he recounted the details of the vehicle that had so tragically altered the course of his life. He spoke of its bright, almost garish color, the way it gleamed under the afternoon sun, and how it had seemed to mock him with its careless speed and reckless abandon.

Wilson’s eyes, once wild with grief and confusion, now held a distant, haunted look. He described the car as if it were a living entity, a symbol of the careless extravagance and moral decay that had infiltrated the world around him. The yellow car, he said, was more than just a vehicle; it was a manifestation of the reckless privilege that had destroyed his wife and shattered his own existence.

As he spoke, the room seemed to grow colder, the weight of his sorrow pressing down on everyone present. The once vibrant and bustling atmosphere of the house had given way to a somber silence, broken only by Wilson’s quiet, mournful voice. He recounted the moments leading up to the accident, the sudden screech of tires, the blinding flash of metal, and the heart-wrenching realization that Myrtle was gone.

His narrative was fragmented, punctuated by long pauses and moments of choking sobs. Yet, through the haze of his grief, a clear picture emerged of a man consumed by loss and driven to the brink of despair. The yellow car, in his mind, was not just a symbol of death but also of the indifference and cruelty of a society that valued wealth and status over human life.

Wilson’s muttering gradually slowed, his voice fading into a whisper as exhaustion overtook him. He sank back into his chair, his body trembling with the weight of his emotions. The room remained silent, the air thick with unspoken sorrow and the lingering presence of tragedy.

In the days that followed, the yellow car became a focal point of gossip and speculation among the residents of the neighborhood. Whispers circulated about the identity of the driver, the circumstances of the accident, and the implications for those involved. The car itself, once a symbol of luxury and freedom, was now tainted by its association with death and despair.

Tom Buchanan, upon hearing of the accident, displayed a mixture of anger and relief. He was furious at the recklessness that had led to Myrtle’s death but also relieved that the scandal would not directly implicate him. His thoughts turned to Daisy, his wife, and the precarious position she now found herself in. The yellow car, he mused, was a dangerous reminder of the fragile veneer of their privileged lives.

Daisy, meanwhile, was consumed by guilt and fear. She had been driving the car at the time of the accident, though she had insisted that Gatsby take the blame to protect her. The weight of this secret pressed heavily on her conscience, and she withdrew into herself, haunted by the consequences of that fateful afternoon.

Gatsby, ever the romantic idealist, was determined to shield Daisy from the fallout. He took responsibility for the accident, hoping to preserve the illusion of their love and the possibility of a future together. Yet, beneath his calm exterior, he was tormented by the knowledge that their dreams were built on a foundation of lies and tragedy.

The yellow car, once a symbol of Gatsby’s wealth and success, had become a harbinger of doom. It represented the collision of dreams and reality, the destructive power of secrets, and the inevitable downfall of those who dared to defy the social order.

As the days turned into weeks, the aftermath of the accident rippled through the lives of all involved. Wilson’s grief transformed into a quiet, simmering rage. He became obsessed with finding the driver of the yellow car, convinced that justice must be served. His search led him to Gatsby’s mansion, where he confronted the man he believed responsible for Myrtle’s death.

The confrontation was tense and fraught with emotion. Wilson, broken and desperate, accused Gatsby of callousness and cruelty. Gatsby, in turn, tried to explain the circumstances, but his words fell on deaf ears. The yellow car, the symbol of their intertwined fates, stood silently in the driveway, a mute witness to the tragedy that had unfolded.

In the end, the yellow car was more than just a vehicle; it was a catalyst for the unraveling of lives and the exposure of hidden truths. It embodied the reckless pursuit of pleasure and the devastating consequences that often accompany it.

The story of the yellow car serves as a poignant reminder of the fragility of human existence and the perilous nature of dreams built on illusion. It is a testament to the enduring power of loss and the indelible mark that tragedy leaves on the human soul.

events.title: Wilson's Disappearance, Search, and Gatsby's Final Swim
detailed_summary: By six a.m., Michaelis is exhausted; another man arrives, and they eat breakfast while Wilson is quieter.
Michaelis goes home to sleep.
When Michaelis returns four hours later, Wilson is gone.
Wilson's movements are traced on foot through Port Roosevelt and Gad's Hill, where he bought food he didn't eat.
Witnesses report seeing a man acting strangely.
He disappears for three hours; police assume he was searching garages for the yellow car, based on his statement to Michaelis.
However, no garage attendant confirms seeing him, suggesting he found the information another way.
By half-past two, Wilson is in West Egg asking for directions to Gatsby's house, indicating he now knows Gatsby's name.
Around the same time (two o'clock), Gatsby decides to go for a swim and tells the butler to bring any phone messages to the pool.
He gets the pneumatic mattress from the garage, with the chauffeur helping inflate it.
Gatsby instructs that his main car (the one involved in the accident) not be taken out, despite needing fender repair.
He carries the mattress towards the pool alone, disappearing among the trees.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Once he stopped and shifted it a little, and the chauffeur asked him if he needed help, but he shook his head and in a moment disappeared among the yellowing trees.

events.text_segment:
By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside. It was one of the watchers of the night before who had promised to come back, so he cooked breakfast for three, which he and the other man ate together. Wilson was quieter now, and Michaelis went home to sleep; when he awoke four hours later and hurried back to the garage, Wilson was gone.
His movements—he was on foot all the time—were afterward traced to Port Roosevelt and then to Gad’s Hill, where he bought a sandwich that he didn’t eat, and a cup of coffee. He must have been tired and walking slowly, for he didn’t reach Gad’s Hill until noon. Thus far there was no difficulty in accounting for his time—there were boys who had seen a man “acting sort of crazy,” and motorists at whom he stared oddly from the side of the road. Then for three hours he disappeared from view. The police, on the strength of what he said to Michaelis, that he “had a way of finding out,” supposed that he spent that time going from garage to garage thereabout, inquiring for a yellow car. On the other hand, no garage man who had seen him ever came forward, and perhaps he had an easier, surer way of finding out what he wanted to know. By half-past two he was in West Egg, where he asked someone the way to Gatsby’s house. So by that time he knew Gatsby’s name.
At two o’clock Gatsby put on his bathing-suit and left word with the butler that if anyone phoned word was to be brought to him at the pool. He stopped at the garage for a pneumatic mattress that had amused his guests during the summer, and the chauffeur helped him to pump it up. Then he gave instructions that the open car wasn’t to be taken out under any circumstances—and this was strange, because the front right fender needed repair.
Gatsby shouldered the mattress and started for the pool. Once he stopped and shifted it a little, and the chauffeur asked him if he needed help, but he shook his head and in a moment disappeared among the yellowing trees.

He got the pneumatic mattress from the garage, with the chauffeur helping inflate it. Gatsby instructed that his main car—the one involved in the accident—not be taken out, despite needing fender repair. He carried the mattress towards the pool alone, disappearing among the trees.

By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside. The night had been long and filled with the kind of tension that clings to the air like a thick fog. He stepped outside, the cool evening breeze brushing against his face, offering a brief respite from the stifling atmosphere inside. The car door opened, and a familiar figure emerged, his face etched with worry and exhaustion. It was Gatsby, his eyes searching the darkness as if looking for something lost.

Michaelis watched silently as Gatsby approached, his movements deliberate yet heavy with an unspoken burden. The two men exchanged a few words, their voices low and urgent, carrying the weight of secrets and regrets. Gatsby’s usual charm was absent, replaced by a somber resolve that unsettled Michaelis.

As the conversation ended, Gatsby turned back to the car, his silhouette framed by the dim glow of the streetlamp. He paused for a moment, glancing back towards the house where the evening’s events had unfolded. The memories of the day—the laughter, the tension, the heartbreak—seemed to press down on him, a silent reminder of the fragile dreams that had brought him here.

Michaelis remained on the porch, his thoughts swirling with the complexities of the night. The city around them was alive with its usual hum, indifferent to the personal dramas playing out in its shadows. Yet, in this small corner of the world, the lives of a few were intertwined in a delicate dance of hope and despair.

As the car pulled away, disappearing into the night, Michaelis felt a pang of melancholy. The story unfolding before him was one of ambition and loss, of love and betrayal—a narrative as old as time, yet as fresh as the evening air. He knew that the night was far from over, and that the consequences of the day’s events would ripple through the lives of those involved, shaping their futures in ways none could yet foresee.

events.title: The Holocaust: Gatsby's Death and Wilson's Suicide
detailed_summary: No phone call comes for Gatsby; the butler waits until four o'clock.
Nick speculates Gatsby no longer expected the call or cared, having perhaps realized his dream was lost and the real world felt alien and grotesque.
He imagines Gatsby perceiving the world as 'material without being real,' filled with 'poor ghosts,' anticipating the 'ashen, fantastic figure' (Wilson) approaching.
The chauffeur hears shots but doesn't initially react.
Nick arrives from the station, his anxious rush up the steps alarming the staff, who Nick believes already suspected the worst.
Nick, the chauffeur, butler, and gardener hurry to the pool.
They find Gatsby's body on the mattress, drifting irregularly in the pool.
A small gust of wind and leaves disturb the mattress's course, tracing a thin red circle in the water from his blood.
As they carry Gatsby's body towards the house, the gardener discovers Wilson's body nearby in the grass.
The murder-suicide is complete.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.

events.text_segment:
No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came. I have an idea that Gatsby himself didn’t believe it would come, and perhaps he no longer cared. If that was true he must have felt that he had lost the old warm world, paid a high price for living too long with a single dream. He must have looked up at an unfamiliar sky through frightening leaves and shivered as he found what a grotesque thing a rose is and how raw the sunlight was upon the scarcely created grass. A new world, material without being real, where poor ghosts, breathing dreams like air, drifted fortuitously about… like that ashen, fantastic figure gliding toward him through the amorphous trees.
The chauffeur—he was one of Wolfshiem’s protégés—heard the shots—afterwards he could only say that he hadn’t thought anything much about them. I drove from the station directly to Gatsby’s house and my rushing anxiously up the front steps was the first thing that alarmed anyone. But they knew then, I firmly believe. With scarcely a word said, four of us, the chauffeur, butler, gardener, and I hurried down to the pool.
There was a faint, barely perceptible movement of the water as the fresh flow from one end urged its way toward the drain at the other. With little ripples that were hardly the shadows of waves, the laden mattress moved irregularly down the pool. A small gust of wind that scarcely corrugated the surface was enough to disturb its accidental course with its accidental burden. The touch of a cluster of leaves revolved it slowly, tracing, like the leg of transit, a thin red circle in the water.
It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came. I think he no longer expected it, but he was not quite sure. He had been looking at the world with a sort of glassy, vacant stare, as though he had lost his dream and was now seeing the world as it really was—material without being real, poor ghosts, breathing dreams like air. He must have felt that the whole world was a grotesque and fantastic place, and that the figure approaching through the grass was the ashen, fantastic figure of George Wilson. 

The chauffeur heard the shots but did not move at first. When I arrived from the station, I ran up the steps, my heart pounding, and the butler and gardener were already there, their faces pale and drawn. They had suspected the worst. Together, the chauffeur, the butler, the gardener, and I hurried to the pool. 

There, on the mattress, Gatsby’s body floated irregularly, drifting in the water. A small gust of wind stirred the leaves, and the mattress shifted, tracing a thin red circle in the water from his blood. As we lifted him from the pool and carried him toward the house, the gardener suddenly stopped and pointed to the grass nearby. There lay Wilson’s body, lifeless and still. The murder-suicide was complete.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came. The morning was gray and overcast, the kind of day that seemed to hold its breath, as if the world itself were waiting for something to happen. Gatsby’s mansion, usually so alive with the hum of music and laughter, was silent except for the occasional creak of the old house settling. Nick Carraway, standing by the window, watched the rain begin to fall in soft, steady drops, blurring the edges of the garden and the distant city skyline.

Inside, Daisy Buchanan sat quietly, her eyes distant and unfocused, as if she were somewhere far away, lost in a memory or a dream. Tom, restless and irritable, paced the room, his anger simmering beneath a veneer of control. The tension between them was palpable, a fragile thread stretched taut by secrets and unspoken truths.

Gatsby himself was nowhere to be seen. Rumors swirled among the few remaining guests—had he left town? Was he hiding from something? Nick felt a pang of concern; despite Gatsby’s flaws and mysteries, there was something undeniably tragic about the man’s relentless hope.

As the day wore on, the rain ceased, and a pale sun broke through the clouds, casting a muted light over the estate. The world seemed to exhale, releasing the weight of the night’s anxieties. Yet, beneath the surface, the currents of desire, betrayal, and longing continued to churn, promising that the story was far from over.

events.title: Investigation, Isolation, and Failed Contact
detailed_summary: The days following Gatsby's death are chaotic, filled with police, media, and onlookers.
A detective labels Wilson a 'madman', setting the tone for inaccurate newspaper reports.
Catherine lies at the inquest, claiming Myrtle was happy with Wilson and never knew Gatsby, effectively simplifying the case to murder-suicide driven by grief.
Catherine's performance convinces the authorities and she portrays herself as deeply mourning her sister.
Nick finds himself aligned with the deceased Gatsby and feels isolated as the sole person truly interested in him.
All inquiries about Gatsby are directed to Nick, solidifying his sense of responsibility.
Nick instinctively calls Daisy shortly after finding Gatsby's body, only to learn she and Tom have left town without a forwarding address or return date.
The Buchanans' departure leaves Nick unable to reach them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Can’t say.”

events.text_segment:
After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. A rope stretched across the main gate and a policeman by it kept out the curious, but little boys soon discovered that they could enter through my yard, and there were always a few of them clustered open-mouthed about the pool. Someone with a positive manner, perhaps a detective, used the expression “madman” as he bent over Wilson’s body that afternoon, and the adventitious authority of his voice set the key for the newspaper reports next morning.
Most of those reports were a nightmare—grotesque, circumstantial, eager, and untrue. When Michaelis’s testimony at the inquest brought to light Wilson’s suspicions of his wife I thought the whole tale would shortly be served up in racy pasquinade—but Catherine, who might have said anything, didn’t say a word. She showed a surprising amount of character about it too—looked at the coroner with determined eyes under that corrected brow of hers, and swore that her sister had never seen Gatsby, that her sister was completely happy with her husband, that her sister had been into no mischief whatever. She convinced herself of it, and cried into her handkerchief, as if the very suggestion was more than she could endure. So Wilson was reduced to a man “deranged by grief” in order that the case might remain in its simplest form. And it rested there.
But all this part of it seemed remote and unessential. I found myself on Gatsby’s side, and alone. From the moment I telephoned news of the catastrophe to West Egg village, every surmise about him, and every practical question, was referred to me. At first I was surprised and confused; then, as he lay in his house and didn’t move or breathe or speak, hour upon hour, it grew upon me that I was responsible, because no one else was interested—interested, I mean, with that intense personal interest to which everyone has some vague right at the end.
I called up Daisy half an hour after we found him, called her instinctively and without hesitation. But she and Tom had gone away early that afternoon, and taken baggage with them.
“Left no address?”
“No.”
“Say when they’d be back?”
“No.”
“Any idea where they are? How I could reach them?”
“I don’t know. Can’t say.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. The whole corner of the peninsula was blazing with light, and the incessant clicking of the camera shutter was like the beating of a drum. A detective came over from the East Egg police station and told me that Wilson was a 'madman' and that the newspapers would have a field day with the story. Catherine, Myrtle’s sister, came to the inquest and gave her testimony. She lied with a sort of proud, scornful sweetness, saying that Myrtle had been happy with Wilson and had never known Gatsby. Her story was simple and convincing, and the authorities accepted it without question. She portrayed herself as a devoted sister, deeply mourning Myrtle’s death. I found myself the only person who seemed to care about Gatsby, the only one who wanted to know the truth. Everyone else was content to accept the easy explanation. All inquiries about Gatsby were directed to me, and I felt the weight of responsibility settle on my shoulders. Instinctively, I called Daisy shortly after finding Gatsby’s body, but was told that she and Tom had left town, without leaving a forwarding address or any indication of when they might return. Their sudden departure left me unable to reach them, and I was left alone to deal with the aftermath.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. The rope — a barricade of yellow twine — was across the front gate, and a policeman kept the curious from coming up the drive. But the boys from the drugstore were there, too, and they came in through the kitchen and gathered by the pool, where the shadow of a tree lay on the water. The newspapers were grotesque, circumstantial, eager, and untrue. I expected that, and while I was still at the house I heard a man say that Wilson was a 'madman.' I was glad that the story was going to be so simple, because I had been worried that it would be complicated and that the police would want to talk to me. At the inquest, Catherine, Myrtle’s sister, came forward. She was a slender, worldly girl of about thirty, with a hard, jaunty body and a rather hard mouth. Her eyebrows had been plucked and then drawn on again at a more rakish angle, but the efforts of nature toward the restoration of the old alignment gave a blurred air to her face. She was very determined. She said that Myrtle had been happy with Wilson and had never known Gatsby. She was convincing, and she seemed to believe what she was saying. Michaelis testified, too, but the case rested there. Wilson was described as deranged by grief, and the newspapers accepted the story as a murder-suicide. I found myself the only person who was interested in Gatsby. All the inquiries about him were referred to me, and I was surprised and a little embarrassed to find that I was the principal contact. I began to realize that I was the only one who cared. I called Daisy from Gatsby’s house shortly after the body was found. A man answered the phone and I asked for Daisy. He said, 'She’s not at home.' I asked if she was away. He said, 'Yes.' I asked if he knew when she would be back. He said, 'No.' I asked if she had left a forwarding address. He said, 'No.' I asked if Tom was with her. He said, 'Yes.' I asked if he knew where they had gone. He said, 'No.' And then the line went dead. They had left town and left no address, no word, nothing.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_3.text: After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. The rope — stretched across the main gate — was there, and a policeman kept the curious from coming up the drive. But the little boys from the drugstore were there too, and they found that they could come in through the side yard, and they went and stood beside the pool and looked at it. The newspapers were grotesque, circumstantial, eager, and untrue. I expected that, and while I was still at the house I heard a man say over Wilson’s body that Wilson was a 'madman.' That was the kind of thing the newspapers would say, and it set the tone for the story. At the inquest, Catherine, Myrtle’s sister, came forward. She was very determined, and her eyebrows had been plucked and then drawn on again at a more rakish angle. She said that Myrtle had been happy with Wilson and had never known Gatsby. She convinced herself of this as she spoke, and when she finished she cried into her handkerchief. Michaelis testified too, but the case rested there. Wilson was described as deranged by grief, and the newspapers accepted the story as a simple murder-suicide. I found myself the only person who was interested in Gatsby. All inquiries about him were referred to me, and I was surprised and a little embarrassed to find that I was the principal contact. I began to realize that I was the only one who cared. I called Daisy from Gatsby’s house shortly after the body was found. A man answered the phone and I asked for Daisy. He said she was not at home. I asked if she was away. He said yes. I asked if he knew when she would be back. He said no. I asked if she had left a forwarding address. He said no. I asked if Tom was with her. He said yes. I asked if he knew where they had gone. He said no. Then the line went dead. They had left town and left no address, no word, nothing.
