LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. The whole town was there, clamoring for a glimpse of the man who had thrown such a lavish party and met such a tragic end. But Gatsby’s house, once so full of life and laughter, now stood silent and somber, a stark contrast to the vibrant gatherings it had hosted. The servants had disappeared, and the gardens were overgrown, the fountains dry and cracked. Nick found himself wandering through the empty rooms, feeling the weight of the emptiness that had settled over the place.

He thought about Gatsby’s life, the mystery that had surrounded him, and the dreams he had chased so relentlessly. Despite the rumors and the gossip, Nick knew there was something genuine about Gatsby’s hope, his belief in the green light and the future that might have been. It was a hope that had ultimately led to his downfall, but also one that made him a tragic figure, caught between reality and illusion.

As the days passed, the visitors dwindled, and the house grew quieter still. Nick tried to arrange a funeral, but few people came forward to claim Gatsby’s body or pay their respects. The only ones who remained were Nick, Gatsby’s father, and a few loyal friends. The emptiness of the mansion mirrored the emptiness in Nick’s heart as he realized how fleeting and fragile the American Dream could be.

In the end, Gatsby’s story was a cautionary tale about the pursuit of wealth and status, and the cost of living in a world of illusions. Nick left West Egg with a heavy heart, carrying with him the memories of a man who had dared to dream, and the lessons learned from a summer that had changed everything.

events.title: Seeking Support and Facing Indifference
detailed_summary: Nick feels a strong urge to find someone to support Gatsby, even in death, imagining reassuring Gatsby himself.
He tries to contact Meyer Wolfshiem, obtaining his office number after finding he's unlisted, but gets no answer after hours.
Nick feels haunted by Gatsby's imagined plea for help and companionship.
He searches Gatsby's desk for contact information for his parents but finds only Dan Cody's picture.
The next morning, Nick sends the butler to New York with a letter urging Wolfshiem to come.
Neither Wolfshiem nor Daisy contacts Nick as he expected; only more officials arrive.
The butler returns with Wolfshiem's written reply expressing shock but stating he's too busy with important business to get involved.
Wolfshiem asks to be kept informed about the funeral via letter through 'Edgar' and claims ignorance of Gatsby's family.
Nick feels defiant solidarity with Gatsby against the indifferent world.
An unexpected long-distance call comes through, initially thought to be Daisy, but it's a man named Slagle from Chicago.
Slagle, unaware of Gatsby's death, speaks rapidly about 'Young Parke' being arrested in a bond scheme.
Nick interrupts to inform Slagle that Gatsby is dead, leading to silence and an abrupt disconnection.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I wanted to get somebody for him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation… then a quick squawk as the connection was broken.

events.text_segment:
I wanted to get somebody for him. I wanted to go into the room where he lay and reassure him: “I’ll get somebody for you, Gatsby. Don’t worry. Just trust me and I’ll get somebody for you—”
Meyer Wolfshiem’s name wasn’t in the phone book. The butler gave me his office address on Broadway, and I called Information, but by the time I had the number it was long after five, and no one answered the phone.
“Will you ring again?”
“I’ve rung three times.”
“It’s very important.”
“Sorry. I’m afraid no one’s there.”
I went back to the drawing-room and thought for an instant that they were chance visitors, all these official people who suddenly filled it. But, though they drew back the sheet and looked at Gatsby with shocked eyes, his protest continued in my brain:
“Look here, old sport, you’ve got to get somebody for me. You’ve got to try hard. I can’t go through this alone.”
Someone started to ask me questions, but I broke away and going upstairs looked hastily through the unlocked parts of his desk—he’d never told me definitely that his parents were dead. But there was nothing—only the picture of Dan Cody, a token of forgotten violence, staring down from the wall.
Next morning I sent the butler to New York with a letter to Wolfshiem, which asked for information and urged him to come out on the next train. That request seemed superfluous when I wrote it. I was sure he’d start when he saw the newspapers, just as I was sure there’d be a wire from Daisy before noon—but neither a wire nor Mr. Wolfshiem arrived; no one arrived except more police and photographers and newspaper men. When the butler brought back Wolfshiem’s answer I began to have a feeling of defiance, of scornful solidarity between Gatsby and me against them all.
Dear Mr. Carraway. This has been one of the most terrible shocks of my life to me I hardly can believe it that it is true at all. Such a mad act as that man did should make us all think. I cannot come down now as I am tied up in some very important business and cannot get mixed up in this thing now. If there is anything I can do a little later let me know in a letter by Edgar. I hardly know where I am when I hear about a thing like this and am completely knocked down and out.
Yours truly
Meyer Wolfshiem
and then hasty addenda beneath:
Let me know about the funeral etc do not know his family at all.
When the phone rang that afternoon and Long Distance said Chicago was calling I thought this would be Daisy at last. But the connection came through as a man’s voice, very thin and far away.
“This is Slagle speaking…”
“Yes?” The name was unfamiliar.
“Hell of a note, isn’t it? Get my wire?”
“There haven’t been any wires.”
“Young Parke’s in trouble,” he said rapidly. “They picked him up when he handed the bonds over the counter. They got a circular from New York giving ’em the numbers just five minutes before. What d’you know about that, hey? You never can tell in these hick towns—”
“Hello!” I interrupted breathlessly. “Look here—this isn’t Mr. Gatsby. Mr. Gatsby’s dead.”
There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation… then a quick squawk as the connection was broken.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I wanted to get somebody for him. I wanted to go into the room where he lay and reassure him, tell him over and over that he needn't be afraid. But he was already dead, and the room was empty except for the faint smell of his cologne and the soft ticking of the clock. I tried to find Meyer Wolfshiem, but his number was unlisted. After some searching, I got the office number and called repeatedly, but no one answered. I felt as if Gatsby himself were pleading with me to find someone, anyone, to stand by him now that he was gone.

I went through Gatsby's desk, hoping to find some clue to his family or friends, but all I found was a faded photograph of Dan Cody. The next morning, I sent the butler to New York with a letter urging Wolfshiem to come. But neither Wolfshiem nor Daisy reached out. Instead, more officials arrived, their faces impersonal and their questions cold.

The butler returned with a note from Wolfshiem, expressing shock at Gatsby's death but explaining that he was too busy with important business to get involved. He asked me to keep him informed about the funeral through a man named Edgar, whom he trusted. Wolfshiem claimed ignorance of Gatsby's family and seemed unwilling to step forward.

I felt a fierce loyalty to Gatsby, a defiant stand against the indifference of the world. Then, unexpectedly, the phone rang. I thought it might be Daisy, but it was a man named Slagle from Chicago. He spoke rapidly about a 'Young Parke' being arrested in a bond scheme, unaware that Gatsby was dead. When I told him the news, there was a stunned silence before the line went dead.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
I wanted to get somebody for him. I wanted to go into the room where he lay and reassure him, tell him over and over that he needn't be afraid. But I couldn't find a single person to come. I tried to get Meyer Wolfshiem's number. It was unlisted, but after some effort, I got it from the Information. I called his office repeatedly, but no one answered. I could almost hear Gatsby's voice in my head, saying, "Can't you get somebody for me?" I felt as if he were asking me to find someone, anyone, to stand by him now that he was gone.

I went back to the drawing-room and sat down. Presently the butler came in and said, "Mr. Wolfshiem's office is closed."

"Did you leave a message?"

"Yes, sir."

"Did you say I was here?"

"Yes, sir."

I sat there, feeling the silence of the house, broken only by the ticking of the clock. Then the door opened and a policeman came in, followed by a photographer and a newspaper man. They looked at me as if I were a stranger, and I felt their eyes on the empty room where Gatsby had been.

I left them and went to Gatsby's desk. I searched for some clue to his family or friends. All I found was a photograph of Dan Cody. There was no address, no name, nothing to guide me.

The next morning I sent the butler to New York with a letter urging Wolfshiem to come. I waited, expecting a telegram from Daisy before noon, but none came. Neither she nor Wolfshiem appeared. Instead, more officials arrived, their faces impersonal and their questions cold.

The butler returned with a note from Wolfshiem. It read:

"Dear Mr. Carraway:

I was shocked and grieved to hear of Mr. Gatsby's death. I regret that I cannot come to the funeral, as I am engaged in important business. Please keep me informed by letter. I know nothing of his family."

There was a hastily added postscript:

"Please send any letters to me through Edgar."

I felt a fierce loyalty to Gatsby, a defiant stand against the indifference of the world.

Then the telephone rang. I thought it might be Daisy, but it was a man named Slagle from Chicago. He spoke rapidly about a "Young Parke" being arrested in a bond scheme, unaware that Gatsby was dead. When I told him the news, there was a stunned silence before the line went dead.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I wanted to get somebody for him. But it was no use. The day was warm and bright, and the air was filled with the scent of freshly cut grass and blooming flowers. Gatsby stood by the window, his eyes fixed on the horizon, as if waiting for something—or someone—that might never come. I could see the tension in his jaw, the way his hands clenched and unclenched at his sides. It was as if the weight of the world rested solely on his shoulders.

"You don't have to do this alone," I said softly, stepping closer. "There are people who care about you, who want to help."

He turned to me, a faint smile playing on his lips, but it didn't reach his eyes. "I appreciate that, Nick. But this is something I have to face myself."

The room was silent for a moment, save for the distant hum of the city outside. I wanted to argue, to insist that he let me in, but I knew better. Gatsby was a man of pride and secrets, and no amount of persuasion would break through the walls he had built around himself.

As the afternoon wore on, the sun dipped lower in the sky, casting long shadows across the room. Gatsby moved to the piano and began to play—a haunting melody that seemed to echo the turmoil within him. I listened, entranced, as the notes filled the space between us, speaking words that neither of us dared to say aloud.

When the last chord faded, he looked at me with a vulnerability I had never seen before. "Sometimes," he whispered, "I wonder if all of this—the parties, the wealth, the dreams—if it's all just an illusion."

I nodded, understanding more than he realized. "Maybe. But illusions can be powerful. They can give us hope when we need it most."

He smiled again, this time more genuinely. "You're right, Nick. Hope is a dangerous thing, but it's also what keeps me going."

We sat in silence, the weight of unspoken words hanging heavy in the air. Outside, the city lights began to twinkle, mirroring the stars above. In that moment, I realized that Gatsby's story was not just about wealth or ambition—it was about the human desire to reach for something beyond our grasp, to believe in the possibility of a better tomorrow.

As night fell, I made a silent promise to stand by him, to be the friend he needed, even if the path ahead was uncertain. Because in the end, we all need someone to believe in us, to remind us that we're not alone in this vast, complicated world.

events.title: Arrival of Gatsby's Father
detailed_summary: On the third day, a telegram arrives from Henry C. Gatz in Minnesota, identifying himself as Gatsby's father and requesting the funeral be postponed until his arrival.
Mr. Gatz arrives, appearing elderly, helpless, and overwhelmed, inappropriately dressed in a heavy coat for the warm weather.
He is visibly emotional, his eyes tearing up, and he nervously pulls at his beard.
Nick takes him inside, offering food and drink, but Mr. Gatz is too distraught to eat or drink steadily.
He explains he learned about his son's death from the Chicago newspaper and came immediately.
Mr. Gatz refers to Wilson as a 'madman'.
Nick leads Mr. Gatz to the drawing-room where Gatsby's body lies and leaves him alone there.
After some time, Mr. Gatz emerges, his initial grief mingling with awe and pride as he takes in the grandeur of Gatsby's house.
Nick helps him upstairs to a bedroom.
Mr. Gatz confirms his name is Gatz, not Gatsby.
He dismisses Nick's suggestion of taking the body West, stating Jimmy (Gatsby) preferred the East where he achieved success.
He proudly speaks of his son's potential, believing he would have been a great man like James J. Hill and contributed significantly to the country.
Overcome with emotion and exhaustion, Mr. Gatz falls asleep almost instantly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He fumbled at the embroidered coverlet, trying to take it from the bed, and lay down stiffly—was instantly asleep.

events.text_segment:
I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota. It said only that the sender was leaving immediately and to postpone the funeral until he came.
It was Gatsby’s father, a solemn old man, very helpless and dismayed, bundled up in a long cheap ulster against the warm September day. His eyes leaked continuously with excitement, and when I took the bag and umbrella from his hands he began to pull so incessantly at his sparse grey beard that I had difficulty in getting off his coat. He was on the point of collapse, so I took him into the music-room and made him sit down while I sent for something to eat. But he wouldn’t eat, and the glass of milk spilled from his trembling hand.
“I saw it in the Chicago newspaper,” he said. “It was all in the Chicago newspaper. I started right away.”
“I didn’t know how to reach you.”
His eyes, seeing nothing, moved ceaselessly about the room.
“It was a madman,” he said. “He must have been mad.”
“Wouldn’t you like some coffee?” I urged him.
“I don’t want anything. I’m all right now, Mr.—”
“Carraway.”
“Well, I’m all right now. Where have they got Jimmy?”
I took him into the drawing-room, where his son lay, and left him there. Some little boys had come up on the steps and were looking into the hall; when I told them who had arrived, they went reluctantly away.
After a little while Mr. Gatz opened the door and came out, his mouth ajar, his face flushed slightly, his eyes leaking isolated and unpunctual tears. He had reached an age where death no longer has the quality of ghastly surprise, and when he looked around him now for the first time and saw the height and splendour of the hall and the great rooms opening out from it into other rooms, his grief began to be mixed with an awed pride. I helped him to a bedroom upstairs; while he took off his coat and vest I told him that all arrangements had been deferred until he came.
“I didn’t know what you’d want, Mr. Gatsby—”
“Gatz is my name.”
“—Mr. Gatz. I thought you might want to take the body West.”
He shook his head.
“Jimmy always liked it better down East. He rose up to his position in the East. Were you a friend of my boy’s, Mr.—?”
“We were close friends.”
“He had a big future before him, you know. He was only a young man, but he had a lot of brain power here.”
He touched his head impressively, and I nodded.
“If he’d of lived, he’d of been a great man. A man like James J. Hill. He’d of helped build up the country.”
“That’s true,” I said, uncomfortably.
He fumbled at the embroidered coverlet, trying to take it from the bed, and lay down stiffly—was instantly asleep.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota. It was a brief message asking me to wait with the body until he could get there. I was surprised to find that the man who came was a very old man, ruddy and handsome, with a smile that understood you just as far as you wanted to be understood, and then let you alone. He was obviously a person who had been through a great deal and had come a long way to see his son. He wore a heavy overcoat, which seemed out of place in the warm weather, and his eyes were red and watery. He pulled nervously at his beard and looked about the room as if he were trying to take it all in.

I took him inside and offered him food and drink, but he was too upset to eat or drink steadily. He told me he had read about his son's death in the Chicago newspaper and had come immediately. He referred to Wilson as a 'madman' and seemed bewildered by the whole situation.

I led him to the drawing-room where Gatsby's body lay, and left him alone with his son. After some time, he came out, his grief mingled with a kind of awe and pride as he looked around the grand house. I helped him upstairs to a bedroom.

He confirmed that his name was Gatz, not Gatsby, and when I suggested taking the body back West, he dismissed the idea, saying that Jimmy preferred the East where he had made his success. He spoke proudly of his son's potential, believing that he would have been a great man like James J. Hill and would have contributed significantly to the country.

Overcome with emotion and exhaustion, Mr. Gatz fell asleep almost instantly.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota. It was a brief message, but it carried the weight of a father’s concern and the quiet dignity of a man who had traveled a long way to see his son one last time. Henry C. Gatz was a small, solemn man, with a weather-beaten face and eyes that held a mixture of pride and sorrow. He arrived in New York with a slow, deliberate step, carrying a worn leather suitcase and a faded photograph of Gatsby as a young boy.

The day he came, the house was silent except for the soft ticking of the clock and the distant hum of the city. Gatsby’s friends and acquaintances had all but vanished, leaving only a few loyal souls to attend to the arrangements. Mr. Gatz’s presence was a stark reminder of the life Gatsby had left behind, a life rooted in the humble beginnings of North Dakota.

He spoke little, but when he did, his voice was steady and filled with a quiet resolve. He told stories of Gatsby’s youth, of the boy who had dreamed big and worked tirelessly to escape the confines of his small town. He showed us a copy of a schedule that Gatsby had meticulously written out, detailing his plans for self-improvement and success. It was a testament to the young man’s ambition and determination.

As we gathered around, Mr. Gatz unfolded the schedule and pointed to the neat handwriting, explaining how Gatsby had always been a planner, a man who believed in the power of hard work and perseverance. It was a poignant moment, revealing the true character behind the glamorous facade that Gatsby had so carefully constructed.

The funeral was a small affair, attended by only a handful of people. Nick Carraway, Gatsby’s loyal friend and confidant, was there, along with Mr. Gatz and a few others who had known Gatsby in his earlier days. The absence of the wealthy and influential figures who had once flocked to Gatsby’s parties was deeply felt, underscoring the loneliness that had marked the final chapter of his life.

In the days that followed, Mr. Gatz stayed on, helping to settle Gatsby’s affairs and sharing memories of his son. He spoke of Gatsby’s dreams and the man he had become, a man who had reached for the stars but was ultimately brought down by the harsh realities of the world he inhabited.

Through Mr. Gatz’s stories, we came to understand the complexity of Gatsby’s character—the blend of hope and tragedy, ambition and vulnerability. It was a reminder that beneath the glittering surface lay a deeply human story, one that resonated with the universal themes of aspiration and loss.

As Mr. Gatz prepared to leave, he expressed a quiet gratitude for the kindness shown to his son in his final days. He carried with him the memories of a son who had dared to dream, a son whose life, though brief, had left an indelible mark on those who knew him.

The telegram, the arrival of Henry C. Gatz, and the subsequent funeral marked the closing of a chapter in the story of Jay Gatsby—a story of hope, illusion, and the relentless pursuit of a dream that ultimately proved elusive. It was a somber end to a life that had captivated so many, a life that, in the end, was defined not by the glittering parties or the grand mansion, but by the quiet, enduring spirit of a man who dared to believe in the impossible.

events.title: Klipspringer's Call and Further Disillusionment
detailed_summary: That night, a nervous caller identifies himself as Klipspringer after confirming he's speaking to Nick.
Nick initially feels relieved, hoping for another attendee at Gatsby's funeral.
He informs Klipspringer about the funeral arrangements for the next day.
Klipspringer promises to tell others but sounds hesitant about attending himself.
When pressed, Klipspringer makes excuses about a prior commitment (a picnic) in Greenwich, though he says he'll 'try' to get away.
Nick reacts with disbelief ('Huh!').
Klipspringer reveals the actual reason for his call: to ask if his tennis shoes could be sent to him, as he feels 'helpless' without them.
Disgusted, Nick hangs up before Klipspringer finishes giving his address.
Nick feels ashamed on Gatsby's behalf, reflecting on another acquaintance who implied Gatsby deserved his fate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That night an obviously frightened person called up, and demanded to know who I was before he would give his name.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: However, that was my fault, for he was one of those who used to sneer most bitterly at Gatsby on the courage of Gatsby’s liquor, and I should have known better than to call him.

events.text_segment:
That night an obviously frightened person called up, and demanded to know who I was before he would give his name.
“This is Mr. Carraway,” I said.
“Oh!” He sounded relieved. “This is Klipspringer.”
I was relieved too, for that seemed to promise another friend at Gatsby’s grave. I didn’t want it to be in the papers and draw a sightseeing crowd, so I’d been calling up a few people myself. They were hard to find.
“The funeral’s tomorrow,” I said. “Three o’clock, here at the house. I wish you’d tell anybody who’d be interested.”
“Oh, I will,” he broke out hastily. “Of course I’m not likely to see anybody, but if I do.”
His tone made me suspicious.
“Of course you’ll be there yourself.”
“Well, I’ll certainly try. What I called up about is—”
“Wait a minute,” I interrupted. “How about saying you’ll come?”
“Well, the fact is—the truth of the matter is that I’m staying with some people up here in Greenwich, and they rather expect me to be with them tomorrow. In fact, there’s a sort of picnic or something. Of course I’ll do my best to get away.”
I ejaculated an unrestrained “Huh!” and he must have heard me, for he went on nervously:
“What I called up about was a pair of shoes I left there. I wonder if it’d be too much trouble to have the butler send them on. You see, they’re tennis shoes, and I’m sort of helpless without them. My address is care of B. F.—”
I didn’t hear the rest of the name, because I hung up the receiver.
After that I felt a certain shame for Gatsby—one gentleman to whom I telephoned implied that he had got what he deserved. However, that was my fault, for he was one of those who used to sneer most bitterly at Gatsby on the courage of Gatsby’s liquor, and I should have known better than to call him.

"I can't — I can't get away," he said. "There's a picnic — I promised to be there." I said, "You mean you won't come?" He answered, "Well, I’ll try to get away." I said, "Huh!" Then he asked abruptly, "Say, old sport, you don't suppose they’ll send my tennis shoes to me, do you? I feel sort of — helpless without them." I was disgusted, and hung up before he could finish giving his address. I felt ashamed on Gatsby’s behalf, thinking of another acquaintance I had called, who had said Gatsby deserved his fate. I blamed myself for having called that man.

That night an obviously frightened person called up, and demanded to know who I was before he would give his name. I told him I was one of the few honest people left in the world, and that I was a friend of Gatsby's. After a moment's hesitation, he said, "This is Gatsby's house. Who is this?" I told him my name and that I was a friend of Gatsby's from the East. There was a long silence, and then he said, "All right, I'll come over." 

When he arrived, I saw that he was a small, nervous man with a pale face and restless eyes. He introduced himself as George Wilson, the owner of a garage in the valley of ashes. He looked around the room anxiously, as if expecting someone to jump out at him. 

"I want to talk to Gatsby," he said. "It's important."

I told him Gatsby was not home, but he insisted on waiting. As the minutes passed, his agitation grew. Finally, Gatsby returned, and I introduced the two men. 

Wilson looked at Gatsby with a mixture of hope and despair. "I need to ask you something," he said. "Did you know my wife?"

Gatsby nodded slowly. "Yes, I knew her."

Wilson's eyes filled with tears. "She's been gone for days. I don't know where she is."

Gatsby's face hardened. "I haven't seen her in a long time."

The tension in the room was palpable. I realized that beneath the glittering surface of Gatsby's world, there were shadows and secrets that threatened to unravel everything.

events.title: Confronting Meyer Wolfshiem
detailed_summary: On the morning of the funeral, Nick goes to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem personally.
He finds Wolfshiem's office, marked 'The Swastika Holding Company'.
Initially, it seems empty, but shouting reveals people behind a partition.
A secretary, Stella, appears and denies Wolfshiem is present, claiming he's in Chicago, despite sounds from within proving otherwise.
Nick insists on seeing Wolfshiem, mentioning Gatsby.
The mention of Gatsby changes Stella's demeanor, and she fetches Wolfshiem.
Wolfshiem greets Nick solemnly, offers a cigar, and reminisces about meeting Gatsby after the war – poor, decorated, but hungry.
He claims credit for Gatsby's success, stating 'I made him' and 'raised him up out of nothing'.
Wolfshiem explains he recognized Gatsby's potential and gentlemanly appearance, using his 'Oggsford' connection.
He boasts of their close association.
Nick asks Wolfshiem to attend the funeral as Gatsby's closest friend.
Wolfshiem expresses a desire to come but ultimately refuses, claiming he cannot get 'mixed up' in a man's death.
He contrasts this with his younger self, who would stick by friends 'to the bitter end'.
Seeing Wolfshiem's determination, Nick prepares to leave.
Wolfshiem advises Nick to show friendship to the living, not the dead, stating his rule is to 'let everything alone' after death.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “After that my own rule is to let everything alone.”

events.text_segment:
The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. The door that I pushed open, on the advice of an elevator boy, was marked “The Swastika Holding Company,” and at first there didn’t seem to be anyone inside. But when I’d shouted “hello” several times in vain, an argument broke out behind a partition, and presently a lovely Jewess appeared at an interior door and scrutinized me with black hostile eyes.
“Nobody’s in,” she said. “Mr. Wolfshiem’s gone to Chicago.”
The first part of this was obviously untrue, for someone had begun to whistle “The Rosary,” tunelessly, inside.
“Please say that Mr. Carraway wants to see him.”
“I can’t get him back from Chicago, can I?”
At this moment a voice, unmistakably Wolfshiem’s, called “Stella!” from the other side of the door.
“Leave your name on the desk,” she said quickly. “I’ll give it to him when he gets back.”
“But I know he’s there.”
She took a step toward me and began to slide her hands indignantly up and down her hips.
“You young men think you can force your way in here any time,” she scolded. “We’re getting sickantired of it. When I say he’s in Chicago, he’s in Chicago.”
I mentioned Gatsby.
“Oh-h!” She looked at me over again. “Will you just—What was your name?”
She vanished. In a moment Meyer Wolfshiem stood solemnly in the doorway, holding out both hands. He drew me into his office, remarking in a reverent voice that it was a sad time for all of us, and offered me a cigar.
“My memory goes back to when first I met him,” he said. “A young major just out of the army and covered over with medals he got in the war. He was so hard up he had to keep on wearing his uniform because he couldn’t buy some regular clothes. First time I saw him was when he came into Winebrenner’s poolroom at Forty-third Street and asked for a job. He hadn’t eat anything for a couple of days. ‘Come on have some lunch with me,’ I said. He ate more than four dollars’ worth of food in half an hour.”
“Did you start him in business?” I inquired.
“Start him! I made him.”
“Oh.”
“I raised him up out of nothing, right out of the gutter. I saw right away he was a fine-appearing, gentlemanly young man, and when he told me he was at Oggsford I knew I could use him good. I got him to join the American Legion and he used to stand high there. Right off he did some work for a client of mine up to Albany. We were so thick like that in everything”—he held up two bulbous fingers—“always together.”
I wondered if this partnership had included the World’s Series transaction in 1919.
“Now he’s dead,” I said after a moment. “You were his closest friend, so I know you’ll want to come to his funeral this afternoon.”
“I’d like to come.”
“Well, come then.”
The hair in his nostrils quivered slightly, and as he shook his head his eyes filled with tears.
“I can’t do it—I can’t get mixed up in it,” he said.
“There’s nothing to get mixed up in. It’s all over now.”
“When a man gets killed I never like to get mixed up in it in any way. I keep out. When I was a young man it was different—if a friend of mine died, no matter how, I stuck with them to the end. You may think that’s sentimental, but I mean it—to the bitter end.”
I saw that for some reason of his own he was determined not to come, so I stood up.
“Are you a college man?” he inquired suddenly.
For a moment I thought he was going to suggest a “gonnegtion,” but he only nodded and shook my hand.
“Let us learn to show our friendship for a man when he is alive and not after he is dead,” he suggested. “After that my own rule is to let everything alone.”

Then I heard a voice shouting from behind a partition, and a girl appeared, a secretary named Stella. She told me Mr. Wolfshiem was in Chicago and could not be seen. I insisted, mentioning Gatsby’s name, and at once her manner changed. She disappeared and returned with Wolfshiem himself. He greeted me gravely, offered me a cigar, and began to talk about Gatsby. He said he had known Gatsby after the war, when Gatsby was poor but decorated, and that he had "made him"—raised him up out of nothing. He contrasted this with his younger self, who would stick by friends "to the bitter end." Seeing his determination, I prepared to leave. Wolfshiem advised me to show friendship to the living, not the dead, saying his rule was to "let everything alone" after death.

I found his office in a small office building, and the door bore the legend "The Swastika Holding Company." I rang the bell and waited. The office seemed empty. I called out, but there was no answer. He greeted me gravely and offered me a cigar. He told me how he had met Gatsby after the war, when Gatsby was poor and hungry but had been decorated for valor. "I made him," he said. He contrasted this with his younger self, who would stick by friends "to the bitter end." Seeing his determination, I prepared to leave. Before I went, he asked me if I had gone to Oggsford, and when I said no, he seemed disappointed. He advised me to show friendship to the living, not the dead, saying his rule was to "let everything alone" after death.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. I found his office in a small, dimly lit building on the lower east side, a place that seemed to have been forgotten by time. The air was thick with the smell of old cigars and dust, and the faint hum of a ceiling fan was the only sound breaking the silence. Wolfshiem was seated behind a cluttered desk, his hands folded neatly in front of him, his eyes sharp and calculating as ever.

"I heard about Gatsby," I said, my voice barely above a whisper. "I’m sorry."

He nodded slowly, his expression unreadable. "Yes, it’s a damn shame. He was a good man, in his own way."

"Did you know he was dead?"

"I heard."

"Are you going to the funeral?"

Wolfshiem shook his head. "No. I have my own business to attend to. Besides, I don’t think Gatsby would have wanted a big show."

I looked at him, trying to read the man behind the cold exterior. "Do you think anyone else will come?"

He shrugged. "I don’t know. Gatsby was a mysterious man. People liked the idea of him more than the man himself."

I left his office feeling a strange mix of sadness and emptiness. The city seemed colder, more indifferent than ever. As I walked back to the train station, I thought about Gatsby’s life—the parties, the dreams, the relentless pursuit of a future that always seemed just out of reach.

Back in West Egg, the house was eerily quiet. The once vibrant mansion now stood as a hollow shell, its windows reflecting the gray sky. I wandered through the rooms, memories flooding back with every step. The laughter, the music, the endless nights filled with hope and longing.

I decided to call Nick Carraway, Gatsby’s closest friend. When he answered, his voice was heavy with grief.

"I’m coming over," I said. "We need to talk."

When I arrived, Nick was sitting on the porch, staring out at the water. "It’s hard to believe he’s gone," he said softly.

"He was a dreamer," I replied. "But sometimes dreams don’t come true."

Nick nodded. "I’m trying to make sense of it all. The parties, the people, the lies."

We sat in silence for a while, the weight of the loss pressing down on us. Then Nick spoke again.

"I think Gatsby wanted to be remembered for something more than just the parties and the wealth. He wanted to be loved, to be understood."

"Did he find that?"

Nick shook his head. "Not really. But maybe that’s the tragedy of it all."

In the days that followed, I reached out to others who had known Gatsby. Few responded. The world that had once flocked to his door now seemed eager to forget him. It was as if his life had been a fleeting illusion, a brief spark in the darkness.

I thought about Daisy Buchanan, the woman Gatsby had loved with such intensity. I wondered if she even knew about his death. I tried to contact her, but she was nowhere to be found. It was as if she had vanished, leaving behind only memories and regrets.

The funeral was a small affair, attended by only a handful of people. Nick, myself, Gatsby’s father, and a few others who had cared enough to say goodbye. The service was simple, a quiet farewell to a man who had lived a life of contradictions.

As we stood by the graveside, I couldn’t help but feel a profound sense of loss—not just for Gatsby, but for the world he had tried to create. A world where dreams could come true, where love could conquer all, and where the past could be rewritten.

But in the end, it was all just a story—a story of hope and heartbreak, of ambition and despair. And as I looked down at the freshly turned earth, I realized that Gatsby’s dream was both his greatest strength and his ultimate downfall.

The days turned into weeks, and life slowly returned to its usual rhythm. The mansion was sold, the parties ceased, and the lights went out. The world moved on, indifferent to the man who had once dared to dream.

Yet, in the quiet moments, I found myself thinking of Gatsby—the man who had reached for the stars, who had believed in the green light across the bay, and who had taught me that sometimes, the greatest stories are the ones we tell ourselves.

And so, I carry his memory with me, a reminder of the fragility of dreams and the enduring power of hope.

events.title: Mr. Gatz's Pride and Gatsby's Boyhood Ambitions
detailed_summary: Nick returns to West Egg amidst darkening skies and drizzle.
He finds Mr. Gatz pacing excitedly, his pride in Gatsby and his possessions growing.
Mr. Gatz eagerly shows Nick a worn photograph of Gatsby's house that Jimmy had sent him, pointing out details.
He recounts Gatsby visiting two years prior and buying him the house he currently lives in.
Mr. Gatz reflects that Gatsby's running away from home was justified by his ambition for a 'big future'.
He emphasizes Gatsby's generosity after achieving success.
Mr. Gatz then reveals an old, ragged copy of 'Hopalong Cassidy' belonging to Gatsby as a boy.
He shows Nick the back flyleaf containing a detailed daily schedule dated September 12, 1906.
The schedule includes time for exercise, study (electricity, elocution, inventions), work, and sports.
Beneath the schedule are 'General Resolves': avoiding wasted time, quitting smoking/chewing, bathing regularly, reading improving material, saving money, and being better to parents.
Mr. Gatz sees the book and its contents as proof of Jimmy's inherent drive to 'get ahead' and improve himself.
He proudly reads the items aloud, expecting Nick to be deeply impressed.

events.text_segment:
When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. After changing my clothes I went next door and found Mr. Gatz walking up and down excitedly in the hall. His pride in his son and in his son’s possessions was continually increasing and now he had something to show me.
“Jimmy sent me this picture.” He took out his wallet with trembling fingers. “Look there.”
It was a photograph of the house, cracked in the corners and dirty with many hands. He pointed out every detail to me eagerly. “Look there!” and then sought admiration from my eyes. He had shown it so often that I think it was more real to him now than the house itself.
“Jimmy sent it to me. I think it’s a very pretty picture. It shows up well.”
“Very well. Had you seen him lately?”
“He come out to see me two years ago and bought me the house I live in now. Of course we was broke up when he run off from home, but I see now there was a reason for it. He knew he had a big future in front of him. And ever since he made a success he was very generous with me.”
He seemed reluctant to put away the picture, held it for another minute, lingeringly, before my eyes. Then he returned the wallet and pulled from his pocket a ragged old copy of a book called Hopalong Cassidy.
“Look here, this is a book he had when he was a boy. It just shows you.”
He opened it at the back cover and turned it around for me to see. On the last flyleaf was printed the word schedule, and the date September 12, 1906. And underneath:
Rise from bed	6:00	a.m.
Dumbell exercise and wall-scaling	6:15⁠–⁠6:30	“
Study electricity, etc.	7:15⁠–⁠8:15	“
Work	8:30⁠–⁠4:30	p.m.
Baseball and sports	4:30⁠–⁠5:00	“
Practise elocution, poise and how to attain it	5:00⁠–⁠6:00	“
Study needed inventions	7:00⁠–⁠9:00	“
General Resolves
No wasting time at Shafters or [a name, indecipherable]
No more smokeing or chewing.
Bath every other day
Read one improving book or magazine per week
Save $5.00 [crossed out] $3.00 per week
Be better to parents
“I came across this book by accident,” said the old man. “It just shows you, don’t it?”
“It just shows you.”
“Jimmy was bound to get ahead. He always had some resolves like this or something. Do you notice what he’s got about improving his mind? He was always great for that. He told me I et like a hog once, and I beat him for it.”
He was reluctant to close the book, reading each item aloud and then looking eagerly at me. I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.

He had a big future before him.” I asked him about Gatsby’s running away from home, and he said, “He had to get away. He had to get ahead.” Then Mr. Gatz pulled from his pocket a small, ragged book. It was a copy of "Hopalong Cassidy," a book Gatsby had owned as a boy. He opened it to the back flyleaf and turned it around so I could see. There, in neat, boyish handwriting, was a schedule dated September 12, 1906. It was a detailed plan for the day: exercise, study of electricity, elocution, inventions, work, and sports. Beneath the schedule were “General Resolves”: “No wasting time at all,” “Don’t borrow money,” “Be better to parents,” “Read one improving book or magazine per week,” “Save a little money every day,” “Don’t smoke cigarettes or chew tobacco,” “Take a bath every other day.” Mr. Gatz read the list aloud, his voice full of pride. “That’s my son’s schedule,” he said. “He was bound to get ahead.” He looked at me expectantly. “You ought to copy it down. That’s the kind of boy he was.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. The streets were slick with rain, and the faint glow of the city lights shimmered on the wet pavement. I pulled my coat tighter around me, the chill seeping through the fabric as I made my way toward the house. The evening air was heavy with the scent of damp earth and the distant hum of traffic, a stark contrast to the opulence that awaited me at Gatsby's mansion.

As I approached the grand estate, the lights were still blazing, casting long shadows across the manicured lawns. The sound of laughter and music drifted through the air, mingling with the soft patter of raindrops. Gatsby's parties were legendary, a dazzling display of wealth and extravagance that seemed almost surreal against the backdrop of the darkening sky.

Inside, the atmosphere was electric. Guests in shimmering gowns and tailored suits moved gracefully through the rooms, their voices rising and falling in a symphony of celebration. The clink of glasses and the soft strains of a jazz band filled the air, creating a sense of timeless elegance. Yet, beneath the surface, there was an undercurrent of restlessness, a yearning that seemed to permeate the very walls.

I found Gatsby standing near the terrace, his gaze fixed on the horizon beyond the bay. There was a quiet intensity about him, a mixture of hope and melancholy that set him apart from the revelry around us. He turned as I approached, a smile playing at the corners of his mouth, but his eyes betrayed a deeper emotion.

"It's a beautiful night," he said softly, his voice tinged with something I couldn't quite place.

"Yes," I replied, "though the rain seems determined to linger."

He nodded, his expression thoughtful. "Sometimes, the rain is necessary. It washes away the past, makes way for something new."

I looked out over the water, the lights of the city reflected in the ripples. There was a sense of possibility in the air, a promise that tomorrow might bring change. Yet, I couldn't shake the feeling that beneath the glamour and the dreams, there was a fragility that threatened to unravel it all.

As the night wore on, the guests began to drift away, their laughter fading into the quiet of the early morning. Gatsby remained on the terrace, his silhouette outlined against the first light of dawn. In that moment, I understood that his dreams were as vast and elusive as the horizon itself, forever just out of reach, yet endlessly pursued.

events.title: The Sparse Funeral
detailed_summary: Shortly before 3 PM, the Lutheran minister arrives for the funeral.
Nick and Mr. Gatz anxiously watch for other mourners, but none arrive.
As time passes, Mr. Gatz becomes increasingly worried, commenting nervously about the rain.
The minister checks his watch repeatedly; Nick persuades him to wait half an hour longer, but it's futile.
Around 5 PM, a small procession of three vehicles (hearse, limousine with Nick, Gatz, and minister, and station wagon with servants and postman) reaches the cemetery in heavy drizzle.
As they enter the cemetery, Nick hears a car stop and sees someone approaching.
It is the 'owl-eyed man' Nick previously met in Gatsby's library.
Owl Eyes, soaked by the rain, wipes his glasses to watch the burial.
Nick momentarily tries to think of Gatsby but finds him distant, only recalling Daisy's silence.
Someone murmurs a blessing for the dead in the rain, and Owl Eyes says 'Amen'.
After the brief ceremony, the attendees quickly return to the cars.
Owl Eyes speaks to Nick at the gate, expressing surprise that no one else came, remarking how hundreds used to attend Gatsby's parties.
He wipes his glasses again and calls Gatsby 'The poor son-of-a-bitch'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.

events.text_segment:
A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars. So did Gatsby’s father. And as the time passed and the servants came in and stood waiting in the hall, his eyes began to blink anxiously, and he spoke of the rain in a worried, uncertain way. The minister glanced several times at his watch, so I took him aside and asked him to wait for half an hour. But it wasn’t any use. Nobody came.
About five o’clock our procession of three cars reached the cemetery and stopped in a thick drizzle beside the gate—first a motor hearse, horribly black and wet, then Mr. Gatz and the minister and me in the limousine, and a little later four or five servants and the postman from West Egg, in Gatsby’s station wagon, all wet to the skin. As we started through the gate into the cemetery I heard a car stop and then the sound of someone splashing after us over the soggy ground. I looked around. It was the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had found marvelling over Gatsby’s books in the library one night three months before.
I’d never seen him since then. I don’t know how he knew about the funeral, or even his name. The rain poured down his thick glasses, and he took them off and wiped them to see the protecting canvas unrolled from Gatsby’s grave.
I tried to think about Gatsby then for a moment, but he was already too far away, and I could only remember, without resentment, that Daisy hadn’t sent a message or a flower. Dimly I heard someone murmur “Blessed are the dead that the rain falls on,” and then the owl-eyed man said “Amen to that,” in a brave voice.
We straggled down quickly through the rain to the cars. Owl-eyes spoke to me by the gate.
“I couldn’t get to the house,” he remarked.
“Neither could anybody else.”
“Go on!” He started. “Why, my God! they used to go there by the hundreds.”
He took off his glasses and wiped them again, outside and in.
“The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.

I persuaded the minister to wait half an hour longer, but it was no use. At about five o'clock a small procession of three cars—the hearse, a limousine with the minister, Mr. Gatz, and me, and a station wagon with Gatsby's servants and the West Egg postman—drew up at the cemetery in a heavy drizzle. As we entered the cemetery, I heard a car stop behind us and saw a figure approaching through the rain. It was the owl-eyed man, his glasses fogged and dripping, who wiped them carefully and stood watching the burial. I tried to think of Gatsby, but he seemed far away, and all I could recall was Daisy's voice, silent and distant. Someone murmured a blessing for the dead in the rain, and the owl-eyed man said, "Amen." After the brief ceremony, we hurried back to the cars. At the gate, the owl-eyed man turned to me and said, "I’m surprised no one else came. Hundreds used to come to Gatsby’s parties." He wiped his glasses again and added, "The poor son-of-a-bitch."

A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars. The day was gray and overcast, the kind of day that seemed to press down on the spirit, making the air heavy and the light dim. The minister, a solemn man with a gentle demeanor, stepped inside quietly, his presence a stark contrast to the usual gaiety that filled Gatsby's mansion. The house, once alive with music and laughter, now felt eerily silent, as if mourning the loss that had just occurred.

I noticed Daisy and Tom sitting together in the drawing room, their faces pale and drawn. Daisy's eyes were red-rimmed, and she clutched a handkerchief tightly in her lap. Tom's jaw was set, his usual arrogance replaced by a brooding silence. The tension in the room was palpable, a mixture of grief, guilt, and unspoken accusations hanging in the air.

As the minister began the service, his voice steady and measured, I found my thoughts drifting back to the events that had led us here. Gatsby, with his unwavering hope and relentless pursuit of a dream, had met a tragic end. His belief in the green light, the future, and the possibility of recapturing the past had ultimately been his downfall.

Outside, the rain began to fall softly, tapping against the windows like a mournful rhythm. The guests who had once flocked to Gatsby's parties were nowhere to be seen, their absence a stark reminder of the fleeting nature of wealth and popularity. In that moment, the grandeur of Gatsby's world seemed hollow, a fragile illusion shattered by reality.

As the service concluded, I felt a profound sense of loss—not just for Gatsby, but for the innocence and idealism that he embodied. The American Dream, so dazzling and elusive, had revealed its darker side, leaving behind a trail of broken hearts and shattered illusions.

events.title: Reflections on East vs. West and Decision to Leave
detailed_summary: Nick recalls vivid memories of returning home to the Midwest from school during Christmas.
He describes the atmosphere at Chicago's Union Station, the goodbyes, and the train journey into the snowy landscape.
He reflects on the feeling of connection to his homeland experienced during those trips.
Nick defines his Midwest not by landscapes but by these youthful returns and the cozy familiarity of home.
He realizes the story he's told is fundamentally about Westerners (himself, Gatsby, Tom, Daisy, Jordan) who were ill-suited to Eastern life.
Even at its most exciting, Nick found the East possessed a 'quality of distortion'.
He envisions West Egg as a grotesque night scene, comparing it to an El Greco painting, symbolizing moral decay and indifference.
After Gatsby's death, the East feels irredeemably haunted and distorted to Nick.
As autumn sets in, he decides to leave the East and return home to the Midwest.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home.

events.text_segment:
One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. Those who went farther than Chicago would gather in the old dim Union Station at six o’clock of a December evening, with a few Chicago friends, already caught up into their own holiday gaieties, to bid them a hasty goodbye. I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from Miss This-or-That’s and the chatter of frozen breath and the hands waving overhead as we caught sight of old acquaintances, and the matchings of invitations: “Are you going to the Ordways’? the Herseys’? the Schultzes’?” and the long green tickets clasped tight in our gloved hands. And last the murky yellow cars of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul railroad looking cheerful as Christmas itself on the tracks beside the gate.
When we pulled out into the winter night and the real snow, our snow, began to stretch out beside us and twinkle against the windows, and the dim lights of small Wisconsin stations moved by, a sharp wild brace came suddenly into the air. We drew in deep breaths of it as we walked back from dinner through the cold vestibules, unutterably aware of our identity with this country for one strange hour, before we melted indistinguishably into it again.
That’s my Middle West—not the wheat or the prairies or the lost Swede towns, but the thrilling returning trains of my youth, and the street lamps and sleigh bells in the frosty dark and the shadows of holly wreaths thrown by lighted windows on the snow. I am part of that, a little solemn with the feel of those long winters, a little complacent from growing up in the Carraway house in a city where dwellings are still called through decades by a family’s name. I see now that this has been a story of the West, after all—Tom and Gatsby, Daisy and Jordan and I, were all Westerners, and perhaps we possessed some deficiency in common which made us subtly unadaptable to Eastern life.
Even when the East excited me most, even when I was most keenly aware of its superiority to the bored, sprawling, swollen towns beyond the Ohio, with their interminable inquisitions which spared only the children and the very old—even then it had always for me a quality of distortion. West Egg, especially, still figures in my more fantastic dreams. I see it as a night scene by El Greco: a hundred houses, at once conventional and grotesque, crouching under a sullen, overhanging sky and a lustreless moon. In the foreground four solemn men in dress suits are walking along the sidewalk with a stretcher on which lies a drunken woman in a white evening dress. Her hand, which dangles over the side, sparkles cold with jewels. Gravely the men turn in at a house—the wrong house. But no one knows the woman’s name, and no one cares.
After Gatsby’s death the East was haunted for me like that, distorted beyond my eyes’ power of correction. So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. The train would come into Chicago in the snow and the station would be packed with people saying goodbye to their families. I remember the warmth of the station, the smell of the coal fires, and the feeling of being connected to a place that was home. The journey from Chicago to my hometown was through a landscape of white fields and dark trees, a quiet and familiar world that felt like a refuge from the restless East. For me, the Midwest was not defined by its geography but by these moments of return, the comfort of family and the sense of belonging. Looking back, I realize that the story I have told is about Westerners—myself, Gatsby, Tom, Daisy, and Jordan—who were all, in different ways, ill-suited to the East. Even at its most dazzling, the East had a quality of distortion, a grotesque night scene like an El Greco painting, where moral decay and indifference reigned. After Gatsby's death, the East seemed irredeemably haunted, a place of shadows and lost dreams. As autumn settled in, I knew it was time to leave and return to the Midwest, to the place where I truly belonged.

The train would come into Chicago in the snow and the station would be packed with people saying goodbye to their families. I remember the hour, the cold, the smell of the station, the voices, the laughter, the tears, the clatter of the train wheels, and the feeling of being part of a larger world. Friends would come to see me off, and there was a ritual of handshakes and embraces, a mingling of excitement and sadness. The train would pull out into the night, and as we left the city behind, the landscape would open up into a vast, dark expanse, the fields and trees blurred by the snow and the speed. The journey was a passage from one world to another, from the restless East back to the quiet familiarity of the Midwest. I thought of the people I knew there, the traditions, the small-town rhythms, and the sense of belonging that was absent in the East. The story I have told is fundamentally about Westerners—myself, Gatsby, Tom, Daisy, and Jordan—who were all, in different ways, ill-suited to the East. Even at its most exciting, the East had a quality of distortion, a grotesque night scene like an El Greco painting, where the colors were unnatural and the figures twisted. I had a dream once, after Gatsby's death, of a group of men carrying a stretcher through the night, their faces obscured, moving silently across a landscape that was both familiar and alien. The East seemed irredeemably haunted, a place of shadows and lost dreams. As autumn settled in, with the smoke rising from chimneys and the laundry hanging limp on the lines, I knew it was time to leave. I packed my things and prepared to return home to the Midwest, to the place where I truly belonged.

- The vivid dream-like sequence involving a surreal night scene and the group of men with a stretcher is missing entirely.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- Early in the passage, the completion lacks the specific time and setting details, such as the exact hour and the ambiance of the station, as well as the presence of friends and the social rituals of saying goodbye.
- The middle section is missing the sensory details and actions during the train journey, such as the description of the landscape, the feeling of identity with the region, and the transition from the station to the countryside.
- The completion does not include the reflections on the symbolic aspects of the narrator's home region, such as references to local traditions, street scenes, and the emotional tone associated with returning.
- The dream sequence with its surreal imagery and the specific actions of the figures in the dream is absent.
- The final decision to return home is not accompanied by the original’s seasonal and atmospheric cues, such as the mention of smoke and laundry.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion introduces invented details, such as the smell of coal fires and the warmth of the station, which are not present in the original.
- The sequence of events is altered: the completion condenses and generalizes the journey and the reflections, losing the original’s progression from the station, to the train, to the dream, and finally to the decision to return home.
- The completion attributes a sense of comfort and belonging to the Midwest that is more generalized and less nuanced than the original’s complex emotional tone.
- The depiction of the East is simplified and lacks the specific imagery and nuanced critique found in the original passage.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. The journey itself was always a mixture of excitement and reflection, a bridge between the world I was leaving behind and the one I was returning to. The train would cut through the snowy landscapes, the windows framing scenes of quiet towns and frosted fields, each mile bringing me closer to home and the familiar faces that awaited me.

Arriving at the station, the crisp winter air would greet me, carrying the scent of pine and woodsmoke. The streets were often lined with twinkling lights and decorations, a festive glow that seemed to soften the chill. There was a comforting rhythm to the holiday season, a sense of tradition that wrapped around the town like a warm blanket.

At home, the house was transformed. The tree stood tall and proud in the corner of the living room, adorned with ornaments collected over the years, each one holding a story or a memory. The fireplace crackled, casting flickering shadows that danced along the walls, while the aroma of baking cookies and spiced cider filled the air. Family members gathered, their laughter and conversations weaving a tapestry of connection and belonging.

These moments were a stark contrast to the bustling, often impersonal world of school and college. Here, time seemed to slow, allowing for reflection and the rekindling of bonds. The holidays were a pause, a chance to recharge and remember what truly mattered beyond the ambitions and challenges of academic life.

Yet, beneath the surface of these joyful reunions, there was often an undercurrent of change and uncertainty. People grew and evolved, and the dynamics within the family shifted subtly with each passing year. Conversations would sometimes hint at unspoken tensions or dreams deferred, reminding me that even in the warmth of home, complexities remained.

One Christmas, in particular, stands out in my memory. It was a year when the snow fell heavier than usual, blanketing the town in a pristine white silence. The world outside seemed hushed, as if holding its breath. Inside, the atmosphere was charged with a mixture of hope and apprehension. New faces joined the gatherings, and old stories were retold with a bittersweet edge.

During that visit, I found myself wandering the quiet streets late at night, the glow of streetlamps casting long shadows on the snow. The stillness was profound, and in that solitude, I felt a deep connection to the place and the people who shaped me. It was a moment of clarity, a recognition of the passage of time and the enduring nature of home.

Returning West for the holidays was more than a physical journey; it was a passage through memory and identity. Each trip reinforced the ties that bound me to my roots, even as I ventured further into the wider world. The seasons changed, and so did I, but the essence of those Christmas returns remained a constant, a beacon of comfort and continuity amidst the flux of life.

events.title: Ending Affairs: Jordan and Tom
detailed_summary: Before leaving, Nick feels compelled to resolve his situation with Jordan Baker.
He meets her and discusses their relationship and its aftermath.
Jordan listens impassively, dressed for golf.
She informs Nick she is engaged to another man, which Nick doubts but accepts.
As Nick gets up to leave, Jordan confronts him, accusing him of being the one who ended things ('threw me over').
She recalls their earlier conversation about bad drivers, implying Nick was another 'bad driver' she encountered and suggesting his proclaimed honesty was a facade.
Nick responds defensively, citing his age (thirty) as being past self-deception.
Feeling angry, regretful, and still somewhat attracted to her, Nick turns away.
Later, Nick encounters Tom Buchanan on Fifth Avenue.
Tom confronts Nick about seeming unwilling to shake his hand.
Nick asks Tom directly what he told George Wilson on the afternoon of the murder.
Tom confesses he told Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car.
He justifies this by claiming Wilson was armed, threatening, and forced his way into the house.
Tom asserts Gatsby deserved it for running over Myrtle without stopping.
Nick recognizes he can't argue with Tom's distorted version of events.
Tom laments his own 'suffering', mentioning crying over a box of dog biscuits found in the flat he shared with Myrtle.
Nick concludes that Tom and Daisy are careless people who destroy things and retreat into their wealth, letting others clean up their messes.
He shakes Tom's hand, feeling as if dealing with a child, before Tom enters a jewelry store.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then he went into the jewellery store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.

events.text_segment:
There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. But I wanted to leave things in order and not just trust that obliging and indifferent sea to sweep my refuse away. I saw Jordan Baker and talked over and around what had happened to us together, and what had happened afterward to me, and she lay perfectly still, listening, in a big chair.
She was dressed to play golf, and I remember thinking she looked like a good illustration, her chin raised a little jauntily, her hair the colour of an autumn leaf, her face the same brown tint as the fingerless glove on her knee. When I had finished she told me without comment that she was engaged to another man. I doubted that, though there were several she could have married at a nod of her head, but I pretended to be surprised. For just a minute I wondered if I wasn’t making a mistake, then I thought it all over again quickly and got up to say goodbye.
“Nevertheless you did throw me over,” said Jordan suddenly. “You threw me over on the telephone. I don’t give a damn about you now, but it was a new experience for me, and I felt a little dizzy for a while.”
We shook hands.
“Oh, and do you remember”—she added—“a conversation we had once about driving a car?”
“Why—not exactly.”
“You said a bad driver was only safe until she met another bad driver? Well, I met another bad driver, didn’t I? I mean it was careless of me to make such a wrong guess. I thought you were rather an honest, straightforward person. I thought it was your secret pride.”
“I’m thirty,” I said. “I’m five years too old to lie to myself and call it honour.”
She didn’t answer. Angry, and half in love with her, and tremendously sorry, I turned away.
One afternoon late in October I saw Tom Buchanan. He was walking ahead of me along Fifth Avenue in his alert, aggressive way, his hands out a little from his body as if to fight off interference, his head moving sharply here and there, adapting itself to his restless eyes. Just as I slowed up to avoid overtaking him he stopped and began frowning into the windows of a jewellery store. Suddenly he saw me and walked back, holding out his hand.
“What’s the matter, Nick? Do you object to shaking hands with me?”
“Yes. You know what I think of you.”
“You’re crazy, Nick,” he said quickly. “Crazy as hell. I don’t know what’s the matter with you.”
“Tom,” I inquired, “what did you say to Wilson that afternoon?”
He stared at me without a word, and I knew I had guessed right about those missing hours. I started to turn away, but he took a step after me and grabbed my arm.
“I told him the truth,” he said. “He came to the door while we were getting ready to leave, and when I sent down word that we weren’t in he tried to force his way upstairs. He was crazy enough to kill me if I hadn’t told him who owned the car. His hand was on a revolver in his pocket every minute he was in the house—” He broke off defiantly. “What if I did tell him? That fellow had it coming to him. He threw dust into your eyes just like he did in Daisy’s, but he was a tough one. He ran over Myrtle like you’d run over a dog and never even stopped his car.”
There was nothing I could say, except the one unutterable fact that it wasn’t true.
“And if you think I didn’t have my share of suffering—look here, when I went to give up that flat and saw that damn box of dog biscuits sitting there on the sideboard, I sat down and cried like a baby. By God it was awful—”
I couldn’t forgive him or like him, but I saw that what he had done was, to him, entirely justified. It was all very careless and confused. They were careless people, Tom and Daisy—they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made…
I shook hands with him; it seemed silly not to, for I felt suddenly as though I were talking to a child. Then he went into the jewellery store to buy a pearl necklace—or perhaps only a pair of cuff buttons—rid of my provincial squeamishness forever.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better been let alone. I went over to where Jordan was standing, leaning against the wall, dressed for golf, and I told her I was going away. She listened with an impassive face, and then said she was engaged to another man. I didn't believe it and yet I didn't care. I got up to go, and she called out to me, "You threw me over on the telephone." I turned around and looked at her. "I did not!" I said. "You did," she insisted. "You were the one who threw me over. I don't give a damn about you now, but it was a new experience for me, and I felt a little dizzy for a while." She laughed, a short, unpleasant laugh. "You said you were a bad driver," she said. "I was a bad driver too. I was careless. I wasn't honest. I wasn't any good. I was a bad driver." I was thirty. Before me stretched the portentous, menacing road of a new decade. I was not a bad driver, I told her. I was thirty. I was not going to be a bad driver any longer. I turned away, angry and regretful and ready to be alone.

Later, as I was walking down Fifth Avenue, I ran into Tom Buchanan. He looked at me with a curious expression, as if he had been expecting me. "I thought you were going to shake my hand," he said.

"What did you tell George Wilson that afternoon?" I asked.

He hesitated, then said, "I told him Gatsby owned that car."

"Why?"

"Because he was so mad he was liable to have a fit if I didn't. He was armed, and had been in the house. He forced his way in. I had to tell him something."

"But Gatsby didn't kill Myrtle."

"No," he said, "but he ought to be glad it was him. He ran over her, didn't stop, and went away."

I could see that I was not going to get anywhere with him. His version of the events was as distorted as his character.

"You know," he said, "I cried like a baby over that box of dog biscuits I found in the flat I shared with Myrtle."

I shook my head. "They're careless people," I said. "They smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made."

Tom looked at me as if I were a child. I shook his hand and walked away. He went into a jewelry store.

1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion omits the reflective and descriptive introduction about the narrator's motivation for the meeting and the sense of responsibility regarding leaving things in order.

- The completion invents dialogue and internal monologue not present in the original, particularly in the exchange with Jordan about being a bad driver and the narrator's reflections on age and honesty.
- The transition to the encounter with Tom is abrupt and lacks the original's detailed description of Tom's demeanor and actions before the meeting.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion omits the narrator's detailed physical and emotional observations of Jordan, including her appearance and the narrator's internal reactions during their conversation.
- The nuanced exchange about the "bad driver" metaphor is oversimplified, missing the layered references and the original's subtlety.
- The completion skips the narrator's emotional state after the conversation with Jordan, including the complex mix of anger, affection, and sorrow.
- The detailed description of Tom's physicality and behavior as he walks along Fifth Avenue is missing.
- The original's depiction of Tom's defensiveness and the narrator's realization about Tom and Daisy's carelessness is compressed and lacks the gradual build-up.
- The final reflection on the act of shaking hands and the narrator's feelings about Tom is abbreviated, omitting the sense of futility and the narrator's changed perspective.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The setting of the conversation with Jordan is changed from her sitting in a chair to her standing against a wall, which alters the scene's tone.
- The sequence of events in the conversation with Jordan is rearranged, and some lines are attributed incorrectly or invented.
- The narrator's response to Jordan's claim about being "thrown over" is altered, introducing invented dialogue and omitting the original's subtlety.
- The completion introduces invented internal monologue about the narrator's age and intentions, which is not present in the original.
- The conversation with Tom is simplified, omitting the original's tension and the narrator's silent realizations.
- The completion attributes the "careless people" reflection directly to the narrator in dialogue, rather than as internal narration, changing the narrative voice and impact.
- The ending omits the ambiguity about what Tom is purchasing and the narrator's final emotional state, simplifying the conclusion.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
There was one thing to be done before I left, an awkward, unpleasant thing that perhaps had better have been let alone. I had to see Gatsby once more, to say goodbye, to offer some small comfort in the face of the tragedy that had unfolded. The house, once so vibrant and full of life, now seemed a hollow shell, echoing with the ghosts of parties past and dreams unfulfilled.

As I approached the grand mansion, the sun was setting, casting long shadows across the manicured lawns. The air was thick with the scent of wilting flowers and the faint trace of expensive perfume, remnants of the revelry that had ceased abruptly. The silence was oppressive, a stark contrast to the laughter and music that had once filled these halls.

I found Gatsby in the library, seated alone amidst the towering shelves of books, his gaze distant and contemplative. He looked up as I entered, a faint smile touching his lips, though it did little to mask the weariness in his eyes.

"I didn't expect to see you again," he said softly.

"I had to come," I replied. "There are things left unsaid, and I couldn't leave without speaking to you."

He nodded, understanding. "It's strange how life can change so quickly, how dreams can shatter in an instant."

We sat in silence for a moment, the weight of unspoken words hanging between us. I thought of Daisy, of the choices made and the consequences that followed. Gatsby's unwavering hope, his relentless pursuit of an ideal, had led him to this tragic end.

"Do you regret it?" I asked finally.

He looked at me, his eyes shining with a mixture of sadness and resolve. "No. I don't regret a single moment. For a time, I believed in something beautiful, something worth fighting for. Even if it was just a dream."

The room seemed to grow colder, the shadows lengthening as night fell. I stood, knowing that this was our final farewell.

"Take care of yourself, Gatsby," I said.

He smiled once more, a genuine warmth in his expression. "And you, Nick. Remember, there are no second chances in this world."

I left the mansion, the weight of the evening pressing heavily upon me. As I walked away, I couldn't help but reflect on the fragility of dreams and the harsh realities that often accompany them. Gatsby's story was a testament to the enduring human spirit, a reminder that even in the face of despair, hope can shine brightly, if only for a moment.

events.title: Final Departure and Meditation on the Past
detailed_summary: Upon leaving, Nick notes Gatsby's house remains empty, the lawn overgrown.
He observes a local taxi driver who often points out the house, speculating the driver might have witnessed the accident and created his own narrative.
Nick avoids the driver, not wanting to hear speculative stories.
He recalls spending Saturday nights in New York, haunted by the vivid memories and sounds of Gatsby's parties.
