events.text_segment:
Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine. One of the taxi drivers in the village never took a fare past the entrance gate without stopping for a minute and pointing inside; perhaps it was he who drove Daisy and Gatsby over to East Egg the night of the accident, and perhaps he had made a story about it all his own. I didn’t want to hear it and I avoided him when I got off the train.
I spent my Saturday nights in New York because those gleaming, dazzling parties of his were with me so vividly that I could still hear the music and the laughter, faint and incessant, from his garden, and the cars going up and down his drive. One night I did hear a material car there, and saw its lights stop at his front steps. But I didn’t investigate. Probably it was some final guest who had been away at the ends of the earth and didn’t know that the party was over.
On the last night, with my trunk packed and my car sold to the grocer, I went over and looked at that huge incoherent failure of a house once more. On the white steps an obscene word, scrawled by some boy with a piece of brick, stood out clearly in the moonlight, and I erased it, drawing my shoe raspingly along the stone. Then I wandered down to the beach and sprawled out on the sand.
Most of the big shore places were closed now and there were hardly any lights except the shadowy, moving glow of a ferryboat across the Sound. And as the moon rose higher the inessential houses began to melt away until gradually I became aware of the old island here that flowered once for Dutch sailors’ eyes—a fresh, green breast of the new world. Its vanished trees, the trees that had made way for Gatsby’s house, had once pandered in whispers to the last and greatest of all human dreams; for a transitory enchanted moment man must have held his breath in the presence of this continent, compelled into an aesthetic contemplation he neither understood nor desired, face to face for the last time in history with something commensurate to his capacity for wonder.
And as I sat there brooding on the old, unknown world, I thought of Gatsby’s wonder when he first picked out the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock. He had come a long way to this blue lawn, and his dream must have seemed so close that he could hardly fail to grasp it. He did not know that it was already behind him, somewhere back in that vast obscurity beyond the city, where the dark fields of the republic rolled on under the night.
Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that’s no matter—tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms further… And one fine morning—
So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine. I hadn’t seen him for a week and a half, and I didn’t see him again. I drove over to his house one afternoon, and the windows were all dark and the house looked as though it had been closed up for a long time. I thought of the taxi driver who used to point out Gatsby’s house to his passengers, and I wondered if he had seen the accident and made up his own story about it. I didn’t want to hear any more of those stories, so I avoided the taxi driver.

On Saturday nights in New York, I used to go to the city and wander through the streets, haunted by the memories of Gatsby’s parties—the music, the laughter, the glittering lights. One night, I saw a car pull up to Gatsby’s house, but I didn’t go over. I assumed it was a late guest who didn’t know the party was over.

On my last night in West Egg, I went to Gatsby’s house one final time. I found an obscene word scrawled on the steps, and I wiped it away with my shoe. Then I walked down to the beach and lay on the sand, looking out at the closed shore houses and the Sound. As the moon rose, the landscape seemed to dissolve, and I thought of the old island as the first Dutch sailors must have seen it—a fresh, green breast of the new world.

I thought of the trees that had been cut down to make way for Gatsby’s house, symbols of the lost American dream. I remembered Gatsby’s wonder at the green light across the bay, how close his dream had seemed. But Gatsby didn’t realize that the dream was already behind him, lost in the vastness of America.

He believed in the orgastic future that kept receding before us. Despite the dream’s elusiveness, I recognized the persistent human impulse to strive toward it—to run faster, to stretch out our arms farther. The book ends with the image of humanity struggling against the current of time, constantly being pulled back into the past.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Gatsby’s house was still empty when I left—the grass on his lawn had grown as long as mine. I could see the windows, gleaming white against the fresh grass, and the house looked as if it had been waiting for something, or someone, to fill it again. The silence was almost tangible, a stark contrast to the wild parties and laughter that had once echoed through its halls. It was as if the very walls were holding their breath, waiting for the return of the man who had made the place come alive.

I walked slowly down the driveway, my footsteps muffled by the thick grass. The air was heavy with the scent of summer, but there was an undercurrent of melancholy that I couldn’t shake. Gatsby’s dream, so grand and shimmering, seemed to have faded into the dusk, leaving behind only shadows and memories.

As I reached the gate, I looked back once more at the house. The lights were off, the curtains drawn, and the garden was overgrown, wild and untamed. It was a stark reminder of the fragility of dreams and the passage of time. Gatsby had built his world on hope and illusion, but in the end, it was all just a beautiful, tragic story.

I thought about the green light across the bay, the symbol of Gatsby’s yearning and ambition. It still shone faintly in the distance, a beacon of desire and the promise of something just out of reach. But now, it seemed distant and cold, a reminder of what could never be.

Turning away, I felt a deep sadness settle over me. Gatsby’s house, once a palace of dreams, was now just an empty shell, a monument to a man who had dared to dream too big. The world moved on, indifferent to the hopes and heartbreaks of those who lived within it.

As I walked back toward the city, the sun dipped below the horizon, casting long shadows over the land. The night was coming, and with it, the quiet that follows the storm. Gatsby’s story was over, but its echoes would linger, a testament to the enduring power of dreams and the inevitable cost of chasing them.

In the end, Gatsby was more than just a man; he was a symbol of the American Dream itself—brilliant, elusive, and ultimately unattainable. His house, like his life, stood as a reminder that sometimes, the brightest lights burn out the fastest, leaving behind only darkness and the faintest glimmer of what once was.
